PETITION.TITLE: Telecom: 0055 Services
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth that:
1. Telecom is selling 0055 telephone networks to private contractors who provide offensive and sexually explicit recorded messages to the public.

2. The providers of these services are advertising in the pages of Australian newspapers in a manner which is designed to titillate and attract calls from the whole community and thus play on the curiosity of children.
3. These services degrade and humiliate women and portray them as sex objects, and they destroy the innocence of children.

Your petitioners request that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, immediately call on Telecom to so regulate the conditions under which these services are made available, that women are no longer portrayed as sex objects, degraded or humiliated and that the innocence of children is protected.
And your petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Newman (from 4,632 citizens) and Panizza (from 122 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Australian War Memorial
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the Speaker and The Honourable Members of the Senate in the Parliament assembled. The humble Petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia showeth that whereas:

``We, the undersigned, wish to signify our strong opposition to the proposal that an admission charge be made for entry into the Australian War Memorial. We believe that it was erected as a Memorial to the dead and that the material on display is as much of a memorial nature as the building itself''.

PETITION.TITLE: Medicare: Abortions
PETITION.PARA: The Honourable President and members of the Senate assembled in Parliament. This petition of the below citizens of Australia draws to the attention of the Senate that we support the continued cover for all abortions on the Medicare schedule. We oppose any attempt to restrict access to the rebate under Medicare.

Medicare cannot pretend to be a Universal health care system without providing a rebate for a termination of pregnancy. Those who will be hardest hit by proposals to restrict access to items 6469, 274 and 275 on the Medicare schedule are poorer and disadvantaged women who will not be able to meet the cost of a non-subsidised abortion.
Your petitioners humbly pray and request that the Senate will vote against any attempt to restrict access to abortion or any abortion-related items on the Medicare schedule.

PETITION.TITLE: Bushmead Rifle Range
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and Members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The humble petition of the undersigned citizens of Australia respectfully showeth:
That your Petitioners request the Senate to urge the Federal Government to retain the Bushmead Rifle Range in Western Australia;
That it remain in the hands of the Federal Government with a commitment to its ongoing use by the various rifle clubs of Western Australia.
Your Petitioners pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should heed the above.
And your Petitioners, as in duty bound, will ever pray.

PETITION.TITLE: United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child
PETITION.PARA: The Petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth their deep concern that the United Nations Convention on the Rights of the Child:
1. (a) makes inadequate provision for a subjective judgement by parents as to what is in the best interests of their children,
(b) makes inadequate provision for parents to use their discretionary powers to act on such judgements.
2. creates the potential for conflict between parent and child (rather than the atmosphere of happiness, love and understanding mentioned as valuable in the preamble).
3. will produce closer monitoring by Government agencies of relationships between parents and children.
Your Petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in the Parliament assembled, should:
1. By Act, ensure that all international treaties (excluding national security) are debated by the Parliament.
2. Take action to have the Convention amended in order to pay the highest regard to the importance of the family unit, and to the rights and responsibilities of parents.

Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Robert Ray) agreed to:

Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to facilitate the use of schemes of arrangement in complex corporate structures.

Where a group of companies consisting of a holding company and wholly-owned subsidiaries is to be involved in a scheme of arrangement, the law at present requires meetings to be held of each class of creditors of each company involved and each meeting must agree to the scheme. Where many group companies are involved in a number of States, the number of creditors' meetings required may run into the hundreds. The requirement of holding separate meetings can therefore present an enormous impediment to the creditors of a group of companies, seeking such an arrangement or compromise.

The legislation arises from the winding up of the Hooker group. In December 1989 the Government was approached by legal advisers to the provisional liquidators of the Hooker group of companies seeking an amendment to the Companies Act because of the considerable practical difficulties which the provisional liquidators were facing. Essentially, the problem faced by the liquidators was the need to convene some 500 separate meetings of various creditors across the whole of Australia because of the complex interrelationship of the ninety-odd companies which made up the Hooker group. The provisional liquidators were concerned that in these circumstances there was a real risk that it would not be possible to reach agreement on an appropriate scheme of arrangement which would enable the affairs of the companies to be wound up in a way which provided the maximum protection for creditors. What was originally sought was a specific amendment relating to the affairs of the Hooker group.

My predecessor accepted that there was a need to facilitate schemes of arrangement for complex company structures. He was not, however, convinced that a legislative amendment simply to facilitate the winding up of the Hooker group was either appropriate or desirable. The Government agreed that legislation should be developed which would provide a general solution to problems of this kind. An essential element of such a scheme was that a court should decide whether or not a consolidated meeting of creditors should be held. This would enable the interests of shareholders to be protected as they could ensure that the court was aware of considerations particular to the circumstances of each case. A Bill was prepared as a matter of considerable urgency and discussions were held with the Australian Democrats and the Opposition. The Government proposed that the legislation would be passed by both Houses before the Parliament rose at the end of the Budget Sittings. This course of action required the co-operation of both the Opposition and the Australian Democrats. It is unfortunate that, despite support from a number of senior members of the Opposition, it was not possible to reach agreement with the Opposition on the passage of the legislation. Because of the effluxion of time since the Hooker provisional liquidators proposed the legislation, there is no longer any certainty that the Bill when it becomes law will be used in that administration. It will, however, be available for other administrations of complex groups.

The Government was advised at the time the legislation was being prepared that major creditors were prepared to support a scheme of arrangement involving a consolidated meeting of creditors which would involve the payment of $45m to the small business creditors while major creditors waited for a considerable period for the assets of the Hooker group to be realised. Because of the failure of the Opposition to support the passage of this Bill that arrangement was not able to be put in place.

Once it was apparent that the Opposition would not support the legislation which, I might add, had been the subject of agreement from each State and Territory Government under the existing co-operative scheme, the then Attorney-General released an exposure draft of the Bill for public comment. The exposure draft has received considerable support from interested groups including the Insolvency Practitioners' Association of Australia, the Law Council of Australia and the State Corporate Affairs Commissions.

This Bill will enable a court to order meetings of creditors of a group of companies on a consolidated basis where the scheme of arrangement will have the effect of transferring assets, property and liabilities to the holding company. This consolidation will reduce the total number of meetings to a manageable number.

The power given to the court is in addition to the powers the court already enjoys under the Companies Act, and the power is to be used in conjunction with the discretions the court has in determining the classes of creditors and protecting the interests of creditors.

This Bill differs from the exposure draft in one respect. The exposure draft provided that the power to order a consolidation should arise only where the number of subsidiaries of the group was at least thirty. As a result of consideration by the Ministerial Council, this Bill allows consolidation orders to be made where the court considers that circumstances exist which would justify making such an order where there are fewer than thirty subsidiaries involved.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: PRIMARY INDUSTRIES AND ENERGY LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL (No. 2) 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 5 March, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That this Bill be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —When the debate was interrupted last night I was making the point that the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 cannot be disagreed with in that it tidies up some drafting inadequacies which caused a few unintended consequences and anomalies. Therefore, the Australian Democrats will not be opposing it. I made the point in passing that it is a frustrating situation to be dealing with legislation which is of little consequence at a time when a great number of our rural communities are in the process of trying to get a message across to their parliamentarians.

SPEECH.PARA: In the second reading speech we are told that the purpose of this Bill is to remove minor legislative inconsistencies and establish a framework for research and development. The implication throughout the speech was that the changes would lead to wondrous things in primary industry. It is all very well to have that framework, provided that the basis and direction of primary industry policy ensures that there will be a primary industry to start with. We are not convinced at the moment that there will be.

I repeat that we are spending time talking about this sort of legislation when there are other matters to consider. Yesterday the Senate debated a matter of public importance, brought on by the Opposition, which did not seek to address the very matter that thousands of farmers want to communicate to this Parliament. We have used the time of the Senate to give all sorts of notices of motion and to consider other business of the Senate but we have not debated what we should be doing to bring about practical, active assistance to our primary industries.

I do not want to labour this point which I have already made several times. We should not waste too much time on this matter. We should pass the legislation and get on with the business of the Senate.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Crane Sen W.

TALK.START.PARA: —As has already been explained, the Primary Industries and Energy Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) 1990 seeks to make some minor amendments because of drafting problems. I want to highlight some aspects of the Bill and refer to some research contributions and their effects. I also want to agree with Senator Bell that we are spending time correcting mistakes that have been made because of insufficient attention to the initial drafting when we should be addressing the very serious situation now facing much of rural, provincial Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: First, I want to refer to a matter which I do not believe has been satisfactorily dealt with yet and which, if not resolved, could well result in the legislation coming back to this chamber again. I refer to the time limit for the Minister to grant approval after recommendations have gone to him. I believe that it is absolutely imperative that when a recommendation goes forward in terms of one of the research councils, the Minister should respond to it in a positive manner within a certain time and that if he does not, he must give the reasons for not doing so. It is inconceivable to me that under section 20 of the principal Act there is no discipline over the response of the Minister in terms of his responsibilities.

I want to highlight some of the things that have occurred in rural research in recent times. In the cattle industry, some $63m a year of growers' funds is collected by way of a transaction levy and is used for promotion, marketing and inspection. Producers are paying $3.15 per head. An amount of $9.2m, of which $4.6m is raised by producers and $4.6m by processors, is paid into the Australian Meat and Livestock Research and Development Corporation area. I would like to highlight the fact that $21m has been allocated to the brucellosis and tuberculosis eradication campaign.

I would like to say something about methods of funding the national residue survey, which is now an industry responsibility rather than a government responsibility. While one can debate the community or government responsibility, I believe that there has been a reneging of responsibility. Export testing under the national residue survey not only benefits producers. It is worth noting that in 1987, when we had problems with the residues in exports, some 297 tests into cadmium in beef were carried out in Australia under the national residue survey. With the changes to the financial arrangements, in 1988 the number of tests grew to 2,878-a tenfold increase. When we look at all beef testing for the various residue problems that we had at that time, we find that in 1987 just under 10,000 tests were carried out. In 1988, as I said before, changes were made in terms of funding and the number grew to some 26,000 tests.

It is quite obvious that the change to the method of funding has certainly made a difference in terms of the emphasis placed on testing. In terms of the 26,000 samples taken in 1988, only 16 violations were found. If we compare the Australian situation with that in other countries we find that we are second to none in terms of the level of residues in our export meat, particularly the beef industry. There is no doubt that much of the problem that occurred with the industry was political rather than factual. I believe that the increase in testing has certainly improved Australia's reputation worldwide. We are now poised, particularly in the beef market and, hopefully, in the not too distant future in the mutton market, to make some more significant penetrations.

In the debate on this Bill I want to highlight a number of points. It is rather unfortunate that the things we are discussing now are not as important as some of the things we should be looking at. Senator Bell has already picked up the point made yesterday by Senator Tambling about the letters presented to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), Dr Hewson and Mr Tim Fischer, which deal with the very significant problems that currently exist in rural Australia.

I would like to draw the attention of the Senate to what happened yesterday when some 300 Western Australian farmers went to Midland seeking work and listed themselves for the unemployment benefit. I do not believe the Government is anywhere near coming to grips with the seriousness of the situation existing in rural Australia. When I talk about rural Australia I am obviously talking about the producers, the farmers and the graziers at the bottom line, and also about the service industries and the infrastructure that goes with them. In the current situation in the rural areas this infrastructure is at risk. The role played by local government-the shires-is at risk because we are moving towards a situation, which probably has not occurred since the 1930s, where people will not be able to pay part of their rates, let alone all of them.

Many things could be addressed here. They were listed yesterday in the debate on the motion moved by Senator Lewis. I was particularly disappointed with Senator McMullan's approach to this subject. Rather than address the shortcomings of the Government's current policies, he chose to attack the policies of the Opposition. In fact, he went so far as to claim that in some areas the Opposition does not have a policy. I find that very strange, particularly considering the failure of the Government since 1983. Regardless of how the economic and industrial policies of the Government are measured, the result has been an enormous blowout in our national debt and a monetary and fiscal policy which has led to excessively high interest rates and has caused many of the problems now being faced by rural Australia and its associated businesses and the bankruptcies that have occurred. Those policies have had an adverse impact in terms of interest rates and the flow-on through to the value of the dollar.

It was rather interesting to note on television over the last couple of mornings that the value of the dollar has dropped about 1.5c. People may not realise this but, for wheat growers, that means approximately an extra $3.50 a tonne return. Many of the problems in relation to the wool stockpile and the wool industry could have been avoided had the Government not continued with its high interest rate, high dollar policy. It is worth noting that, when wool purchases by the Australian Wool Corporation peaked, the dollar was at US83c and 70 per cent of the clip was being bought whereas, when the dollar was at US75c, only 35 per cent of the clip was being bought. Many of the problems in the wool industry were created purely and simply by the Government's monetary and fiscal policy.

Today I want to spend some time on a number of industrial relations cases that have occurred recently in Australia. We have heard much from Senator Cook about reliance on the umpire in determining the system that exists and in getting a rational and fair decision. I want to highlight four cases today. I think what is now occurring in this country is an absolute disgrace, particularly as it affects a number of our key perishable commodities. I want to refer specifically to the meat dispute in Victoria and the SPC and Heinz cases. Perishable commodities are involved in each of these cases. When irresponsible people take industrial action in cases involving perishable commodities, much valuable produce goes straight down the drain and that is what has occurred.

In the two cases involving the Australasian Meat Industry Employees Union in Victoria and in other States and in the Heinz case, directions have been given by the Arbitration Commission-the so-called umpire-for workers to go back to work and get on with the job because their case could not be sustained. However, what did that mean? Absolutely nothing! The unions just thumbed their noses at the Commission's decisions and we find that the umpire, without the ability to discipline them, is just laughed at.

Before I come to the figures on these cases, I touch briefly on another case in terms of structural efficiency, another matter of which we have heard much. It is worth noting that, on the other side of this chamber, only Senator Robert Ray is present and he is not paying any attention, anyway. I want to highlight the case in respect of the Federal pastoral award and refer to the principal structural efficiency changes made in that case. The Arbitration Commission put an order in place relating to increases in wages in the Federal pastoral award and said that, in the event of wet weather, shearers, crutchers and associated rouseabouts could work for up to 40 hours per week including weekends. That was a very sensible and essential reform, but what happened?

The New South Wales branch secretary, Ernie Ecob, came out and said, `We will not do it.' He advised shearers to ignore it and to cross out form 10, I think it is, and write in a different clause saying that they would not do it. What is the point of Senator Cook, who is the Minister for Industrial Relations, talking in this place about structural efficiency and reform? What is the point of Senator Cook talking about the umpire when unions blatantly thumb their noses at the umpire? What is the point of the Arbitration Commission, which would have to be the most ineffective institution in this country, spending millions of dollars of taxpayers' money sitting down at hearings and bringing down decisions or orders-the umpire's orders to quote Senator Cook again-which are totally ignored?

I do not believe the Government is serious about structural efficiency. The Government sits back and says, `Let the umpire have another look at it'. However, the umpire has made his decision. He has gone through the process of analysing it and has come up with a sensible response which would have increased productivity and efficiency and would have addressed some of the problems we face in Australia. What happened? Nothing, because the unions still go out and hold the individuals-in this case the wool producers-to ransom. I will give a little warning here-the wool producers have had enough. They are going to stand up and fight. They will not take this lying down.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have a look around a few of the shearing sheds in the west about the weekend shearing.
—Yes, and it is an absolute nonsense.

SPEECH.PARA: I move on to make some brief comments on the SPC agreement. There was an agreement between the parties for real structural reform, a true enterprise agreement in which there would be profit-sharing and significant changes to the award under which all the parties were winners in the medium and long term. There is no doubt that in the short term sacrifices were being made, but they were being made on both sides of the scale. What happened? We mixed in big brother, the union boss, and the Industrial Relations Commission, and all that happened was that there was little if any structural reform and a reduction in workers' wages. There was no long term future, no security, no effective breakthrough in industrial relations. We ended up with the worst possible scenario and delayed the inevitable for a short time.

I wish to talk a little about the Heinz case with regard to the tomato industry and what has occurred there. This would have to be one of the most despicable disputes that has ever arisen in this country. A tomato has a useful commercial life of about three days, and despite a direction from the Australian Industrial Relations Commission-a direction given by Senator Cook's umpire-to the workers concerned to go back to work and get on with the job and to sort out the problems through the proper processes, what did those people do? They stayed out on strike, tomatoes were ploughed back into the ground, tins of baby food were not produced and the very viability of the Heinz operation was put at risk.

It is worth running through some of the events that have occurred during the period of the dispute. On 20 February 1991-and one would think we were living in 1673 rather than in 1991-at the peak of the three-day period of which I have spoken, a 24-hour picket was set up outside the plant. It is about time that somebody got a bulldozer to push some of these pickets aside and allowed this country to get on with its job. Why did the workers set up the picket? It was because a couple of employees had been sacked by the company for unauthorised absences. They had had numerous warnings about the fact that they were coming late to work. Their case was taken to the Industrial Relations Commission. On 22 February 1991, the Commission issued a recommendation that union members should return to work. What happened? They stayed on strike. They ignored the umpire; the umpire was not worth a crumpet. What would have happened in the West Indies in the test match if Greg Matthews, having been given out when apparently he did not hit the ball, had stayed at the wicket and refused to go? That is precisely what is happening now in the case I have mentioned. I see Senator Robert Ray looking up. I am sure that he would not endorse the action that has been taking place during this dispute-or perhaps he likes the idea of tomatoes being ploughed into the ground. Maybe that is his scene-I do not know-but it is an absolute disgrace.

Let me look further at what has happened during this dispute. Some 2,000 tonnes of tomatoes were ploughed into the ground; 840 tonnes of fresh tomatoes worth $125,000 at the works rotted in their cases. The strike has crippled the main plant. The plant normally produces 1.25 million cans or bottles of product each working day. Those have been lost to the gross domestic product of this country, lost to our exports. Let us look at the position on 26 February 1991. The strike had cost the company and growers $5.5m in the past week; Heinz was losing $1m a day in sales alone. Let us go through estimations made on 27 February. We find that Victorian tomato growers were losing $500,000 a week. As one goes through this sad and sorry saga one appreciates better the impossible situation in this country, which is supposed to have an industrial relations system. Senator McMullan had the gall to stand up here yesterday and say that the Opposition did not have a wages policy, when we have in this country an industrial relations system that is so damned one-sided that it is an absolute disaster.

In talking about the rural situation and its problems, and when we look at the Australian situation in general-our current account problems, our negative growth and the blow-out in our national debt-we realise that, unless that side of the equation is addressed effectively in the statement to be made on 12 March, we shall keep on going down the drain at 100 miles an hour. It is no good getting up in here and quoting figures as to how things have improved or how much better things are now than they were in the Fraser years. That is totally irrelevant in today's scenario. We now have the worst kind of guerilla warfare. Perishable products are being deliberately selected for action, and the abuse of the Industrial Relations Commission, the umpire, has become untenable. Some action needs to be taken in the current position that will give power to the Commission to apply orders that have some weight. Perhaps something similar to a sequestration order needs to be used so that the people who seek to hold companies, individual growers and the country to ransom will have to pay, and pay very dearly, for their irresponsibility.

Each case that I have highlighted-and one could address them over a significant period because there is a whole host of other angles-has been in defiance of the umpire. It was not as if there had been an endeavour to obtain agreement in a genuine case through the Industrial Relations Commission. Those concerned took the law into their own hands. This is particularly relevant in terms of the pastoral industry award. What did the New South Wales branch of the Australian Workers Union do? It did not take its concerns about the extension of the structural efficiency changes back to the Commission; it decided to make its own set of rules and to do what it wanted to do.

As I said earlier, the wool industry and individual growers will not take this lying down. I highlighted the fact that in Midland, just outside Perth in Western Australia, 300 farmers-good hardworking Australians, people who do not want to go on strike but who want to work-went to register for employment at the employment bureau. That is a very different attitude from what we see occurring here.

I think it is absolutely essential when these matters are brought before this place for us to start addressing some of the serious anomalies. We should start looking for answers as to why our major rural industries have been brought to their knees. We should start to apply those answers and put a stop to the sorts of selective guerilla tactics that are occurring in this country right now. In this way we are losing valuable produce that could earn this country export dollars. It is produce that could create employment and increase our gross domestic product. It is time that we stopped this wastage and the irresponsibility that has been perpetuated by a few totally irresponsible Australians. If we are to take such action it is essential, unless the Government is prepared to adopt our approach to industrial relations and allow true enterprise agreements to be developed, that the Industrial Relations Commission be given some real teeth to deal with the industrial bandits who are tearing the heart out of a number of individuals.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Brownhill Sen D.G.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want to spend a moment of the Senate's time today during debate on this omnibus legislation to make some remarks in respect of rural industries generally and the meat industry specifically. As the Senate already knows, members of the National Farmers Federation and New South Wales farmers yesterday presented 35,000 letters in front of Parliament House in a protest to the Federal Government about the way things are going in rural Australia. It was coincidental yesterday also that in the rural industries grain prices fell across the board by about $30 a tonne, which was another slug to the grain growers of this country.

SPEECH.PARA: The letters that came in yesterday were for the most part addressed to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and to the Treasurer (Mr Keating). As we heard in Question Time yesterday, the Prime Minister is a man with many responsibilities and it would seem that he is too busy to spend any time with rural people or worrying about rural industries. However, as we learnt yesterday from Senator Button, he is not too busy, and neither should he be, to spend a day at the cricket. If that is the Prime Minister's priority, obviously that is why Australia has some of the problems that it has now. It is a sad reflection of the importance that this Government places on agriculture.

For years, agriculture has been the convenient milking cow for this Government. Rural Australia has provided this country with much needed export income; it has for generations. It now seems that the Prime Minister and the Treasurer are too busy to see these export income providers when they need help. As I said, all those letters that came from the farmers were addressed to the Prime Minister and the Treasurer. Unfortunately, they did not turn up.

The legislation that we are debating changes amongst other things the name of the Australia Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation (AMLRDC) to the Meat Research Corporation. I am told that this is being done to avoid confusion with the Australian Meat and Live-stock Corporation. Other amendments will confine the Government's commitment to match industry research funding to 0.5 per cent of the gross value of production. There are a lot of people who live in cities and other areas away from the rural areas who say that farmers get handouts from the Government. There are still many who believe that the wool floor price scheme was a scheme for getting money from the Government; it was not. But this legislation restricting Government funding to 0.5 per cent shows very clearly that rural industry is overwhelmingly self-supporting, which it has been for years and which it will have to be in the future.

The AMLRDC has an annual budget of around $42m with over $13m coming directly from livestock levies and charges. I congratulate some of the people who were in that Australian Meat and Live-stock Research and Development Corporation: the Chairman, Nigel Monteith, the Executive Director, Ian McCausland, Kevin Bowtell, Archer Field, John Hall, Brian Hickman, Gerald Martin, Gardner Murray, Peter Stewart, Leonie Still, and Tony Wharton. They all do a great job for their industry as far as research is concerned. It is significantly important to people in the rural areas, especially in the livestock industries.

The Corporation's most recent annual report, from which I have quoted those names, clearly outlined the various research projects that it is doing. I think that the range is as broad as it is exciting. However, I would like to think that one area that the Corporation might turn its attention to is research that demonstrates the healthy qualities of meat. Given that we are living in a rural economy, it depresses me that I read the following article in the Canberra Times on Tuesday, 5 March:
Statistics revealing a shift towards a healthier diet.
Australian Bureau of Statistics figures issued yesterday revealed a shift toward a healthier diet, fresh vegetables, white meat

The most dramatic change in Australian diets appears to be the shift away from red meat, Australians getting through 83.3 kg a head in 1987-88, compared with 86.1 kg in 1982-83 and 112.4 kg in 1958-59.

I could say, and I am quite sure that the Minister for Defence (Senator Robert Ray), who is at the table, would agree with me that red meat is good for us. Anything is good for us that is within the bounds of keeping a good balance in our diets. In fact, if we give away eating red meat, for example, we are going to have a very big problem with our health because of iron deficiencies. We have to keep red meat in our systems. As a person who produces red meat, I would like to see more people eating it, because it is healthy and it is good for us; especially the lean meat that is being produced at the moment.

I think that a reading of that article suggests that Australians are getting healthier because they are eating less red meat. Of course, that really is not the case at all. I believe that there are a lot of benefits from eating red meat. The cattle and sheep producers benefit from it and the person who eats it benefits from it as well. I am not at all happy about articles like that which we see in the papers and which are denigrating one of our Australian industries.

The Meat Research Corporation has been carrying out research trials on new lean meat sheep breeds such as the Coolalee-a breed developed in Australia by an Australian vet-which produced a leaner, larger-framed carcass lamb to cater for health conscious Australians. I would like to see an article in these papers promoting that and promoting something that is going to make things a little better for people in the rural areas by in fact helping people's health.

I had a checkup the other day and the doctor said, `Are you eating much red meat?'. I said, `I am eating a little bit'. He said, `You keep eating it because it is a very important part of anyone's diet to keep eating it; definitely not to eat too much fat but definitely to eat red meat'.

The same developments are occurring with cattle as they are with sheep. We are now seeing the established British breeds of cattle, using crossbreeds with a traditionally leaner European breeds. The message that is perpetuated in Australia that it is somehow not healthy is not right. I can attest to that and I am quite sure that the Minister at the table would attest to that, as would my colleagues on this side.

Rural Australia is desperately strapped at the moment. It is imperative that all Australians start to think about agriculture every time they shop. I think that is a lesson that we could all consider. It is not really achieving a lot if we are buying things off the shelves that have been imported. If this Government is too busy to consider the plight of rural Australia, then it is up to the rest of us, both inside and outside Parliament, to support our farmers. I know that Senator Panizza supports the farmers in Western Australia. Senator Knowles supports the farmers in Western Australia because she knows the value that they are to the economy and to the community. Senator Parer from Queensland, who is sitting on the front bench of the Opposition at the moment, soon to be in Government, agrees with me that we must all do more in our support, consideration and understanding for the Australian farmers.

Since 1971 Australian farmers have increased their productivity by 2 per cent every year. They have done that without any export enhancement program such as United States farmers get. Yesterday in Question Time I asked Senator Button why the Prime Minister was not going on the trade mission. Why is he not leading a bipartisan group consisting of himself, Dr Hewson and Tim Fischer-they would really make a mark in Washington-instead of sending Minister Blewett, who has been there many times? I know that he will do his best. He is sending a backbencher from the Government; of course, we are sending our two frontbenchers-Mr Lloyd, the shadow Minister for primary industry, and Mr Downer, the shadow Minister for trade and trade negotiations. If they were to get into the White House they might have a chance of achieving a little more. Unfortunately, I believe that they will find that they are not heard in the way we need them to be heard. They are trying to get the Americans to understand what their export enhancement program is doing to Australia generally, not just to the Australian farmers. It affects the constituents of Senator Ray just as much as it affects the constituents of those who are principally representing rural areas.

The Australian farmers are the most efficient in the world. It is time that this Government gave us a little thought on the way through and did not neglect the rural industry. I believe the Government will do that at its own peril.

Other aspects of this legislation deal with changes to the Dairy Produce Act and the Horticultural Research and Development Act. They have been well covered by other senators. I am sure that Senator Panizza will cover some of those areas in a moment or two.

I wish to conclude my remarks by reminding honourable senators yet again that while the Prime Minister and the Treasurer of this country might be too busy to worry about rural Australia, our farmers will not be forgotten by the people on this side of the chamber. I have every confidence that they will emerge from this crisis wiser and stronger and back on top of the tree when the Liberal and National parties are the government of this country.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Primary Industries Legislation Amendment Bill (No. 2) is an omnibus Bill which is far reaching. It deals with the changing of names, which has caused confusion. I cannot see why there was such a great amount of confusion. However, the Government claims, and the media considers that these names have been confusing, so we have an omnibus Bill which will correct the situation that exists at present.

SPEECH.PARA: In passing, I mention that this Bill amends the Cattle Transaction Levy Bill. It has only had the name changed. Honourable senators may recall that I spoke pretty strongly on this Bill at the time. I believe that it hurt some part of the industry. I am talking about pastoral area cattle station owners and sheep station owners where there is a walk in, walk out situation and one could not really separate the stock from the rights to the leasing of the station. The rights have been sold on the 99-year lease.

The amendment to the Cattle Transaction Levy Bill was to change the onus on paying certain levies from the processor of meat to the producer of meat. The change occurred around 25 February. When the buyer bought in the saleyards after that one expected that he would be paying more because he had more money to play with, the onus being on the producer to pay the levy.

I have done research around Australia and I can assure honourable senators that there was no change whatsoever in the return to the producer; in fact, it diminished around that time and there was the added burden of having to pay the levy.

We have a great research organisation in Australia which deals with primary industry. Unfortunately, research money will be drying up in time to come. The Government is limited to 0.5 per cent of total production of that industry. The value of the total production will be decreasing, as will research money that is coming from the Government and research money coming out of the industry itself. Research is ongoing. It is not done overnight, over two years or even five years; it is a continual, slow, grinding process and, as I have already said, it will get a reduced amount of money over the years in this downturn.

We certainly have to look into that matter. The Government may have to increase its contribution at least in the short term during the agricultural downturn, otherwise programs will have to be cut. If programs and research are cut, that will have devastating results in the longer term.

I will move on to the rural problems that exist around Australia. I believe that these problems have not yet got through to the Government. As has been mentioned, yesterday representatives of the New South Wales farmers organisation were delivering letters to the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy (Mr Kerin), the Leader of the Opposition (Dr Hewson), and the Leader of the National Party of Australia (Mr Tim Fischer) at the front of Parliament House.

I do not believe that the seriousness of this situation has got through to the Government. I know that some of these problems have not got through to many of my own colleagues from the eastern seaboard and in the heart of the biggest cities. I believe that the people in the west certainly know what is going on because of the number of meetings they have attended. There were 10 or 12 crisis meetings before Christmas and there have been various seminars since Christmas regarding ways to survive this economic downturn. I do not think the Government has a grip of it. If it has, it is not coming out with anything to relieve the situation.

The first week of March has gone and planning for next week's wheat crop in Australia should be in the advanced stages. Farmers who have suffered a downturn certainly do not know which way to go. They do not know whether to plant a crop. If they do intend to plant a crop, those who need finance do not know whether they will get it and where it will come from. This has already had an effect on the suppliers of agricultural imports. At one seminar I questioned a speaker from the fertiliser supply organisation. He told me that compared to this time last year only about 20 per cent of the superphosphate has been distributed. Of course, that could produce logistic problems a bit later in the year when there may be a sudden rush in buying fertiliser and transporting it to the farms. Delivering it from the factories could be a problem. The same situation exists with chemicals that are needed on a crop and the labour that will be hired on those farms when seeding time comes. That is all up in the air. The seasonal workers who normally go out to those jobs, people who spend the rest of the year in shearing sheds, driving council trucks or even in mines, will not be in a position to know what is going on at seeding time.

It is something that the Government must address now that we have got into this situation. The industry has asked for a temporary guaranteed minimum price (GMP) of wheat to do something with the disastrous downturn we have had in the last six months, when the price of wheat around the world has crashed because of the actions of the United States (US) Government and its export enhancement program.

I am not a believer in subsidies, but our own wheat industry willingly gave up the guaranteed minimum price that used to work on a three-year rotation basis, under the Wheat Marketing Bill that went through this Parliament about 18 months ago. Unfortunately, the industry has now woken up to the fact that it should have kept it and maybe given up some of the other aspects that it wanted to keep. It finished up losing the regulation of the domestic market-which I totally agreed with anyhow-but it kept the regulation of the export market. It should have insisted that the Government keep the three-year rotating average. The three-year rotating average used to keep the price from drastically dropping overnight, as has happened in the last six months. Unfortunately, that has gone now, but the industry is trying to get a GMP, even if it is only on a one-year basis.

I believe that the wheat industry could turn around fairly quickly and could turn around in time for next year. Unfortunately, the people who have to borrow finance and who need to be confident about planning to put in a crop need something better than a blue sky to give them encouragement. There is another aspect: if a decent sized crop is not planted for next year we will lose our traditional markets around the world and we have got to hang on to them. I know we are already losing some traditional markets because the US is muscling in on us, but I think the Government should look at a temporary GMP of some sort for next year.

I know that wool will certainly not turn around for five, six or seven years, but wheat could turn around overnight. If it does, then rural Australia could get moving again, even if it is on a temporary basis waiting for wool to turn around as well. The beef industry was doing reasonably well, but if there is to be some shift from wheat and wool to beef I believe we will have an oversupply in the meantime.

I repeat, the Government must look at some sort of GMP. If the Government were to provide a GMP of $150 it would not mean that it would be putting in $30 a tonne. It would mean that it could be. If the wheat industry around the world does turn around-and, as I said, it could turn around overnight-the Government would not have to put up a cent. A GMP would give people the confidence to plant something like a normal crop to maintain the present structure.

Now we have this not-so-high delegation going off to the United States today. When I say `not-so-high delegation' I do not reflect on my colleagues who are going-the shadow Minister for primary industry, Bruce Lloyd, and the shadow Minister for trade and trade negotiations, Mr Downer. I believe that in this situation, the most disastrous for the wheat industry for 50 years, a top level delegation should have gone to the United States, led by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and ably backed by the Leader of the Opposition, Dr Hewson. However, this has already been debated in this chamber, and that was not to be. Obviously, the rural industry and rural communities around Australia are not important enough for the Prime Minister to spend a day in Washington to bring the situation to the attention of his counterpart, Mr Bush. I believe that the Government has failed us badly. As we have cooperated with the United States in the Gulf and other places, such a move would not have been out of the question.

What amazes me is why this delegation which is going off to the United States is not going to the European Economic Community (EEC) as well. In this game of a trade war we need two to tango and there are two sides at fault. There is the US with its export enhancement program, and the European Common Market. Nobody even gives the European Common Market a mention.

Honourable senators may remember that last year I moved a formal notice of motion in this place condemning the United States for its enhancement program-it had just taken a traditional market in West Africa off us. The day after, an agricultural attache of the United States Embassy came around to my office to see me. He thought that the motion regarding the US was fair enough, but he wanted to know why I did not give the European Common Market equal time. At the time I told him, `Well, it was the United States that annoyed me that day; when the EEC annoys me I will do the same'. Unfortunately, not enough attention is being paid to the fact that the European Common Market needs to be made well aware of what it is doing in hurting Australia.

Furthermore, I believe that the delegation should be charged with ensuring the protection of our traditional markets in the Gulf. Iraq was our second biggest customer for wheat after Egypt; Japan was the third; and probably number four was China. With the United States Government having done the most to relieve Kuwait, Australia should make sure that we get back our market share when everything is over, including our share of the live sheep trade into Kuwait. It amazes me once again that this delegation is not moving into that area as well.

I will move on to a few points that have been mentioned by other speakers. Senator Crane, in his very able delivery in this place on this subject, mentioned a few of them. Employer bashing was one of them. He was talking about the graziers and the shearing industry in New South Wales. With Australia being in the economic mess that it is, one would think that members of this Government would let up a certain amount on their continual bashing of, and loading up of responsibilities on, employers. After all, the employer is the one that provides the jobs. I believe that an employer is entitled to a fair return on the capital that he risks. He is not keeping a business going just for the fun of it and to supply employment to employees.

Anyone who read the West Australian last week would have seen an article quoting our illustrious Deputy Speaker of the House of Representatives, Mr Ronald Edwards, regarding a young 16-year-old who was employed in a shopping centre. He was employed by a contract cleaner. Obviously, the cleaner had a contract to do the cleaning in the shopping centre and needed someone to recover the shopping trolleys that were left scattered around the car park and on the street. This 16-year-old was quite happily bringing home $322 a week on average. He could not get a job anywhere else. He had left school the year before.

Mr Edwards pointed out to the union that this boy was working too many hours for that $322. Recovering shopping trolleys is not an arduous job, nor is it continuous. Certain times of the day are quiet. The fiasco created and helped along by Mr Edwards resulted in an argument between the union and the contract cleaner. The shopping centre ended up not being cleaned and the shopping trolleys not being collected. The probable result is that this young fellow, who was bringing home $322 a week, has gone on to the dole queue and social security. The firm doing the cleaning lost the contract. Thanks to Mr Edwards, that is what has happened.

Honourable senators have probably read in the press that Mr Hand, our Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, has made big noises to the effect that Australia has too many illegal immigrants. I agree. But if that is the case, it is the fault-the wrongdoing or slackness-of the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs, which is not catching up with illegal immigrants. What has Mr Hand said? He has said he will increase the penalties on employers who employ-`knowingly', he said-illegal immigrants. Where are we heading? Are we heading back to the Australia Card?

As a longstanding employer, all I know is that I am entitled to ask prospective employees for a tax file number; I have to ask that they sign a tax rebate form and a declaration form if they have dependants; and I think I am entitled to ask that they produce a drivers licence if they will be driving a vehicle of mine. I do not think I am entitled to ask for anything else. I am certainly not entitled to ask for a marriage certificate. I do not think I am entitled to ask for a naturalisation certificate or a birth certificate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Or his passport.

—Or a passport and, in fact, whether or not the person has one. Mr Hand suggests that he will introduce stiff penalties. But who will prove whether these people are employed knowingly or unknowingly? Employer bashing in Australia is increasing. Employers have other things to do as well: they are free tax collectors and free collectors of child support. I know that office work in business has virtually doubled in the last five years.

SPEECH.PARA: I move on to some further problems around Australia. There was a call by Father Brian Morrison in Western Australia for free or cheap meat to be given to needy families. That is a noble gesture and it has been done. But who gives the freebie? The farmer is expected to give away sheep for free or for very little money. The next step is the transport of the sheep. That is not free. Then the sheep go into the abattoirs. That is not free. Senator Crane very ably pointed out the problems in the abattoirs, which I will not go into now. But there are problems with our work practices in terms of the quota system in our abattoirs. Most slaughtermen knock off at 11.30 a.m. with a full day's pay. Because of these and other work practices, abattoirs cannot be kept going 24 hours a day. This meat is provided cheaply or for free but some people are not prepared to do their bit.

I have quoted figures in this chamber time and again and I will provide them again. In Australia it costs a minimum of $13 to slaughter a sheep and put it on the hook; in America it costs under $5. In Australia it costs $19 to put a sheep into cans; in America it costs less than half of that. In Australia it costs $120 per head to slaughter cattle whereas in America it costs from $35 to $40. Even if we want to provide cheap or free meat to the needy, not everyone will do his bit. I do not want abattoir workers to work for nothing; I just want them to do a day's work while they are there and get the product out so that those costs come down and we can provide this cheap meat.

I believe that 12 March will be D-day for all Australian industries and, indeed, all the population. On this day the Prime Minister will bring down an economic impact statement. We do not know what will be contained in that statement but many things need to be done to get this country going again. As I said, hopefully there will be some mention of a temporary GMP for next year's wheat planting. But we also need other things. Probably most of all, we need an accelerated depreciation on developments.

The mining industry is still doing pretty well around Australia and it is contributing to the economy. But unfortunately at this stage it is not going into any major projects. There are certain reasons for that, such as the locking up of resources, aided and abetted by the green movement. Apart from that, some can make a move with accelerated depreciation.

A compact steel mill is proposed in the south-west of Western Australia. This would be very important for Western Australia. A good friend of mine, Dr Ivankovich, has been working on the feasibility of putting such a steel mill in the south-west. But there is no way that we can compete with Indonesia, Taiwan and Korea. I think a similar kind of mill and technology was commissioned in or near Poland last year. There is no way that we can compete with the present labour structure and the taxation structure. With an accelerated depreciation system, I believe that we could get many of those industries going. This would provide employment for the labour from other industries, such as the wheat and wool industries, that are in trouble. I hope that this measure will be included in the statement of 12 March.

Prime Minister Malcolm Fraser moved in this direction in 1975-76-77. Mr Fraser's accelerated depreciation system was more an investment allowance on top of depreciation which meant a doubling up of the investment allowance. He could have placed that extra investment allowance on Australian produced material that went into the industries. Had Mr Fraser done that rather than import material and machinery, Australian manufacturing may have been in a far better position. However, as Australian manufacturing is almost non-existent now, I believe that something like this should be developed, irrespective of whether the materials or the machinery for this technology is imported. Australia, particularly the remote areas, and the industries are in a very precarious position at the present moment. I look forward to measures being announced in the 12 March statement that will assist those industries so that all Australians will be provided with the income and standard of living that we have been used to and hope will continue.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —in reply-Listening to the contributions of honourable senators in this debate, it would have been difficult to believe that they were speaking on a Bill that is concerned with the strategic and operational plans of research and development councils or whether the report concerning the Australian Meat and Live-stock Industry Selection Committee Act 1984 should be placed in the annual report. We have had some wide ranging speeches that were interesting but had nought to do with that Bill.
