DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (INVESTIGATION OF COMMONWEALTH OFFENCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 14 February, on motion by Senator Richardson:
That this Bill be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Hill Sen R.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —The coalition will not be opposing the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Bill 1990, the purpose of which is to give police the specific power, on arresting a person in relation to Commonwealth offences, to question such persons and to carry out further investigations. This is really a question of the balance of the requirements of law enforcement agencies in investigating suspected offences and the civil liberties issues which are inherent in the pre-charge detention of arrested persons. The Opposition has come to the conclusion that it is appropriate that the police should have the power to detain arrested persons for purposes of questioning and investigation and that it is desirable that the detention of persons arrested for Commonwealth offences should be governed by separate Commonwealth legislation.

SPEECH.PARA: The approach in this Bill is to amend the Crimes Act 1914 to provide for the introduction of a fixed period of time during which a person can be detained by the police before being charged in relation to a Commonwealth offence. Having given serious consideration to the arguments advanced by the Government in support of the fixed period of time for precharge detention, the Opposition has come to the view that on balance a more flexible approach would be preferable. Therefore, we will be opposing those provisions of the Bill which set out the time limits and will be moving amendments to provide for the detention of arrested persons for a reasonable time.

The Bill also provides for a number of procedural safeguards relating to the rights of arrested persons, which we support. The most important provision introduced in this Bill is the mandatory tape-recording of confessions and admissions obtained during detention, the giving of cautions, for example, the caution regarding the suspect's right to remain silent, and the arrested person's responses to those cautions are also to be tape-recorded.

The other principal safeguard introduced in this Bill-the statutory right to communicate with relatives and legal practitioners-is also strongly supported by the Opposition. It is presently the case, when a person is arrested for an offence against Commonwealth law, that it is the law of the State or Territory in which the arrest is made that applies, by virtue of the operation of section 68 of the Judiciary Act 1903. There are some specific provisions in various pieces of legislation, such as the Customs Act, that vary this position.

This means that in New South Wales the common law applies and this rule, in slightly varying forms, has been given statutory force in Queensland, Western Australia, Tasmania and the Australian Capital Territory. South Australia has a maximum period of four hours and in both Victoria and the Northern Territory a reasonable time period applies. At common law there is no power to detain the person who is suspected of having committed a crime for the purpose of questioning that person or for completing an investigation. An arrested person should be brought before a magistrate as soon as is reasonably practicable.

For example, in the 1986 High Court decision in the case of Williams the relevant State law provided that the suspect should be brought before a justice as soon as practicable. It was held that the police had no power to question an arrested person about the offence for which he had been arrested or other offences and that a delay in bringing a person before a magistrate could not be justified by the fact that the arresting officer wished to question that person.

The question of whether the police should have the power to detain arrested persons for questioning and, if so, what the limits on the exercise of such a power should be, has been the subject of many inquiries and reports. The major report in this area is that of the Committee Reviewing Commonwealth Criminal Law, chaired by the former Chief Justice of the High Court, Sir Harry Gibbs. The Gibbs Committee came up with a series of recommendations in relation to pre-charge detention. The principal recommendation was that a period of six hours apply in the case of serious offences and in other cases a period of four hours.

In calculating the relevant time period, the Committee recommended that certain periods of so-called dead time be excluded because questioning of the arrested person or investigation of the suspected offence cannot take place. This dead time would cover such matters as the time taken to transport the arrested person to the nearest police station, the time taken for the person to communicate with a relative, a friend or a legal practitioner, and any time during which the questioning is delayed due to the arrested person receiving medical attention or being intoxicated. The Committee took the view that any detention period less than six hours would be impractical due to the difficulties experienced in Victoria in 1984 where the system was introduced of a fixed six-hour pre-charge detention period. An extension could not be made without the consent of the arrested person.

The system proved unsatisfactory in several important respects. The six-hour period was inadequate in the case of complex investigations or where there were multiple offences and the need to apply for extensions of time disrupted the continuity of investigations. The time could easily be eroded by travelling or by obtaining medical treatment or legal advice. There was also a tendency for the six hours to be regarded as the norm rather than as the maximum and arrested persons might be detained for the full six hours when this was unnecessary for the purposes of the investigation involved.

The Coldrey committee, which reviewed the system in 1986, came to the view that the prescription of a fixed period was too inflexible and recommended that the police be required to take an arrested person before a magistrate within a reasonable time. This committee further recommended that dead time be excluded from the calculation of the reasonable time.

This Bill which the Government has introduced is based largely on the recommendations of the Gibbs Committee, although it is proposed that no distinction be made between summary and serious offences in relation to the maximum period of pre-charge detention, which is to be four hours. The maximum period for which a person under the age of 18 years or an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander may be held is to be two hours. The Bill provides for an extension of up to eight hours of that maximum period by way of application to a magistrate, who must be satisfied that this is justified in the particular circumstances of the case.

In calculating the maximum period, provision is to be made for excluding dead time, as recommended by the Gibbs Committee. When the relevant time period expires the person arrested must be either released, unconditionally or on bail, or brought before a magistrate so that the question of bail or remand in custody can be dealt with.

This Bill also addresses the difficulties arising from the situation at common law with respect to confessions obtained during detention. Since the Williams case, where a confession is obtained from a suspect while he or she is in police custody, after the time when it has been reasonably practical to bring him or her before a magistrate, the confession is liable to be rejected at the discretion of the trial judge as having been unlawfully or unfairly obtained. There is an exception where legislation, either Commonwealth legislation or applied State and Territory legislation, lays down a different rule. Under this Bill it will be clear to arresting police that a confession or admission will be admissible only if it is obtained during the permitted period of detention. There is a safeguard for arrested persons in that material relating to confessions or admissions obtained during the pre-charge detention must be tape-recorded.

One aspect of this Bill which disturbs the Opposition is the apparent failure of the Government to consult with the Australian Federal Police and the State and Territory governments about the changes to be introduced by the Bill. We would have thought that consultation with the groups which will be most affected by this Bill would have been an essential part of the process of initiating the significant modifications proposed here. One of the reasons why consultation in this area with the States and Territories is essential is that this Bill may impose significant difficulties upon law enforcement agencies when arresting persons suspected of both Commonwealth and State offences, which is of course a reasonably common occurrence. The most obvious solution is uniform State and Territory legislation. Obviously this cannot be achieved without consultation.

Commissioner McAulay of the Australian Federal Police said in a letter to the National Secretary of the Australian Federal Police Association (AFPA) that he believed that the imposition of arbitrary time constraints on the interrogation of suspects in important and complex matters is impractical and likely to impede justice and is, therefore, against the public interest. He is of the view that these constraints will result in lower detection and conviction rates and an escalation in the costs of trials.

The Australian Federal Police Association was not consulted on the provisions of the Bill. The AFPA rejects the concept of maximum detention times before charging as fraught with risks for the efficiency and effectiveness of Federal law enforcement and the discharge of justice in the interests of the entire Australian community. The AFPA contends that the Federal Police have a higher percentage of complex and advanced investigations than their State counterparts. The length of time available for interviewing persons in custody is an essential element of criminal investigation and must be treated in a flexible case by case manner to be truly successful. Thus, the concept of reasonable time is the only one which can effectively work in the Federal jurisdiction. It also appears that the Federal Government has not consulted with State and Territory governments about the impact of these changes on their police forces when investigating Commonwealth offences.

As I indicated, the Opposition will not be opposing this Bill, but we are of the view that State and Territory governments and the Australian Federal Police should have the chance to contribute their views on this proposed legislation, which will have such a significant effect on their police operations. Furthermore, we believe that the issue of a fixed time period as opposed to a more general specification such as a reasonable time merits reconsideration in the light of the Victorian experience, which found the longer six-hour period unsatisfactory.

The Opposition has, therefore, foreshadowed its intention to pursue these aspects within the committee system of the Senate and within that committee to move an amendment to provide that arrested persons may be detained for a reasonable time. The procedure, I understand, has been implemented for this Bill to be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs after this second reading debate. I trust that at some stage there will be negotiations with the responsible Minister and with the Deputy Chairman of the Committee, who is no doubt talking to the Chairman of the Committee, about getting a range of witnesses before the Committee, probably on Friday week. State Attorneys-General representatives, State police representatives, the Law Council of Australia, and such organisations as the Institute of Criminology, we believe, should have the opportunity to put their views directly before the Federal Parliament; and our committee system and the reference of Bills procedure facilitate that occurring.

Subject to the debate that will occur within the Committee, as I have indicated, we will move our amendment proposing that a `reasonable time' be substituted for the fixed time period provided for in this Bill. We hope that by then the Government will have been persuaded of the merit of our amendment and that the Bill will in due course be carried with the substitution of a reasonable time for the fixed period in the Government's proposal. As I indicated, in all other respects we support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cooney Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I understand from the Leader of the Opposition (Senator Hill), who is quite renowned for his appetite for matters pertaining to civil liberties, that the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Bill 1990 will be referred to the Senate Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, which I have the honour of chairing. Of course, what I say in this debate will not in any way indicate a fixed mind about what I might hear and what might be put to me in that Committee.

SPEECH.PARA: As I understand it, the Bill will be referred to the Committee for its consideration of the question of the proper time to allow the authorities, usually the police, to detain someone for the purposes of conducting investigations before actually charging that person. The issue of whether the police should have a reasonable time to investigate a person before they charge him or her, whether that time should be four hours, six hours or eight hours, when baldly stated does not sound all that dramatic. Although that issue does not seem to be dramatic, it raises issues that are quite fundamental to the sort of society in which we want and expect to live. It raises the question of what is a free, tolerant and just society. One of the centrepieces of such a society is the ability of people to go about their business freely and unhampered and not to be questioned by the state, through the police that it employs or otherwise. That is the matter being discussed here.

It is a matter of public policy in a country such as Australia that people should not be arrested arbitrarily or held at the whim of others. It is also, no doubt, a matter of public policy that when crime is committed it should be detected; indeed, that crime should be prevented before it happens. It is obviously in the interests of the public that that should occur. Clearly, any reasonable society has to equip its police forces with the ability to detect crime and to bring persons alleged to have committed offences before the courts. They are the two public interests that must be balanced against each other.

There is a long tradition in the British common law that addresses those two, as it were, conflicting public interests-although I think they conflict in theory rather than in reality. Clearly, there have to be procedures open to the police to enable them to find out who committed a crime and to prosecute that person. At the same time, there has to be a limit on that. That limit is not inconsistent with the proper means being available to the police to carry out their functions.

Originally, Mr Acting Deputy President, as you no doubt know, the concept was that under common law police could not detain a person for any time at all after arrest for the purposes of carrying out investigations. Since I do not want to indicate that I have a closed mind on this subject, I shall go to what some eminent judges have said over the years to give a flavour of what was once the law. In the case of Wright v. Court and others, the court said that it is the duty of a person arresting anyone on suspicion of a felony to take him before a justice as soon as he reasonably can. It said that the law gives no authority, even to a justice, to detain a person suspected but for a reasonable time until he may be examined.

What was understood to be the meaning of `a reasonable time' and `as soon as practicable' was that a person arrested should be brought before the magistrate as soon as practicable. A different interpretation was put on that by Lord Denning, the Master of the Rolls, in Dallison v. Caffery in 1964. The Wright v. Court matter was heard in 1825, long before Lord Denning came onto the scene. Lord Denning said that, if a constable, as distinct from a private person, arrested somebody suspected of a felony, he could take a reasonable time to investigate the matter before bringing the person before a court. So there was a shift in the meaning of `as soon as practicable' from that of bringing someone suspected of a crime before a court as soon as practicable in terms of the physical ability to get the person from the place of arrest to the court, according to Lord Denning's interpretation, which was as soon as it was practicable for the police to conclude their investigations.

There has been a change in that grand tradition coming down through the common law. There has been a change from the emphasis on protecting people's rights to one of giving the police time for investigation. That was the situation as it applied in England. In Australia there was a disinclination to follow what Lord Denning had said. That is clearly illustrated by a judgment by Mr Justice Hampel of the Supreme Court of Victoria, who in 1983 said:
The words `as soon as practicable' in the section-
of the Victorian Crimes Act-

refer to the time required to bring the person arrested before a justice and not to the time which the police may choose to take after arrest to make further enquiries or conduct further investigations.
He referred to the judgment of His Honour Mr Justice Deane of the High Court of Australia. The words of Mr Justice Deane are worth quoting. He said:

A police power or practice of arbitrary detention is, like a police power or practice of arbitrary arrest, a negation of any true rights to personal liberty and a hallmark of tyranny. It is of critical importance to the existence and protection of personal liberty under the law that the restraints which the law imposes on police powers of arrest and detention be scrupulously observed.

It is in everybody's interest that people be brought to justice, but the means by which they are brought to justice should certainly have some set limits. Since I am quoting judges, it is proper to quote a decision of the Vice-Chancellor, Sir Knight Bruce, who, in 1846, had this to say:

The discovery and vindication and establishment of truth are main purposes certainly of the existence of Courts of Justice; still, for the obtaining of these objects, which, however valuable and important, cannot be usefully pursued without moderation, cannot be either usefully or creditably pursued unfairly or gained by unfair means, not every channel is or ought to be open to them. The practical inefficacy of torture is not, I suppose, the most weighty objection to that mode of examination, nor probably would the purpose of the mere disclosure of truth have been otherwise advanced by a refusal on the part of the Lord Chancellor in 1815 to act against a solicitor, who, in the cause between Lord Cholmondeley and Lord Clinton, had acted or proposed to act in the manner which Lord Eldon thought it right to prohibit.
Then he goes on to say, and I would like to emphasise this:

Truth, like all other good things, may be loved unwisely-may be pursued too . . . . keenly-may cost too much. And surely the meanness and mischief of prying into a man's confidential consultations with his legal adviser, the general evil of infusing reserve and dissimulation, uneasiness, and suspicion and fear, into those communications which must take place, and which, unless in a condition of perfect security, must take place uselessly or worse, are too great a price to pay for truth itself.

When we listen to the arguments put that there ought to be a greater period than four hours-certainly when this matter comes before my Committee I will listen with an open mind-or reasonable time should be allowed, without its being defined, it is to be remembered that this practice of taking people in and detaining them against their will before charging them has had legal sanction in recent times only; that the grand tradition of common law, which we resort to so often, was that a person be arrested and brought before a justice or a magistrate as soon as practicable. The move away from that has brought some very difficult issues as to what should and should not happen.

I notice that the New South Wales Law Reform Commission brought out a report in December last year dealing with police powers of detention and investigation after arrest, and the time period fixed in the model Bill allows for four hours custody before a matter goes before a magistrate-I do not know whether a justice is provided for there-or before the courts. What is wrong with the proposition that a person should be taken before a magistrate after four hours-or whatever is a reasonable time within that period-and put his position to a magistrate?

One concern I have with the Bill-I hope this will be discussed in the Committee-is that an application for an extension of the investigation period can be made in certain circumstances before a justice of the peace. There are many fine people who generously give their time to be justices of the peace, but I have considerable concern about their ability to judge a matter in a way where the result is fair. I am not accusing them of being deliberately unfair, but the way they go about their task may not always result in what is fair.

A long while ago now, in the years when I had occasion to appear before justices of the peace, I found them to be deficient in an appreciation of what the phrase `reasonable doubt' meant. There is always a tendency, I think, for them to accept whatever is asked for by the policing authorities. What is being sought is an eight-hour extension where people can be held and detained without being charged. It is a very serious matter, and to leave that decision before one or more untrained people seems to me to be a fairly adventuresome trend. Again, I have no final thoughts about that issue except to say that I am much concerned at this point that these applications for extension periods can be brought before a justice of the peace.

The fact of the matter is that none of us would like to be detained in some enclosed space in an area where we were being questioned, where we were divorced from our usual surroundings and where we were asked questions which may rightly or wrongly lead us to be convicted.

Oftentimes what is put forward to illustrate the need for a greater period than four hours is the fact that we have complex issues coming before the police. On the other hand, to detain an inexperienced person-who may be 20, still at home, and unused to the world's ways-locked away for four hours could be a matter of considerable terror for him because it is clear that convictions are obtained on confessions that are not true.

An illustration of that is given in the Herald-Sun today. It relates to a hearing in England of six people who were accused of being members of the Irish Republican Army (IRA). They were convicted in the 1970s and there have been several appeals since. Those appeals were rejected. It now appears that much of the evidence, including the confessions, was quite wrongly obtained. That can lead to all sorts of strains. Lord Denning, whom I have already quoted, as it were, opening up the floodgates in this area, had this to say about the appeal of these six people:
If the six men fail-
he is not talking about this particular procedure going on now but an earlier appeal-

it will mean that much time and money will have been expended by many people for no good purpose. If the six men win, it will mean that the police were guilty of perjury, and that they were guilty of violence and threats, that the confessions were involuntary . . . and that the convictions were erroneous. That would mean the Home Secretary would either have to recommend they be pardoned or he would have to remit the case to the Court of Appeal. This is such an appalling vista that every sensible person in the land would say: It cannot be right these actions should go any further.

It is a matter of considerable concern that, where it appears that these confessions-which led to the gaoling of these people for many years-have come under suspicion, a judge of Lord Denning's eminence should say something like that. It is a sign that in giving powers to police and in allowing questioning by them to take place, we have to be very careful to circumscribe them so that this sort of thing should not happen. I should say in passing that Lord Denning later modified, if not withdrew from, that statement. No doubt I will hear arguments from fellow members of the Committee, but it is a matter of considerable concern that the traditional rights that we all enjoy in this society should not be modified or taken away in a way that makes this society different from what it is.

Senator Hill mentioned the Coldrey committee in Melbourne. I must join with Senator Hill and say that the Coldrey committee did great work. I note that Mr Coldrey, QC, is now His Honour Mr Justice Coldrey of the Victorian Supreme Court, having been properly elevated to that position last month. Of course, he is very eminent in law and no doubt will grace the bench in that worthy and great State. That report was made by a committee and all committees, hopefully, are able to compromise. The fact that a reasonable time was agreed to does not mean that we should blindly, or even readily, follow that line.

This important piece of legislation raises these issues. As presently advised, I can see much merit in a four-hour period capable of being extended by another eight hours on a proper application to a magistrate or, in certain circumstances, to a justice of the peace. That four hours will be recorded by video. It seems to me that an interview which runs for four hours will probably provide very good evidence to a jury or a judge about the way in which the alleged confession was made and the weight that should be given to it. But as I say, I stand ready to be convinced. I see that I will be followed by Senator Spindler, who has a great ability to influence the way I think; Senator Tambling; Senator Reid, who has also done much work in this area; and then, of course, the Minister.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate today is debating the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Bill 1990. This Bill is an important piece of legislation, as Senator Cooney and Senator Hill have already indicated. It deals with the conflict that arises between, on the one hand, depriving citizens of their liberty and, on the other hand, the obvious need to allow law enforcement agencies to do their jobs well and without impediment.

SPEECH.PARA: The starting point for this debate is that in a democratic society no-one should be placed under detention merely because law enforcement officers have a suspicion that the person may have broken the law. The 1986 case of Williams v. the Queen confirms the common law position that a person may not be arrested simply for questioning by the police but must be brought before a magistrate or judge as soon as practicable. In other words, there must be good cause for the arrest and the police officer could be subject to penalties for false arrest if he cannot show such good cause for the arrest.

As I have said, this raises the competing public policy requirements that law enforcement officers must be afforded the opportunity to question a suspect, if only to establish whether prosecution is justified and should proceed. Both before and since the 1986 High Court ruling in the Williams case, the dilemma posed by this issue has been examined and reported upon on numerous occasions. In 1975 the Australian Law Reform Commission recommended that a precise time limit should be set for police custodial investigation and that this should be four hours with provision for dead time. Dead time is time not actually spent in questioning the person concerned but in arranging for legal representation, allowing him or her rest periods and other matters that are purely incidental to the questioning process.

In 1989 the Gibbs Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law suggested allowing six hours in the case of serious offences. The Bill before the chamber has the lower limit and also includes the various safeguards recommended by Gibbs and canvassed by the Law Reform Commission; and I will return to these.

This Bill seeks to create a balance between the two competing demands by providing in proposed new section 23c that the investigation period begins when the person is arrested and ends `at a time thereafter that is reasonable' subject to a maximum of two hours for people aged under 18, for Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders, and four hours for all others. Thus we have the notion of reasonable time even in this Bill, which places an outer limit on that time. Even at this stage it may be useful to compare this limit with the six-hour limit introduced in Victoria in 1984, which remained in force until 1988. I will go into some more detail at a later stage but it was found that in 152 out of some 42,000 cases at that time the police required in excess of six hours for questioning people they had arrested. In other words, even when the six-hour limit was in force, for fewer than 0.5 per cent of cases that time was not sufficient. It was a very small percentage.

We should also note at this stage that those six hours did not provide for so-called dead time. At that time, the six hours covered the total time that a person was in custody for questioning purposes. It would be useful to advert to the fact that one of the last proposed sections in this Bill provides for compulsory tape recording of interviews. A survey carried out by the Tasmanian Police Force found that this reduces the actual questioning time by two-thirds.

If we compare the four hours that this Bill provides as an upper limit with the time available in other jurisdictions, such as the Victorian jurisdiction, we are looking at an equivalent of some 12 hours or more that this Bill provides as an outer limit. I think this matter should be taken into account when we debate whether the cap is necessary or reasonable. In saying that, I am very conscious of the arguments put up by the Australian Federal Police, which I will deal with in some greater detail.

The Bill provides for some quite extensive exclusions for so-called dead time. They include the time required to convey the person from the place of arrest to the nearest premises where the investigation is being carried out and the time required to communicate with a legal practitioner, friend, relative, parent, guardian or other person and also to allow such people to come to the place where the questioning is taking place. I do not intend to go through all of them, but these few examples will give some indication of the quite extensive matters covered in the exclusions.

Because I know that Senator Tambling intends to advert to some correspondence from the Chief Minister of the Northern Territory, Marshall Perron, I point out that in his letter the Minister confuses a little the matters that are covered by dead time and the matters that are simply taken into account when the extension of time is being considered. He complains that in the provisions for dead time the Bill does not provide for time taken for medical examinations or for time taken to allow the person to rest. Clearly that is wrong because both matters are contained in the Bill.

He then suggests that the number and complexity of matters to be investigated and the time taken to interview available witnesses and so on also should be included in dead time. But those criteria go to the question of whether or not the time should be extended by up to eight hours on application to a magistrate or a justice of the peace as the Bill currently provides.

In considering this Bill and bearing in mind its importance, I have engaged in considerable and extensive consultation with people who are concerned either as practitioners or as observers. As I have mentioned before, this included the Australian Federal Police (AFP). I wish now to express my appreciation for the assiduousness with which it has provided me with material and for the arguments which were cogently and capably put forward.

I was told yesterday by a journalist that the AFP nonetheless is somewhat disappointed with our stance, which is one of basic support for the Bill, and that it intends to campaign politically against the Australian Democrats as a result of the stance I have indicated we will take. If that is true-I have not been able to verify it although I tried to contact its office this morning but to no avail-I would say that would have to be a matter of regret. I believe that the AFP, in common with other public servants, is not entitled under our system to become politically active if it is unhappy with a particular decision that is arrived at by a political party or indeed by Parliament. I trust that it is a misunderstanding and can be cleared up.

I also wish to express at this stage some regret about statements issued by Mr Bill Stefaniak, a member of the Australian Capital Territory Legislative Assembly. By the words he has used in his own statement, he has indicated that he has not fully appreciated the matters canvassed by this Bill and the issues concerned, and I find his statements somewhat insulting.

We talked to a whole range of people, including practitioners at the criminal bar, mainly in Victoria, and the Victorian Council of Civil Liberties and, in a number of cases, the people we talked to belonged to both categories. We also spoke to the office of the Director of Public Prosecutions, Mr Coldrey, who has already been mentioned by both Senator Cooney and Senator Hill as having been the author of the Coldrey report which in Victoria was responsible for initiating the change from the-six hour limit to a reasonable time, which is currently in force. I shall return to that matter later.

We have also spoken to the Australian Legal Aid Office in Darwin and the Aboriginal Legal Aid Office in Alice Springs. As well, we have spoken to people connected with a campaign for prevention of custodial deaths who have been in constant contact with the evidence that is being provided by the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. In all of these consultations the issues that we were dealing with led many people to say that there were arguments to be had for both positions. In fact, there was a time, when I started out on this investigation, when I thought reasonable time was `reasonable'.

Some members of the Bar put forward the view that it took the pressure off a police interview, that people could have their case investigated at a more leisurely pace and without constraints and that, ultimately, in many cases this may work in favour of the person being detained. As the consultations progressed, however, I became convinced that while it was important to pay some attention to `reasonable time'-and I will ask the Minister to confirm that the criteria for reasonable time, although not specifically mentioned in this Bill, will in fact be used in the context of this Bill-the time that is allowed for questioning before people are brought before a magistrate is more usefully defined with an upper limit to give certainty to the police who do not, as they do in a reasonable time situation, have to second-guess what a court subsequently might think of their decision, whether a particular time or circumstance was reasonable, and who may possibly lose their case. It was also put to us with quite some force-particularly from people who deal with Aboriginal people and others who are culturally, or for other reasons, not familiar with our legal system and with police procedures-that there must be some protection at some stage where the process can be interrupted, if only to have it brought before a magistrate.

I turn to the legislation that was in force in Victoria and is now in force through section 460 of the Crimes Act. I intend to lean fairly heavily on the evidence that we have been able to collect in that area because, as I said, a lot of the other evidence that we have collected is based very much on people's perceptions of how that conflict between two competing public policy principles can best be resolved. I think in that situation we should, as far as possible, go back to the experience which, fortunately, we are provided with in the Victorian context.

The major concern of the police who provided evidence to the Coldrey committee, which was investigating whether the six-hour limit brought into operation in 1984 should be changed, was that the six-hour limit was `hampering effective police investigation of crime'. Yet, as I have mentioned before, some 99.5 per cent of interrogations were completed within the six-hour limit. So it is a little difficult, it seems to me, to sustain that particular argument.

It is also on the record that of the 330 returns which were made at the time of police requests for an extension of time 168 actually took less than six hours. The police obviously made an application, but then found, when it came to the point, that they did not need to use that time. Of the 330 returns, 152 took from six to 12 hours, 10 took from 12 to 18 hours and none took more than 18 hours. So 162 exceeded six hours.

I should repeat the point that I made before: in this particular case all interviews were carried out by the time-honoured method of a police person asking a question, taking note of the answer and typing it-usually by the two-finger method-before proceeding to the next question. This Bill makes provision for taping and we have the evidence that it can reduce and-according to a survey carried out in Tasmania-has reduced the time by two-thirds. It is worth noting too that as a result of these statistical investigations the Coldrey committee found that there was no statistical basis for suggesting that section 460 necessarily impedes police investigations of crime.

The committee went further and looked at whether there was, in fact, a case on a qualitative basis. The only two points-they are really one point-which are relevant to the current Bill were that the police may be impeded `where investigations are being made into complex crimes and multiple offences' and `where the continuity of interviews is broken during the investigation of complex crimes and multiple offences'.

We have obviously addressed that point in our considerations and have come to the conclusion that since the four hours nominal time nominated in the Bill, in fact, is something like 12 hours, at least 12 hours-compared with the experience that we were told about in Victoria where a six-hour cap applied-that aspect is well and truly taken care of, particularly in view of the fact that a further eight hours can be obtained by application to a magistrate.

I now wish to move to a number of amendments that the Australian Democrats will move to this Bill because in assessing the main thrust of the Bill we found that in some areas the Bill could be improved. I advert first of all to the persons who under proposed section 23C are put into the upper limit of two hours category. At the moment, they are people under 18 and Aboriginal people and Torres Strait Islanders. We believe that to these two categories we should add persons who are not fluent in English, illiterate persons and persons of diminished responsibility. I would suggest that these additions are pretty self-explanatory.

I might at this point also advert to the arguments that were brought up against the inclusion of Aboriginal people in the two-hour limit, claiming that it was discrimination on racial grounds. Surely this is a case of positive discrimination because we are dealing with people who are not familiar, culturally, with our legal system, who are not familiar with our methods of police interrogation and, as those of us who have been fortunate enough to have had substantial contact with Aboriginal people would know, who have a tendency to want to please people and to answer in a way in which the questioner has indicated he would like to have an answer provided. Taking all these factors into account, it would seem a necessary safeguard to ensure that before such a person is subjected to lengthy and very often intimidating interrogation-and I am not here suggesting that the intimidation is intentional necessarily-we should allow a magistrate to determine whether further interrogation should take place.

I would also advert to the point made in this connection that, because Aboriginal people are perhaps more hesitant and may require an interpreter, we should, in actual fact, provide more time. It seems to us, on the basis of the evidence that is being provided from the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody and other people who are in daily contact with Aboriginal people and have experience of the legal system, that this consideration is far outweighed by the necessity to afford them some protection. If further time is required as a result of the need to interpret what they are saying, clearly the extension time on application is available.

TALK.START.PARA: —Can you give again the list of the people you wanted to include in the exemptions?

—I will repeat them: persons not fluent in English; illiterate persons; and persons of diminished responsibility. Our next amendment would be to proposed new section 23f which would require that the person being cautioned on the point of the right to remain silent should actually repeat that instruction or that caution in his or her own words to ensure that he or she fully understands what that caution means to him or her.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a list in the Bill which provides for the establishment of interview friends and interpreters to cover those cases where the person in custody does not have a personal friend whom he or she can ask to be present at the interview. We believe that serving police officers should be excluded from that list because of the obvious possibility of their taking a professional interest in the proceedings which could be detrimental to the person being questioned. This is, of course, no reflection on police officers. It is simply a reflection of the reality of what happens in outback areas.

We believe that the tape recording provisions need to be strengthened. While the cautioning, questioning, admissions and so on are very often done on a verbal and written basis in the first instance, we believe that they should be repeated and tape recorded at the first opportunity. At the moment the Bill simply provides that this should be done where practicable. We feel that while this may apply in the first instance it should be picked up on a subsequent occasion.

We believe that when an application is made for an extension of the investigating period, this application should be made to magistrates and/or bail justices only. We would prefer to see justices of the peace excluded from this function.

We would argue that the use of lie detectors and polygraphs should be prohibited. We would see that there are some consequential amendments which need to be introduced in the Bill resulting from the inclusion of the additional categories that I have mentioned in the first instance.

Let me conclude by saying that the Bill as it stands, with all its safeguards-particularly if our amendments are introduced-could well serve as a model Bill for the States because ultimately we should move to a position where the Commonwealth and the Commonwealth Territories coincide in their provisions with the procedures followed in the States. In that context, I was pleased to see that the New South Wales Law Reform Commission, in its discussion paper for community consultation entitled Police Powers of Arrest and Detention, suggested:
An arrested person may be detained at a police station for so long as is reasonable but for no more than four hours before either being released or brought before a court.
The Australian Democrats support the reference of this legislation to a committee where the issues raised today will be able to be canvassed more thoroughly.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tambling Sen G.E.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are considering the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Bill 1990. The coalition will not be opposing the Bill at the second reading stage, although it has very serious concerns with some aspects of it, and I will be supporting the coalition's move to have this piece of legislation referred to committees for further consultation and consideration. A number of the issues that have been addressed already by Senator Hill, Senator Cooney and Senator Spindler, of course, do require that detailed assessment by committees.

SPEECH.PARA: This Bill, firstly, seeks to confer upon police the power to detain for the purpose of questioning or investigation and, secondly, having gone that far, it seeks to lay down precise limits upon the manner in which such a power should be exercised. Bearing in mind the fundamental importance of liberty of the person as the cornerstone of our common law rights, any interference with this liberty must be subject to strict safeguards which, fortunately, this Bill provides.

It is arguable that the present common law rule that arrested persons cannot be detained for the purpose of questioning is an impediment to effective law enforcement. It is perhaps desirable that police have the power to detain arrested persons in order to carry out further investigations so that they can settle the appropriate charges. The law relating to arrest, that police can arrest persons only on the basis of reasonable suspicion, provides a safeguard against arbitrary detention.

The three principles in contention are: firstly, whether police should have the power to detain arrested persons for the purpose of questioning; secondly, whether it is necessary or desirable to have separate Commonwealth legislation to govern detention of persons arrested for Federal offences or whether State or Territory law should continue to apply; and, thirdly, assuming that the answers to these questions are in the affirmative, whether the detention period should be governed by what is considered a reasonable amount of time or fixed by prescribed maximum time limits subject to an extension of time procedure and, if so, what these time limits should be.

I would like to expand on maximum time limits that the Government has currently placed with respect to this legislation. Provision is currently made for a pre-charge custodial period for a person under arrest in relation to a Commonwealth offence. Such period is not to exceed two hours if the person is under 18 years of age, an Aboriginal or Torres Strait Islander; or four hours, in any other case.

Two points should be raised at this stage. The first involves the complex nature under which the Australian Federal Police operate their investigations, which may require lengthy sessions of questioning. The second involves the blatant discrimination of the length of time of interview between two categories of Australian citizens, which categories have already been mentioned.

More specifically the concerns of the fixed time interview have been expressed to the shadow Attorney-General by my colleagues in the Northern Territory-the Chief Minister, the Hon. Marshall Perron; and the Northern Territory Attorney-General, the Hon. Daryl Manzie. I seek leave to have incorporated in Hansard two letters from Mr Perron and Mr Manzie to the Hon. Andrew Peacock.
Leave granted.
The letters read as follows-
ATTORNEY-GENERAL
The Hon. Andrew Peacock, M.P.,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA A.C.T. 2600
Dear Andrew,
I refer to your letter of 15th November 1990 seeking my views on the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Bill 1990.
There are a number of features of the Bill which are of concern to myself and the Territory law enforcement authorities. These concerns are:

(a) The fixed periods of 2 and 4 hours are unrealistically short. The reduction of the period for Aboriginals and Torres Strait Islanders fails to take into account the reality of the situation. As has been the experience in this jurisdiction the detention time required for an Aboriginal suspect is often far greater than the norm. For instance a great deal of time can be taken, particularly where electronic recording is involved, in explaining the caution to the interviewee and getting them to demonstrate, on tape, that the effect of the caution is clearly understood.

(b) The Bill makes no provision for delays occasioned in the interview situation by the use of an interpreter. Interpreters are frequently used in this jurisdiction particularly during the interview of Aboriginal suspects.

(c) Section 23c (3) (a) states that `within' the investigation period, the person must be released (or otherwise dealt with). This requirement ignores the delays often encountered in watch-house processing.

During a busy period it may be some time before watch-house staff can charge and bail a person. It is not unusual to have a delay of some hours, particularly when there are conditions set for bail, e.g. a surety or large cash sum.
(d) The standard of proof in Section 23b (2) (a), i.e. `sufficient evidence to establish that the person has committed a Commonwealth offence' appears too onerous.

(e) It is my view that the Bill places too much emphasis on `questioning' at the expense of `investigation'. The fact that `questioning' is defined to include only investigative practices in which the person participates would appear to fail to take into account the exigencies of criminal investigation.
(f) The `dead time' provision Section 23c (b) when compared to a similar provision in the Northern Territory, Section 138 of the Police Administration Act seems unduly restrictive.
Matters which are taken into account in our Section 138 but which do not appear in Section 23c (6) are:
- the number and complexity of matters to be investigated;
- the time taken to interview available witnesses (and the victim);
- the need for members to assess relevant material in preparation for interview;
- the number of people who need to be questioned during the period of detention;
- the need to visit the crime scene/s;
- the time taken in awaiting the completion of forensic investigation or procedures;
- the time taken for a medical examination; and
- the time taken to allow the person to rest.
It is felt that the exclusion of these matters will severely restrict police investigations in the following ways:
- police with no real knowledge of what may be a complete matter may be forced to conduct an interview. This could also act to the detriment of the suspect;
- there is no time allowed for interview preparation which is essential when electronically recording an interview;
- the fact that time is not allowed for a medical examination;
- the inability to interview witnesses, particularly the victim, may severely diminish the value of the interview with the suspect.

(g) Section 23c (6) (a) which requires a person to be taken to the nearest premises may affect the quality of the investigation. For example, there was a recent case in the Northern Territory where a suspect was apprehended in Alice Springs some time after the commission of an offence. The offence having been committed in Darwin. The investigating officers were in Darwin. The suspect at the `nearest premises' Alice Springs Police Station.
(h) Section 23c (6) (f) refers to `intoxication' but the Bill fails to define the term.

(i) Section 23c (5) which relates to the 48 hour limitation in my view would unduly hamper police investigations. For example, where a person is arrested for a serious assault and the victim dies shortly after the offender is released (or otherwise dealt with). If the maximum period has been used, are police to allow the offender to remain at large?
The main failing of Section 23c appears to me to be that it disregards the severity and complexity of some offences and the number of cases where multiple offences or co-offenders are involved.
(j) Section 23d which deals with the extension of the investigation period appears unsatisfactory. The absolute maximum of 10-12 hours would not allow for police to properly investigate offences.
(k) In the Northern Territory many remote areas do not have telephone facilities. Section 23g presupposes that there are means readily available by which communication can be made.

(l) Another major concern relates to the mandatory electronic recording of interviews. The Northern Territory Police Force now routinely audio and for major crimes audio and video interviews. However it was not made mandatory through legislation. Under this Bill interviews carried out in the field may have to cease. Confessional evidence and admissions may be excluded.
In the Northern Territory admissions will not automatically be excluded if there are not facilities available or a technical failure has occurred.

The inflexibility of this legislation can be seen from this example. A suspect is being interviewed for possession and use of heroin. During the interview admissions are made as to the importation of heroin. The interview was conducted in accordance with Northern Territory law and practice. Even though the confession was voluntary and electronically recorded under this Bill it would be excluded at trial. For the Northern Territory charges it would be necessary to excise the portion dealing with the importation from the recording.

The Northern Territory recently enacted amendments to the Police Administration Act. These amendments, Sections 137 and 138, dealt with pre-trial detention. A copy of the amendment is attached. The amendment was suggested to the Government by a committee comprised of members of the bar, Law Society, prosecutions and judiciary. The committee, after examining the experience of other jurisdictions, chose the `reasonable period' test. Following passage of the amendments a Police Powers Review Committee was formed to monitor the effect of the legislation. A copy of the committee's first and second interim reports are attached.

Amongst other reasons it was seen that the `reasonable period' test gave flexibility to the police force investigating crimes on behalf of society and left it to the experts, the courts, to determine whether the time the person was detained was reasonable.
Yours sincerely,
DARYL W. MANZIE
Enc.
CHIEF MINISTER
NT House, Mitchell Street...G.P.O. Box 3146,
Darwin, N.T. 0800...Darwin, N.T. 0801
Telephone: (089) 89 6222...Telex: AA85253
...Facsimile: (O89) 81 2415
The Hon. Andrew Peacock, M.P.,
Shadow Attorney-General,
Parliament House,
CANBERRA. A.C.T. 2600.
Dear Andrew,
I understand that the House of Representatives will today be considering the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Bill 1990.

My colleague, the Hon. Daryl Manzie, M.L A., has written to you to explain in detail the difficulties that passage of this Bill would create in the Northern Territory. As Minister for Police, Fire and Emergency Services, I share his concern and fully endorse the comments that he has provided to you, as well as the additional information recently provided to Senator Tambling.

This Bill is not in the best interests of the administration of justice in the Northern Territory, and possibly elsewhere. I urge the Opposition to use its influence to seek a withdrawal of the Bill to allow time for an examination of the Territory's experience with legislation including a `reasonable period' detention provision.
Yours sincerely,
MARSHALL PERRON

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank the Senate. Both letters emphasise that Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people often require more time to interview, not less. Mr Manzie's letter goes further to describe the practicalities that are often necessary to interview an Aboriginal person. Detailed explanation of the electronic devices is necessary and interpreters are often required, which delays the interviewing process.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr Manzie points out further inefficiencies in this Bill in relation to the Northern Territory, one of which refers to the `dead time' provision of proposed section 23c (6). When compared with a similar provision in the Northern Territory, section 138 of the Police Administration Act would appear unduly restrictive. Matters that are taken into account in the Northern Territory but are not considered in this legislation include the number and complexity of the matters to be investigated, the time taken to interview available witnesses and the victim, the need for members to assess relevant material in preparation for an interview, the number of people who need to be questioned during the period of detention, the need to visit the crimes and scenes, time taken in awaiting the completion of forensic investigation or procedures, the time taken for medical examination and the time taken to allow the person to rest.

It would seem that the exclusion of these matters will severely restrict the ability of police investigation. The police, with no real knowledge of what may be a complete matter, may be forced to conduct an interview; there is no time for interview preparation; there is no time allowed for the medical examination; and the inability to interview witnesses, particularly the victim, may severely diminish the value of the interview with the suspect.

These inefficiencies have been raised not only by the Northern Territory Government Ministers but also by the Northern Territory Police Association, and the Australian Federal Police Association, in particular the Northern Territory Branch, which has drawn to my attention two case scenarios that would be severely hampered by such legislation.

Scenario 1: a foreign national was arrested after attempting to import approximately 7.5 kilograms of heroin. The initial interview lasted nine hours, after which the person was given eight hours rest and then interviewed for a further three hours. Although allowed by the legislation to apply for an extension to the specified four hours, any interruption in a case such as this will deny any chance of a controlled delivery, leaving no options for investigations into co-offenders and organisers.

Scenario 2: in an investigation into a complex fraud matter, involving multiple offenders, the main offender was interviewed for 12 hours, during which it was required for the offender to be shown innumerable documents. Given the time saving of taped interviews, it is probable that the interview could still have taken six to seven hours, involving the suspension of the interview to allow for an application for extension of time.

The second point I wish to raise regarding the fixed time period is the blatant discrimination between two lengths of time between different sectors and sections of the community. I understand that we are all sensitive to the recommendations of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody. However, I think the two-hour limit is quite unrealistic for police investigations. When I was in Alice Springs recently I had an extensive discussion and toured through the new facilities at the police station. The implementation of video surveillance of prison cells in Alice Springs and throughout the Northern Territory has gone a long way in providing suitable holding conditions for Aboriginal people.

The Government drafting of different lengths of time for interviews between two categories of Australian citizens makes a mockery of the Government agenda to advance Aboriginal Australians from their current plight. The proposal to have a two-hour pre-charge custodial period discriminates against Aboriginal people, particularly the innocent who often need extra time for interpretation, simple English explanations and medical attention. The Government has a total disregard for the very obvious cultural and social differences that Aboriginal people face. This can only work as reverse discrimination and this issue was canvassed quite widely in the House of Representatives by Mr Peacock. There is no doubt in my mind that the time restriction of four hours will become an increasing problem affecting investigation into Commonwealth offences.

Another area that causes me some concern is the lack of consultation by the Government with regard to this piece of legislation. After considering the recommendations of the Gibbs committee and representations from the Australian Federal Police, the former Attorney-General opted for the position that a reasonable time period for questioning apply as well as other procedural safeguards. The present Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has reversed that decision, might I say, without consultation with the Australian Federal Police Association and State or Territory governments to which these changes will impact on Federal, State and Territory police forces when investigating Federal offences. The consultation process has excluded the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police, Mr McAulay, in the processes leading up to the preparation of the legislation. In a letter dated 16 November 1990 from the Commissioner of the Australian Federal Police Association, the Commissioner says:
. . . the new position has been reached by a review process which did not involve further consultation with my officers or myself.

It is amazing that such a Bill has been introduced into this House which contains reforms affecting law enforcement agencies around the country responsible for its administration, without obtaining the views of these associations.

In conclusion, I support the basic principles of the legislation, as it seeks to improve checks and balances in relation to pre-charge detention procedures. I would, however, put on the record my strong reservations in relation to the extent of consultation leading up to the Bill's introduction into this House and the fixed time detentions which are not only discriminatory but also unrealistic in remote locations of Australia.
Sitting suspended from 12.43 to 2 p.m.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. I refer the Minister to the statement by the Treasurer in his 1990 Budget Speech that the forecast surplus of $8.1 billion `maintains fiscal policy as the Government's principal weapon in the fight against the current account deficit and our overseas debt'. I also refer the Minister to the Treasurer's admission on the Sunday program three days ago that the 1991 Budget could finish up in deficit, but that, if so, `it would be no calamity'. In light of these statements and the huge January balance of payments deficit of $1.6 billion-the second largest in almost a year-announced today, I ask the Minister firstly: how does he reconcile these seemingly totally contradictory statements? Secondly, does the Treasurer's statement on the Sunday program represent a major change in the Government's economic policy stance? Thirdly, given that the Government has completely lost control of fiscal policy, what policy weapons does it now propose to use to tackle Australia's fundamental economic problems, including its chronic balance of payments and debt problems, and the recession that the Treasurer said we were not going to have but then had to have?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —Firstly, Senator Short would be aware that, since the Treasurer made his statement in the Budget Speech, there has been the onset of a recession in Australia. Of course, in terms of the Budget surplus there are enormous cyclical effects of a downturn in the economy of this current order. The first cyclical effect comes from growing unemployment, which we have seen in the past few months. The second cyclical effect comes from the reduction in corporate profits and the corporate profit share of the revenue side of the Budget. That should not be news to Senator Short.

ANSWER.PARA: Senator Short has related a number of issues into one. What the Treasurer has clearly been saying, and was said on the Sunday program, is that the decline in the surplus is due to the impact of the recession on outlays and revenue as well as the effect of the wage tax trade-off, which I think was universally accepted as a sensible thing to do in terms of inflationary anticipations. Of course, there have been two other items which have affected the Budget surplus-our participation in the Gulf war and the compensation for woolgrowers; also, some bits of legislation which would have brought in substantial revenue but which were rejected by the Opposition in the Senate. Those are the matters which, in addition to cyclical factors, have effected the downgrading of the surplus. The Opposition knows that to be perfectly true.

TALK.START.PARA: —So, it is all our fault?
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—I never said that it was all the Opposition's fault. I think a lot of it is its fault, but not all of it. I would not ever make a claim like that. In terms of the structural composition of the Budget there are cyclical factors which are operating and there are additional factors which are operating which have produced the decline of the surplus which I have just identified.

ANSWER.PARA: That is my response to Senator Short's part of the question which relates to two statements by the Treasurer: one in August 1990 and one last week. In so far as the current account deficit, the balance of payments figure published today, is concerned, let me say this: Senator Short seeks to gain short term mileage out of these particular difficulties.

TALK.START.PARA: —That is not the truth. You know that.

—I can always turn this Opposition into a group of sophisticated conversationalists. The Budget forecast for the current account deficit was $18 billion, as Senator Short ought to know, but I do not say that he necessarily does know. Let me make the following point: for the first seven months of this financial year, the current account deficit has been $10.1 billion, which is well within the Budget forecast, the Budget assumption, of $18 billion for 1990-91.
—They always speak in billions as if it is something to be proud of.
—Order! There are too many interjections.

—I do not mind interjections provided they have some intellectual calibre about them. The interjections I have had from Senator Alston, for example, do not have any intellectual calibre about them. For the first seven months of this year, that is the fact. For those months, exports have exceeded imports by $734m, following a deficit of around $3.1 billion in the corresponding period in the previous year.
—So, they are beautiful figures?
—No, I did not say that; they are not beautiful figures, not at all. In terms of Senator Short's question, that is the appropriate answer; that is the fact.
—Are they on track?

—Yes, that is what I just said in terms of the Budget forecast. Regarding Senator Short's attempt to connect these two issues, I think they have to be seen-although they are important and difficult figures for the Government and this country-in a slightly different context from the way in which he put it in his question.

—Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Do I take it from the Minister's answer that he is saying that when the Treasurer presented his Budget on 21 August he was unaware that he was about to pull the levers to engineer the recession that he boasted only three months later he had done?

—Senator Short knows perfectly well what has been said about that by the Treasurer, by the Prime Minister and by me in Question Time on previous occasions. The Government was quite explicit and put up with a lot of questions and flak from those opposite about the necessity of having tight monetary policy in order to slow demand in the Australian economy. That was painful for us.
—Fiscal policy.
—I am talking about the slowing of demand in the Australian economy. Senator Short asked me a question about the recession--
—And the use of fiscal policy.

—Senator Short cannot reinvent his earlier question. The question was about the recession. By any admission of the Government, a downturn in the Australian economy was desired as the terms of policy instrument in order to effect that result.
—Why didn't he anticipate that in his Budget, on Budget outcomes?
—Order! Senator Short, you have asked a supplementary question.

—Unfortunately, as Senator Short should know, as a former Treasury officer, the figures on economic performance in this country are lag figures. There was a lot of anecdotal evidence about the severity of the downturn in the Australian economy, but very few figures which supported it and very few economists or officials in the Treasury who understood precisely what was happening. I think I have answered the question in terms of the limited understanding of the Opposition, and I have nothing more to add.

—Will the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade tell the Senate what the Government's response is both to the news of a coup in Thailand and to subsequent political developments there, particularly in relation to the restoration of democratic government?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —As the Prime Minister and I both made clear in public statements at the time, Australia very deeply regrets the seizure of power in Thailand on 23 February by the armed forces leadership, overthrowing the democratically elected Government of Prime Minister Chatichai Choonhavan. Our concerns have, of course, been conveyed formally to the Thai authorities. We emphasised, in so communicating, our wish to see human rights observed and democratic government quickly restored.

ANSWER.PARA: The military leadership, which has adopted the title of the National Peacekeeping Council, has dissolved parliament, abrogated the constitution and declared martial law, with military courts replacing criminal courts. Bans have been imposed on meetings of more than five people and on any public political gatherings. Total press censorship was originally imposed but has later been relaxed.

The Australian Government remains concerned that former Prime Minister Chatichai and former Deputy Prime Minister Arthit Kamlang-ek remain in detention. Thai officials formally advised us following the coup of the military leadership's assurances that political power would be returned to the people within a short period, and that human rights would be fully respected.

I have to say that the interim constitution which was promulgated on 1 March does not offer much encouragement in this respect. Regrettably, it incorporates provisions which entrench the ultimate authority of the military leadership, even after the formation of an interim civilian government. The National Peacekeeping Council retains its role as ultimate decision-maker, and the constitution invests it and the interim government it has appointed with arbitrary powers to deal with national security threats. It is also a matter of concern that the interim constitution allows for the delay of elections for up to 14 months.

A civilian Prime Minister, Mr Anand Panyarachun, has been appointed by the National Peacekeeping Council. He will now appoint an interim cabinet and a national legislative assembly, and this assembly will, we are told, draft a new permanent constitution. I note that Prime Minister Anand has spoken of the urgency of returning to parliamentary government and lifting martial law. I simply say that the Australian Government would be most concerned if the military authority's assurances of an early return to elected parliamentary government were not honoured. We also look to the military authorities and their civilian appointees to comply fully with internationally accepted human rights standards.

The Australian Government has decided that we should continue our existing relationship with Thailand for the time being, subject to close and continuing review of the actual human rights situation on the ground and, of course, the prompt restoration of democratic government.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! I draw the attention of honourable senators to the presence in the chamber of a parliamentary delegation from the European Parliament, led by Mr Lambrias. TALK.START.PARA: —There is no manual or guidelines of which I am aware. We rely on the good sense, dignity and intelligence of the ambassadors concerned. —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Attorney-General. ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

ANSWER.PARA: From my conversation with Mr Murray Allen, the Western Australian Regional Commissioner of the Australian Securities Commission at the time, I know that he has been delighted with the response of the Western Australian business community to the setting up of the business office and the regional office functions of the Australian Securities Commission in Perth. —Is the Minister for Industrial Relations aware of a statement made by the Premier of New South Wales in the Parliament of New South Wales on 21 February to the effect that industrial disputes in that State had declined by almost 16 per cent while the Labor States supposedly had shown an annual increase of 13.4 per cent? Can the Minister advise the Senate whether this statement is correct or is the Premier misleading the people of New South Wales about the extent and level of industrial strife in that State?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is true that Premier Greiner has claimed bragging rights for the decline in the levels of industrial disputation and has sought to contrast the level of disputation in his State with those elsewhere in Australia. That claim, coming from a conservative government, does sit oddly with the comparison between the performance of this Government and the previous Fraser Government. Under this Government industrial disputation declined by 61 per cent over the amount which used to apply under the former administration.

ANSWER.PARA: I believe that the claim is misleading and that can be demonstrated. But I should first say that it is true that Mr Greiner told the New South Wales Parliament on Thursday, 21 February-its first day back for 1991-that industrial disputation in New South Wales declined by almost 16 per cent while in the Labor States there had been an annual increase of 13.4 per cent. From what was said it is clear that Mr Greiner was referring to industrial disputation figures for the year ended October 1990.

What Mr Greiner did not say was that New South Wales has the highest rate of industrial disputation of any State in Australia-a rate of 247 working days lost per 1,000 employees in the year to October 1990. That rate is 27 per cent higher than the Australian average of 194 working days lost per 1,000 employees. It is higher than Tasmania, with 64, Queensland with 101, Western Australia with 183, Victoria with 205, and South Australia with 218. I remind the Senate that the figure in New South Wales is 247. It appears that Mr Greiner arrived at his figure of an annual decline of 16 per cent for New South Wales because in October 1989 New South Wales was in an even worse position than it is now; its position in 1989 was 44 per cent higher than the national average rate.

It is also, I think, statistically illiterate to make the comparisons he did. He summed the rate of annual disputation for each Labor State, averaged those figures, and then found another rate of change. Using the same logic to arrive at the Australian unemployment rate, Mr Greiner would sum the individual rates of each State and then divide by six. This, of course, is a nonsense.

The latest figures for November 1990, released on 1 March, still show that New South Wales has the worst rate of industrial disputation of any State-277 working days lost per 1,000 employees, 32 per cent higher than the national average of 210.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade. I refer also to the issue of whether Brian Burke is a fit and proper person to be an ambassador. Has the Minister asked his colleague Senator Beahan for the facts concerning Mr Burke's allegation that the surveillance of former Liberal members of the Western Australian Parliament was paid for by the Australian Labor Party? If he has not asked him, will he?

—As I had occasion to say yesterday in answer to a similar question, it is none of Senator Knowles's business what conversations I may have had with Senator Beahan. As it happens, I have not asked him that question. But if I do ever get around to asking the question, I am not inclined to tell Senator Knowles what the substance of that conversation will be.

—I ask the Minister representing the Prime Minister: is the Government aware of the total opposition of the Australian conservation movement to the concept of resource security? Is the Government aware that the Tasmanian State Government is set to lose office if resource guarantee goes ahead because the Green Independents would withdraw their support for that Government? Finally, under resource guarantee legislation will the timber industry be required to provide reciprocal guarantees in regard to jobs, a real monetary return on the forests and the ecological sustainability of the forest environment?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —In answer to the first two parts of the question regarding, as Senator Vallentine put it, the total opposition of the Australian conservation movement to resource security legislation, let me say that all those arguments have been put to us and canvassed. Whether the Tasmanian Government is set to lose office or not because of this or any other issue is a matter which I have heard people discussing, but I have no comment on it; I do not think it is appropriate for me to comment.

ANSWER.PARA: In so far as, if there was resource guarantee legislation, whether there would be commitments sought from those who were allegedly the beneficiaries of that legislation, the answer is yes, very solid commitments.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. Could the Minister please clarify what kinds of reciprocal guarantees the timber industry would be required to provide?
—The Government has not announced any decision on this matter. When it does, I think it would be appropriate for Senator Vallentine to ask the question again and get a full answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade and it relates to the Burkegate cover-up. In light of the Minister's arrogant lack of response to Senator Knowles's question in relation to whether Ambassador Burke is fit and proper to be an ambassador, will he undertake to investigate the contradictory statements made to the media last week by his ambassador to Ireland, Brian Burke, and his own back bench colleague Senator Beahan as to whether the surveillance of former Liberal members of the Western Australian Parliament was paid for by the Premier's Department, the Australian Labor Party or Premier Burke's leader's slush fund?
