—I will not undertake any such investigation, for exactly the same sorts of reasons that I have identified in response to questions on about a dozen previous occasions. Might I say that, if Opposition senators cannot provide a better class of coordinated cross-examination than we have heard today, I really do think they ought to leave me alone to get on with reading my files, because it is far more productive for me to do so.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Land Transport. I ask: can the Minister advise whether the Government proposes to proceed with an Australian design rule which will require, from 1 March 1992, that all new motorcycles be wired in such a way that once the engine is running the low beam headlamp or running lights will turn on? If so, what are the road safety benefits of this decision?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am pleased to say that I can confirm that. I must say as someone who during his eight years as a divisional officer with the St John Ambulance Brigade carted more than his fair share of dead motorbike riders off the road-usually in more than one piece, I must say-I am very pleased that the Government has decided to press ahead with this proposal despite significant opposition, unfortunately, from some of the riders associations. Around 270 motorcycle riders and passengers were killed in Australia last year and about 10 times as many would have been seriously injured.

ANSWER.PARA: Last December the Minister advised me that he had taken a decision to introduce an Australian design rule which will require, from 1 March next year, all new motorcycles to be wired so that once the engine is running the low beam headlamp or running lights will automatically turn on. The rule will apply only to new motorcycles. The decision was taken after a very thorough review of the evidence and extensive consultation with motorcycle representatives and State road safety authorities. The Government has no intention of resiling from that decision.

Many motorcycle crashes involve a car driver who fails to react to the presence of a motorbike rider. I can certainly attest to that. There is strong research evidence that use of daytime lights increases the visibility and noticeability of motorcycle riders. Up to 70 per cent of riders themselves already choose to use daytime lights for safety reasons. It is estimated that an increase in use of daytime lights to 90 per cent of motorcycle riders would reduce the number of serious motorcycle crashes by about 3 per cent. This is a saving of about 10 lives and 100 serious injuries a year, and a much larger number of less serious crashes. The saving to the community in medical costs, lost earnings and property damage is estimated at $24m a year.

The Government was aware, when this decision was taken, of the concerns expressed by representatives of motorcycle rider groups. The Minister is disappointed that they have been unable to accept the decision that offers a worthwhile safety benefit to the motorcycle community. It has become plain that the opposition to this measure stems largely from a libertarian view that riders should be free to make their own choices about risks and safety.

Without continuing with the brief that the Minister has given me, I must say that that would be an acceptable and supportable view if, of course, these people then had to bear the cost of the accidents they have. Of course they do not. I strongly support the decision taken by the Government and reiterate for the benefit of Senator Zakharov and the Senate that the Government will not resile from implementing this decision.

TALK.START.PARA: —I ask whether the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training is aware of criticisms made yesterday by the Queensland Premier, Mr Goss, that the Federal Education Minister was bereft of ideas about the future of young Queenslanders, and that these criticisms were about the funding of tertiary education places. I remind the Minister that this current dispute had also existed with the previous National Party Government, during which time the Australian Labor Party claimed it was the fault of the intransigence of that Government. I ask: now that the same dispute exists with a Labor government, does this represent a natural bias by the Education Minister against Queenslanders receiving their justified proportion of funding for tertiary education, especially when participation rates in north Queensland are half those in Canberra and Melbourne?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think the first part of Senator Bjelke-Petersen's question was whether I thought the Minister for Employment, Education and Training was bereft of ideas. Having enjoyed listening to him and debating with him over the last six months or so in Cabinet, I can assure Senator Bjelke-Petersen that Mr Dawkins is never bereft of ideas and quite often has quite constructive ideas. I must say that I do not always agree with them, but they are there.

ANSWER.PARA: In relation to the third part of the honourable senator's question, relating to the impact in north Queensland, I do not know what statistics she bases her assertions on, but we can always look at those. In respect of the second part, and probably the heart of her question, about the Government's performance in the area of tertiary education, it should be acknowledged that not only in terms of places under the higher education contribution scheme relating to funding, but also with capital of a continuing nature and in cooperation with the States, Mr Dawkins has had a continuing input of ideas and success in ensuring the upgrading across Australia of access to tertiary education by young Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. My question was not about the performance of the Government in relation to education; it was about bias against Queensland. If there is not a natural bias on the part of the Government against Queenslanders receiving their justified proportion of education funding, I want to know why Queensland is not receiving it.

—In respect of Queensland I made one specific point in response to Senator Bjelke-Petersen-that is, in terms of the numbers on a proportion basis in north Queensland. I have not seen any figures to suggest that this Government is biased against Queensland. I think it is fair to say that, in the approach that this Government has taken, what it has attempted to do and what it has succeeded in doing is ensuring that across the country, whether it is primary, secondary or tertiary education, young Australians have equal access to the education system and educational structures.

—I direct my question to the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services. Is the Minister aware of complaints about excessive delays in the processing of Austudy applications? Can the Minister tell the Senate whether these reports are accurate and, if so, what the Government will do to speed up the processing of Austudy applications?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —There have been some reports in newspapers and I think also on Victorian radio in respect of this matter. Those claims are unsubstantiated, and they cannot be substantiated. The Government has been concerned and is concerned about this particular issue, and it has acted to redress any problems that may have occurred in the past. It has incorporated a national set of client service standards which set goals as to the turnaround time for the processing of applications. One of these goals is that 80 per cent of applications should receive an initial response to the application within 21 days. In terms of the monitoring of that goal each student centre, and the Minister's Department nationally, monitors the performance against these client service standards. In monitoring the performance, we find that the Department has exceeded those goals, and exceeded them by a substantial margin. Something like 90 per cent of 1991 applicants have received a response within 21 days. This is significantly above last year's turnaround time, when the figure was 70 per cent having a turnaround time within the goals set by the Government.

ANSWER.PARA: This substantial improvement is in light of the fact that there has been an increase-about 16 per cent so far-in the number of applications received for Austudy. So there has been a major improvement. The goals set have been met and surpassed. I think it is fair to say this has happened for a number of reasons: first, the adoption of management practices; secondly, the introduction of innovations such as the simplification of the scheme itself; and, thirdly, simplification of application forms for continuing students. Those three measures in themselves have added substantially to improving standards and turnaround times.

I should also mention that students who find themselves in financial difficulty may be granted urgent payments either through immediate processing of their claims or through access to counter checks. I mention in conclusion that I think it was Senator Bell who claimed that Austudy recipients are ineligible for income support before the start of the academic year. He probably understands that his claim was wrong. Payments are made as soon as possible after applications are received.

TALK.START.PARA: —He never admits it, though.

—He may not admit it, but he might quietly do so to himself. But payments are made as soon as possible after applications are received. Continuing students who, for instance, completed their applications before the end of 1990 did not have a break in their payments during the Christmas period. Senator Bell might review his position on this matter.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development. I refer the Minister to the not-so-high delegation to the United States, and that is not a reflection on my colleagues. Firstly, does that delegation include the business of protecting our share of the wheat markets in the Gulf region? Secondly, will the delegation also confer with the European Community (EC) on its subsidisation of grain sales because it is equally at fault? If the delegation is not going to talk to the EC, why not?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The point about this delegation to the United States is that it is linked to the congressional consideration of the export enhancement program and the expansion thereof, which debate starts on 11 March-something which was entirely overlooked by the Leader of the Opposition when he proposed the delegation go after the debate was likely to be concluded, which is a demonstration of how close his feet are to the ground when it comes to the details of the hard negotiating work that has to be done if Australia's voice is to be heard.

ANSWER.PARA: Nobody is in any doubt what our position is so far as the European Community is concerned on agricultural subsidies. That point has been made over and over again. The present situation in Brussels is, however, delicately poised in terms of the internal consideration of reforms to the common agricultural policy and the formulation of a further European position on the Uruguay Round. We made a judgment in light of the situation presently prevailing that it was not especially appropriate to make a further major high profile assault on the Europeans at this stage.

As members of the European Parliament will be well aware, from the sorts of noises made to them during their visit to this country, Australia will not in any way resile from continuing to press through all available and appropriate opportunities the very strongly held position that we do adopt about the impropriety, inappropriateness and counter-productiveness in terms of world trade and economic development of European agricultural support practices.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. Is it within the Minister's knowledge that there has been pressure by both employer and employee organisations in Victoria-so far resisted by the Opposition there-to have its Parliament pass industrial relations legislation? Is there any, and if so what, ramification for the Federal industrial relations system if that legislation is not passed?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I am aware of the debate going on in Victoria about the industrial relations legislation and the sordid politics being played out by the Opposition in that State, which is threatening to block the passage of that legislation in the upper House. The Bill before the Victorian Parliament is an important one for Victoria from an industrial relations standpoint. It proposes to abolish the Conciliation and Arbitration Board system entirely and have all matters of industrial dispute settlement dealt with by the Commission. It proposes to divide the Commission into a panel structure much like that of the Federal Commission; it proposes to introduce provisions allowing for joint proceedings of the Commission with other commissions-in this case, namely the Federal Commission and the State Commission are operating jointly-and it establishes a two-tier industrial court system; that is, an industrial magistrates' court and a commission in court session structure.

ANSWER.PARA: One of the stated aims of this legislation is to complement at a State level the provisions of the Federal Act. As a Federal Government we welcome the Victorian Government's proposal to do so. It is consistent with the moves going on all around Australia to blend the industrial relations systems of the States and the Commonwealth so there is a much greater interconnectibility about their decisions and a much greater rationality to the consumers of those decisions, be they employers or unions.

This legislation arose from a classic tripartite consultative approach. It is in many respects a model of what State governments or Federal governments ought to do in order to see that a disputatious area like industrial relations is sorted out. The Government sat down with the unions and the employers in that State and came up with this body of legislation. It is strongly supported both by the Victorian Trades Hall Council and the Victorian employer organisations. The threat by Alan Brown, the Leader of the Opposition in Victoria, to block this legislation therefore runs counter to what is a model of industrial relations conduct.

To do so on the basis of political opportunism is disgraceful and irresponsible. Once again, it is an example of a conservative party trying to politicise industrial relations, to manipulate industrial relations for political purposes and for crass political gain. It is about time people woke up to the fact that this very sensitive field ought to be dealt with in the proper way-in the way in which the Victorian Government has dealt with it.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister for Administrative Services. I understand that the standard rate for laying bricks in Sydney is approximately $650 per thousand or 65c a brick. Can the Minister explain why each brick in the new veterans garden of remembrance at Rookwood Cemetery is costing $2.70 to lay, and how can the Minister justify Australian Construction Services agreeing to such a rate? What has been the role of the Building Workers Industrial Union (BWIU) in this contract? Coupled with the fact that work on the garden was supposed to be finished by Christmas 1990 and that now, in March 1991, completion may be many months away, is this not yet another example of questionable management practices by the Minister's Department, practices which the Minister seems consistently unable and unwilling to address, or is this just another make-work project being engineered by the Government to counter spiralling unemployment?
—It is a classic example of Mr Howard's ideas in industrial relations going crazy. Let the market decide, that is his idea.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think it is fair to give some history to this project. I know that Senator Newman comes in here with emotional allegations. I do not know what is the price per brick laid in New South Wales, and I bet that most of the Australian community does not know and would not be expected to know. As my colleague Senator Cook has quite rightly said, if we are talking about industrial policies, if the Opposition's industrial policy were in place on the basis that John Howard would be approaching this issue, whatever is happening now would be well and truly orderly conduct compared with what would happen under an Opposition regime.
—You don't know the answer, do you?

—If Senator Newman keeps quiet for a minute she will get the answer that I want to give her. The Commonwealth Office of Australian War Graves is currently constructing a garden of remembrance at the Rookwood Cemetery in New South Wales. It is estimated to cost $6m and is scheduled for completion within a few months. It will provide for 100,000 plaques; we know that aspect of it. The contract of $3.8m was let to a New South Wales proprietary limited company in August 1988. The anticipated completion date, as we also know, was supposed to have been July 1989. That company was Girvan Pty Limited. Progress in the first half of 1989 was extremely slow due to a combination of abnormally wet weather, brick supply problems, low productivity and severe industrial disputes. All that is very much on the record and has been on the record for some time. There is nothing new in that.

ANSWER.PARA: The works were temporarily suspended on 4 July 1989 to allow the work to be redesigned to permit the incorporation of different bricks. The suspension was lifted in October 1989; the resumed work proceeded well, until Girvan went into receivership on 30 January 1990. After that another company was engaged to provide a temporary construction management service to enable work to continue and to avoid further industrial disputes. That firm was R.N. Cooper. It commenced work on the site on 16 February 1990, and I am informed that that work proceeded well until wet weather in April 1990 hampered progress. After that there have been considerations as to the financial costs. The Department of Finance approved an increase in authorisation of $6m after April 1990 in order to complete the work. A lump sum contract was signed with R.N. Cooper on 6 July 1990 and a contract completion date was set for September 1990.

There has been overrun since then. R.N. Cooper has subsequently experienced delays resulting from wet weather combined with safety, industrial and some contractors' problems. That has resulted in progress being slower than usual. There must be some mystique on the other side in respect of this. There must be some expectation that the Opposition can stop the rain; that it can stop industrial disputes-in the public sector but not in the private sector. What we are talking about here is a situation which prevails whether the operation is conducted by a private sector company or by the public sector. In fact, in this particular instance, very clearly, Australian Construction Services is contracting with private sector organisations for them to complete the work.

In terms of the specific question of $1.70, $2.60 or whatever per brick, I will find out for Senator Newman; but I ask her to recognise that what we have here is a contracting-out arrangement. It is one which is subject to the vicissitudes of weather and the economy; one that has been entered into in accordance with normal and acceptable contracting practices; and one that is proceeding despite difficulties.

Those difficulties have been on the record for some time. I think it was last December or November that Senator Newman asked me about the same cemetery by a different aspect of questioning. I hope that this time she has her allegation right. I know that the last three times that Senator Newman and Senator Parer raised questions about this matter they got it wrong. In fact, at one stage Senator Newman alleged in the chamber that there was a toilet on a mezzanine floor when in fact there was no mezzanine floor in the building. I hope that Senator Newman is right this time. I will check it out and let her know.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his undertaking to provide some extra information, but I did ask him what has been the role of the BWIU in this contract. Is he unable to give me that information now or will he give it to me later? Has the BWIU been responsible for the industrial delays? Has it been responsible for the rate at which the bricks were contracted? Is it responsible for the people who got the contracts?

—I took the reference-and I think quite rightly so-to the BWIU as some gratuitous political point-scoring. I think that if one looks and listens to the last part of Senator Newman's question, as to whether the BWIU was involved in organising the contract or whatever, it is very easy to come in here and make off-the-cuff allegations without substantiation off the top of one's head to get a run in the press. It is very easy to ask a question, but it is incumbent on all members of the Opposition when they come in here with allegations--

—Mr President, I raise a point of order. I invite you to rule that it is quite out of order for the Minister, certainly on the grounds of relevancy, to reflect upon someone who simply asks a question in this chamber. If we are going to be subjected to a harangue that questions are being asked for political motives, that somehow it is improper to even mention the name of an industry union without being told that that is a gratuitous reference, then you are reducing Question Time to nonsense and invite you, Mr President, to direct the Minister accordingly.
—There is no point of order. Senator Bolkus, the answer has been very long.

—I know. The supplementary question was also very long. I will close on this point. I will fairly and without political emotion check out the questions that Senator Newman has asked, but I make the specific point that it is the Opposition which has declared publicly and widely across Australia that it wants to raise the level of performance in this Parliament. It has made a stunt of this place. Members of the Opposition come in here with unsubstantiated allegations, throw them across the chamber and expect them to get a run. Senator Newman has to lift her form.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Aged, Family and Health Services. On 21 February I questioned the Minister on the use by the Government of the term `working families' in its child-care media release to mean only those with both parents in the paid work force. The Minister responded that there is no discrimination against mothers not in the paid work force and that they can take advantage of the child-care places and the extension of fee relief to commercial centres. How does the Minister reconcile this statement with the fact that of total child-care funding by the Federal Government, the Government has actually reduced the percentage for the type of occasional child-care required by mothers not in the paid work force in pursuance of their devoted work for their families? Is the Minister not aware of the fact that his own Government has reduced that percentage from 1989-90, which was 6 per cent of the total, to this Budget of 4.1 per cent? In the interests of equity and in recognition of this marvellous work of mothers, will the Government consider the issue of vouchers to those mothers for that purpose?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not have available to me the exact percentages of child-care places that might be apportioned in the way suggested by Senator Harradine. The Government has been committed to, and has implemented, a program of increasing the number of child-care places, so the percentages of a larger gross number of places could go down but the number of places actually increase, and that is quite a compatible statement. I believe that some further research into the percentages, proportions and total number of child-care places would have to be undertaken in order to answer fully Senator Harradine's question.

ANSWER.PARA: As to the Government's overall policy, particularly with the passage through this Parliament of the fee relief to commercial centres, I believe that particular matter took up a lot of time both in this chamber and in committee just before Christmas. There was evidence of the Government delivering on its promise to make fee relief available to families using previously unfunded commercial, employer provided and non-profit centres. That is just one example of the way in which this particular Government has increased the range of child-care services which are available to a range of Australian families and households including, of course, those situations where a mother chooses to not be part of the paid work force.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I have a supplementary question. The Minister has not responded to the last part of my question; that is, in the interests of equity for mothers who are not in the paid work force, has the Government considered the issue of vouchers for those mothers for the purposes of occasional child-care in pursuance of their devoted work for the family?

—I believe that it is very evident what the policy of the Federal Government is in relation to the contribution of persons to the provision of child-care. I will ask the Minister responsible for child-care and other services whether he has any further comment to make on the alternative proposal put forward by Senator Harradine and let the honourable senator know the answer.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Transport and Communications. Under the leaked government pay television plan as revealed by Tom Burton in today's Sydney Morning Herald, is it possible for Mr Kerry Packer, who already owns the Nine television network, owns 22 per cent of TNQ and owns Australian Consolidated Press, to buy and operate all four pay television channels, in addition to his existing Sky Channel licence? If the Government wants to save us from that fate, is it likely that the Foreign Investment Review Board, given its record on selling off the farm, will allow British newspaper publisher Mr Robert Maxwell or Mr Ted Turner of Cable News Network to buy and operate pay television in Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is certainly true that it would be possible for the Government simply to remove the moratorium that was placed on pay television in 1986 by way of proclamation if it determined to do so. The Government has no intention of doing that and it would be foolish to do that before a regulatory regime was put in place to control pay television. Pay television is also a factor in the sale of Aussat Pty Ltd, for the simple reason that satellite is one of the means by which pay television could be transmitted. So far as the regulatory regime is concerned, that would be a matter that the Government would consider in the overall review that it is currently conducting into broadcasting regulations generally.

ANSWER.PARA: The potential purchasers of Aussat will also need to be advised by the Government and be given some guidance in respect of pay television because, as I said, it is relevant to the sale of Aussat. I have not had an opportunity yet to read the article that Senator Kernot has referred to, but I will. The Government is currently considering these issues. It will announce a decision on pay television, and it will provide that advice to the potential purchasers of Aussat at an appropriate stage during that sale process.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Is pay television part of the sale of Aussat because there is a demonstrated demand for pay television or is it simply part of this desperate package to find a buyer for Aussat?

—I did, in fact, answer that question just a minute ago, but I will say again that the Government is currently considering that issue. Advice will have to be given to any potential purchasers of Aussat as to the Government's position on pay television because satellite is, of course, one of the means by which pay television can be delivered. I will say again that the Government will announce its decision on that at an appropriate time during the process of the sale of Aussat.

—My question is directed to the Minister for Industrial Relations. I remind the Minister that he has been reported as saying that Australia is not currently ready for enterprise agreements. Can he inform the Senate when Australia will be ready for enterprise agreements?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —What I have said-in the interests of accuracy-is that a survey conducted over two years covering 4,500 managers of plants and union representatives in something like 2,500 workplaces in Australia, both big and small, covering all sorts of industry and geographically spread around Australia, and overseen for statistical accuracy by the Australian Bureau of Statistics, has reported that one of the features of Australian workplaces is a lack of the infrastructure necessary to support enterprise bargaining. That is what I have said.

ANSWER.PARA: I have indicated that that is a sobering finding from an objective survey for a Government like my own, which has argued in the current national wage case that a degree of enterprise flexibility should be provided, that the decentralised system should be devolved to some extent to the enterprise level and that the national wage case bench, when it brings down its decision, should prescribe guidelines for that enterprise negotiation. The key is that, if the infrastructure is not adequate to support a successful carrying off of those enterprise negotiations, the move to the new phase of industrial relations development in this country-to an enterprise phase-will be complicated.
When will it change? I think honourable senators will have to wait until after 12 March for the Government to say something about its industry policy before I answer that question in full.

TALK.START.PARA: —Pursuant to the order of the Senate of 28 September 1988 I ask the Minister representing the Treasurer to explain why answers have not been given to questions numbered 159 and 165, of which I gave notice on 23 and 24 August 1990, relating to tax simplification and aspects of the capital gains tax affecting the timber industry.
—There wasn't an answer because it wasn't a good enough question.

—My colleague Senator Evans interjected and said that Senator Watson had not had an answer because it was not a good enough question. I must say that I do not remember the question; so I cannot necessarily agree with that. My office has been pursuing these answers for Senator Watson and I hope to have them within a couple of days.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

QUESTION.PARA: That the Senate take note of the explanation.
I do so on the understanding that I believe there is an answer in the Treasurer's office at the moment.

TALK.START.PARA: —Do you wish to seek leave to continue your remarks later?
—No. I will leave it to the Government to do the right thing and answer the question.
—I will try to do the right thing.

—During Question Time Senator Coulter asked me a question about a letter from Mr Justice Stewart of the Resource Assessment Commission to the Prime Minister. My understanding is that there was no such letter.

DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I have received a letter from Senator Short proposing that a matter of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion, namely:

INTERJECT.PARA: The failure of the Government to pursue policies to redress Australia's fundamental economic problems, including its chronic balance of payments and debt problems, as demonstrated by the failure of the January balance of payments figures released today to show any significant improvement.
I call upon those senators who approve of the proposed discussion to rise in their places.
More than the number of senators required by the Standing Orders having risen in their places-

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —This Government's policies have not only failed to redress Australia's fundamental economic problems; they have indeed been a deliberate and conscious part of the increasingly deep-seated problems that we have today. This morning we had the release of the balance of payments figures for January. Once again, we have had another month where Australia has gone into debt to the rest of the world to the tune of not much short of $2 billion. In seasonally adjusted terms, the balance of payments deficit for January was $1.6 billion; in unadjusted terms it was $1.9 billion.

SPEECH.PARA: I interpose to farewell Senator Button from the chamber, Senator Button being one of the key architects of the Government's failed policies. He is the Leader of the Government in the Senate but he is not even prepared to sit and listen to, let alone participate in, a debate of very considerable importance. Senator Button has ducked every such debate in this chamber this session and indeed in previous sessions. Today he has left Senator Cook as his key speaker. We all know, including from that ridiculous answer we just heard from Senator Cook in Question Time, what he can bring to this debate-nothing but gobbledegook and nonsense. I call on Senator Button as the responsible Minister-as the Leader of the Government in the Senate and as the Minister representing the Treasurer and the Minister for Finance-to take his responsibilities to this Senate, to this Parliament, much more seriously than he does.

We as a nation are caught in a current account deficit rut of approximately $1.5 billion a month-month in, month out. This is despite the fact that we have the worst recession since the Second World War and arguably-if Senator Button's answer yesterday to Senator Chapman's question is correct, namely, that we are about to have a third successive quarter, and the fourth out of the last five quarters, of negative economic growth-the longest protracted period of negative economic growth that this country has had since the Great Depression. Despite that, imports are continuing to run at $180m a day, as they have in the last month. The current account deficit has been stuck at an enormously high figure-about $18 billion a year.

The bottom line of all of that is that the current account deficit for this year looks like coming in at about 4 1/2 per cent of gross domestic product (GDP). That is roughly in line with what was predicted at the time of the Budget. It is coming in at that figure despite the fact that unemployment may be running at 9 per cent or above-almost certainly above; well above the Budget forecast-and despite the fact that economic growth will be decidedly negative this financial year compared with the Budget estimates of a growth of 2 per cent.

Economic Planning Advisory Council studies suggest that a current account deficit of this magnitude would mean that the foreign debt obligations of this nation would not be stabilised this century. That would mean that the Hawke Government would have to maintain high, and probably rising, real interest rates as we struggle to attract funds to cover our recurring current account deficits and face very strong competition for funds from abroad and further possible downgrading of our international credit rating.

Today the international economic environment is a decidedly less positive and favourable environment for us than it was a year ago. The prospects of the export side of our balance of payments deteriorating are very strong indeed in the short term and may well continue into the longer term. Already export volumes have fallen. Commodity prices have eased in the face of that economic slowdown taking place overseas. That will simply compound the problems that we have as a nation in getting ourselves out of the dreadful mess that has been dug for us by this Government.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) has stated that we need to get the current account deficit down to 2.5 per cent of GDP in order to stabilise our external debt by 1993. That would imply a current account deficit for this year of about $10 billion, not the $17 to $18 billion that now seems certain to be in prospect. The Treasurer needs to explain to the Parliament and to the Australian people just how the $6 billion to $7 billion-odd gap will come about and how it will be filled. Surely he does not propose to drive the economy even further and deeper into recession to meet that gap. However, given the policies of this Government, one could not be too sure of that.

The foreign debt figures are equally disturbing. The figures that were released last week for the end of December period show that foreign debt is now running at a gross figure of $165 billion and a net figure of $131 billion. That is equal to $7,800 for every man, woman and child in this country. The net interest that is payable on that debt as a ratio of our exports of goods and services continues to run at the staggeringly high rate of 20 per cent.

It is interesting to look at the growth of foreign debt in this country over the past 20 years, particularly over the past 10 years, throughout most of which this Government has been in office. In 1969-70, only 20 years ago, our net foreign debt was $2 billion. Today our net foreign debt is $131 billion, about 65 times higher than it was only 20 years ago. Twenty years ago the net interest payable on that debt equalled 0.4 per cent. The net foreign debt as a proportion of our gross domestic product was 6.5 per cent. Today that figure is 33.3 per cent. Most of that increase has occurred in the past 10 years. In the past 10 years our net foreign debt has gone from $6.8 billion to $131 billion.

Virtually all of that has occurred since the Hawke Government came to office and the long term consequences for this nation are very grave indeed. I cannot quote a much better authority on what this Government has done to our economy than the man who until March-April of last year was the Minister for Finance for the Hawke Government and had been for the preceding four or five years. In a speech in New York only 10 days ago he said that the Government had `massively stuffed up the economy'. And he explained why.

TALK.START.PARA: —Who said that?

—Senator Walsh said that-the Doodlakine kid said that. He also gave reasons for it. He said that the major cause of Australia's problems was a monetary policy which kept interest rates at around 20 per cent for 18 months. I quote him:

SPEECH.PARA: This also had the perverse effect of pushing up an exchange rate already too high. The credit squeeze was a policy response to the blow-out in aggregate demand which, in 1988-89, pushed the current account deficit above 6 per cent of GDP, at a time when our terms of trade were on a 12 year high. The credit squeeze-
said Senator Walsh, very correctly-

was a policy of last resort because other options for curbing demand were, or were perceived to be, closed off. Thus, it can be argued that the present recession is a function of fiscal policy being too loose.

If we look at what the Treasurer has been saying about fiscal policy over recent months, we will get a very different position. In his Budget Speech just seven months ago he said that the forecast at that time of $8.1 billion `maintains fiscal policy as the Government's principal weapon against the current account deficit and our overseas debt'. Then on 22 February, just 10 days ago, he said:
The estimated surplus is now much lower-$1.7 billion.
Only three days ago, on 3 March, on the Sunday program on Channel 9, when asked whether the Budget would go into deficit, he said:
It's always a possibility . . . It would be no calamity.

The Treasurer has a fundamental question to answer. Senator Button was unable to answer it today. It is a fundamental question that goes to the heart of economy policy that the Treasurer must answer, that is: if a Budget surplus of the order of $8.1 billion only seven months ago was seen as the Government's principal weapon against the current account deficit and our overseas debt and if now, as he says, it would be no calamity not only if that were all wiped out but also if indeed the Budget goes into deficit, what is the explanation for the total contradiction between those two terms? Senator Button today tried to tell us that the reason for the difference was that the world had changed and we have really plunged into recession since the Treasurer introduced his Budget just seven months ago on 21 August.

But the Treasurer, only three months after that, told us that he had planned the recession, that it had been deliberately-to use his word-`engineered', and that he had pulled the levers to engineer that recession. Did he not know on 21 August that he was going to start pulling a few levers? If he did not know on 21 August that he was going to pull a few levers, why did he not? If the Treasurer cannot provide answers to that fundamental question, and if the Treasurer cannot now come up with an unequivocal statement on the role that the Government sees for fiscal policy and the policy weapons that the Government is now going to use to tackle the problems which, it said, fiscal policy was the principal weapon for, then the Treasurer should resign; and if he does not resign, he should be sacked.

The coalition, by contrast, is very clear on the role that it sees for fiscal policy: despite the recession, fiscal policy should remain tight. If there is a continuation of the fiscal laxity that is now prevalent throughout every area of government, with the wipe-out of the Budget surplus, the Budget probably going into deficit, and a borrowing requirement this financial year, 1990-91, of close to 3 per cent of gross domestic product, and then it is compounded-and let us see what happens in that respect next week with the much-vaunted industry statement, which is going to be a ripper-and if that finishes up further weakening fiscal policy, then this Government will stand condemned even more than it stands condemned today.

Further pressure will be put on interest rates-that is the only thing that can happen. The reason for that is that this Government has failed to tackle the fundamental problems of structural reform in this economy and society which need to be addressed in order for us to increase our productivity and, therefore, our output. All that will happen as demand increases because of, amongst other things, increased fiscal laxity, is that very quickly demand will bounce up again against the supply ceiling in this country and will spill over into imports. We will be back on the old accentuated treadmill of balance of payments crisis, inflation crisis and boom and bust, which have been the hallmarks of this Government.

It is not good enough for the Treasurer to cloud the issue of the Budget position by talking about structural and cyclical surpluses or deficits. As I said, regardless of the reason, the public sector will be making calls on financial markets this year and that, categorically and unequivocally, is bad. By condoning the magnitude of the fiscal deterioration, the Government has signalled that it will be leaving monetary policy once again to bear a quite unequal share of the burden of adjustment. Ask any businessman, family or householder in this country what that cripplingly high interest rate policy, that deliberate interest rate policy-because the Government has not had the guts or the ability to take the other measures necessary to get a proper mix of policies in this country-has done to them.

This Government is unable or unwilling to address the structural rigidities in the economy. I have to say that one of the prime architects of this policy-namely, Senator Cook-is sitting opposite and will follow me in this debate. As the Minister for Industrial Relations, Senator Cook is presiding over the continuing rigidities and inflexibilities in the labour market. This critical area of the economy and structure of this country needs a fundamental loosening up and deregulation.

This Government did the right thing back in 1983-84 when it deregulated the financial markets. However, in doing so it made a fundamental error-it did not deregulate the other arm of labour market policy. As a result, we have had a Government which, ever since it has been in office, has relied on the accord to try to keep the lid on wage increases. One would have to say that to some extent that has not been a total failure. But what has been a total failure is that in doing so, the Government has put a high inflationary floor under the economy.

While the Government continues to have a policy which relies on the accord, it will continue to institutionalise high inflation in this country and we will never be allowed to get out of the desperate straitjacket that we are in-the desperateness shown in the economic statistics that are published every day. I must say that I do not hold out much hope of any change in this area. Senator Cook said the other day that the $12 a week wage increase-a wage increase not at all based on productivity-would not cost Australians one job. I ask Senator Cook to ask any employer what it is going to cost in terms of employment. It may not mean that people will be put right off the payroll. What is happening now is that the work force is rocketing to a four-day working week, which means a 20 per cent cut in workers' wages. That situation will continue, and may get worse, as a result of the $12 a week increase.

There is no magic pudding solution to the problems. Everyone accepts that there is a very long, hard road ahead of this country to get out of the mire of fundamental economic problems. I remind the Senate that it is a mire that is largely of the Government's own doing because of the policies that it has pursued. There is a better way, an alternative way. The coalition has spelt it out consistently for several years now in terms of the use of fiscal policy; the proper balance between fiscal and monetary policy; the use of wages policy; the freeing up of the labour market; and not relying on rhetoric but having the practical specific proposals to tackle the fundamental areas of micro-economic reform.

We should never have had the recession that we are now experiencing. It is due to policy miscalculations and mismanagement. Given that we do have it, let us take the opportunity to get at some of the structural problems and other problems confronting us which regrettably, disgracefully, this Government is refusing to tackle at all.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —This is a so-called matter of public importance which has been got up by the Opposition because today, 6 March, is the day on which the current account figures have been released. The Opposition has chosen to release an announcement of those figures to make what it would no doubt regard as an attack upon the management of the economy by this Government.

SPEECH.PARA: A careful look at the current account figures shows that they are nothing like the image that has just been projected. In fact, the image of catastrophe and impending doom that has been projected is no doubt what an Opposition would be expected to wish to paint. To talk down the economy is what an Opposition would be expected to do but, nonetheless, one has to have a clear-eyed view of the facts and we have not been treated to one now.

A remark was made-gratuitously, I thought-about the absence of Senator Button in this debate. It just so happens that Senator Button is working with the other senior economic Ministers in this Government to finalise the industry statement which will be made next Tuesday. Therefore, it is true that the Opposition has to put up with me. I would be delighted if I were somewhere else and not having to answer this but, now that I am here, I am delighted to have the opportunity to shed some light on these allegations.

The first thing that has to be said about what has been put is that there is, on an Opposition, an incumbent responsibility not only to criticise government-and we welcome that criticism-but to say what its alternative model is. We have not heard any exposition of an alternative today. We have heard an attack. We have heard references to, `Oh, we have always referred to our alternative model. Our alternative model is well known'. But really it is not. It has never been cogently presented. It is evasive, it is rubbery, and it is shadowy. It is designed to be all of those things so that there can be no public scrutiny of the alternative economic approach of the Opposition save in some areas of great passion and emotion for it-one would say prejudice and bigotry-that is, areas related to the labour market, which I will go to momentarily. But we do not have the alternative model. We have an allegation of fiscal laxity, and it is one that ignores the fact that, in all of the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries, Australia is closest to Japan in the size of the public sector. We have a very small public sector in this country.

It ignores the fact, too, that the woes of the current account figures -and there are some-are a reflection of borrowings of the private sector, not of the public sector. Overseas borrowings have raised our debt levels but they have not been, by and large, borrowings of the public sector. But I return to the theme, for the moment, of fiscal laxity. Here is an interesting theme- this is an opportunity for the Opposition. I invite it to fill the void, enter the vacuum. (Quorum formed)

I had embarked upon the theme of the allegation of fiscal laxity by this Government-a theme that Senator Short propagated as the central plank in his argument. I now invite, as I did before I was rudely interrupted by the quorum call, other speakers from the Opposition to tell this Parliament and the people of Australia where it is they propose to be fiscally tougher. For example, is the Opposition going to deny the woolgrowers of Australia the money which this Government injected into that industry to support them in the deregulation period of the floor price? Are we going to deny them that? Is that an example of fiscal laxity to which honourable senators opposite refer?

In the interests of fiscal toughness-which apparently is the obverse and what the Opposition would do-are we going to cut pensions in this country? Are we going to cut health benefits in this country, or are we, in the aftermath of the Gulf conflict, to cut some expenditure on defence? Are we going to do something about education? Those are all the big outlay areas of the Budget. If the Opposition is going to be fiscally tough and have a policy that might impress people, it should tell them the truth. What is the Opposition going to cut? The Opposition should stop hiding behind phrases and glib assertions and give us its alternatives. Until the Opposition does that, it is without clothes in this debate and its allegation about fiscal laxity does not stand.

In terms of the importance the Opposition attaches to this debate, having made an issue about Senator Button's absence from the chamber, I should point out that we have just come through Question Time and on this subject there was but one question-an indication of the level of priority the Opposition assigns to it. There were four questions concerning Mr Burke and one question on the economy. This was an orchestrated Question Time by the Opposition. Let us put aside this rubbish about the Opposition believing that this is important.

I now turn to the current account figures which, as I indicated, were released on 6 March, and deal with some key aspects of those figures. In seasonally adjusted terms, the current account deficit for January 1991 was $1.58 billion; in unadjusted terms it was $1.86 billion. The seasonally adjusted figure of $1.5 billion is a 10 per cent fall on the December figure-that is, the January figure is 10 per cent lower than the figure for December. I think it is important to identify the trend line. In seasonally adjusted terms, for the seven months to the end of January 1991, the current account deficit was 23 per cent lower than for the same period last year; again, the core trend is edifying when it is identified.

In seasonally adjusted terms for the seven months to the end of January 1991 exports have risen by 8 per cent and imports have fallen by 5 per cent, indicating an ability to replace imports and lift our export volumes. Importantly, in that export figure there are two key aspects to which we should pay attention. Manufactured exports, the highest value-added exports, have continued their growth and were 16 per cent up on the previous figures. That has to be seen as a significant qualitative change. It also means that the Budget forecast last August for the current account deficit of $8 billion for 1990-91 is achievable. They are significant elements which, interestingly, have not been referred to in this debate by the Opposition because they go against the phantom argument which it proposes to put. Also, these export figures have been achieved in a very difficult climate.

I should like for a moment to talk about the falls in commodity prices. The result in the current account has been achieved despite prices for several of Australia's major commodity exports falling sharply in world markets since mid-1991. It could fairly be said that at Budget time last year one could not have predicted the fall in these prices.

Let me turn to the forecast by the Australian Bureau of Agricultural and Resource Economics of a decline in wool exports by about $1 billion in 1990-91. In fact, wool exports have fallen further than that. They have fallen from $5.9 billion in 1988-89 to $3.8 billion in 1989-90 and are projected to fall to $2.7 billion in 1990-91. In addition, exports of cereals were $3.1 billion in 1989-90 and are forecast to be $2.3 billion in 1990-91. Despite those falls in high volume, high money earning commodities in this current account figure, exports have increased by 8 per cent and manufacturing exports have increased by 16 per cent. With those trade terms running against us, there has nonetheless been that improvement in the current account. It does not indicate the catastrophe that has been foreshadowed here.

Senator Button in answer to a question at Question Time did say that a big difference now is that we are in a recession, and that is reflected to some extent, but, comparing this downturn with the 1982-83 downturn, there are important differences. Inflation is now beginning to come under control. The underlying rate of inflation continued to fall over this year to the December quarter of 1990 to 5.4 per cent. The Government is confident that this downward trend will continue, and our confidence is well-based.

In the area of my own portfolio responsibility, the wage-tax trade-off delivered by the Government on 1 January was a significant circuit-breaker in the inflationary cycle. I interpolate that, if there is to be another significant circuit-breaker in the wages spiral in the next few years, it can be achieved only through an accord arrangement that we have with the Australian trade union movement, the like of which the Opposition envies but does not aspire to and cannot ever emulate in terms of its policies.

The orderly management of aggregate wage growth which the accord and the centralised wage system have given this Government have enabled it to deliver a predictable target figure, and in some cases to undershoot it, on what aggregate wage outcomes will be. We have a wages policy through the accord which enables that predictability and that degree of economic planning which the Opposition does not have. The fundamental labour market reform strategy in this Government under the processes of award restructuring has used the wages system to deliver improvements in the flexibility and productivity of Australian enterprises. That is another reason why there has been the increase in exports, particularly in the manufacturing sector.

The attempt of the Opposition to blame wage and salary earners for all the economy's ills is implicit in what the Opposition says and it is central to what John Howard says. He calls for a return to a 40-hour week and the abolition of a leave loading. These are dangerous distractions from the necessity of continuing with the award restructuring task that we have embarked on. The success of award restructuring will make a vital contribution to turning around the current account deficit by making sure Australian enterprises can compete with their overseas counterparts.
I move to a more fundamental point. Another fundamental difference in the economic performance of this country is that aggregate company profits have begun to decline substantially.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I bring to your notice the state of the House. We on this side of the Senate believe that the Leader of the Government in the Senate should be leading this debate anyway.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. The state of the House request was presaged by a comment of belief from the Opposition as to who should speak from the Government side on this debate. The conjunction of the two ideas is put so as to imply that members of the Opposition are vexatiously invoking the Standing Orders in order to interrupt the speech that I am making, which they obviously dislike, and to punish the Government and the Parliament because the Leader of the Government in the Senate, Senator Button, is not here. In those circumstances, I urge upon you, Mr Acting Deputy President, not to accept the request for a quorum and to allow me to complete my remarks in the four or five minutes that I have.
—On the point of order, Mr Acting Deputy President: I bring to your notice the state of the House. (Quorum formed)

—I have now had my speech interrupted twice by quorum calls, vexatiously made in order to try to punish the Government in some way for Senator Button not being here. We are being broadcast; therefore for those who might be listening I will identify who has descended this debate into farce. Let it be now on the record that the interruption of the Government's point of view in this debate-being led by me, a Cabinet Minister, on behalf of the Government-in order that that view not be heard was by Senator Walters, Tasmania, Liberal Party of Australia and by Senator Brownhill, New South Wales, National Party of Australia. They are the two people who have vexatiously used Standing Orders to prevent free speech from being heard in this chamber and to prevent the Government from delivering its view on the economy. If this is an example of the sorts of tactics that the Opposition wants to engage in, then it does not believe in reasoned argument, debate or consideration; it believes in vexatiously using the Standing Orders to disrupt debate and consideration of issues in this chamber.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I draw your attention to the fact that the Minister has described the taking of points of order as being in some way improper in the running of this chamber. I ask you to direct the Minister and teach him that points of order are perfectly appropriate to be used in this Parliament. When Senator Cook could not even get sufficient members of his own Party to come to listen to him, it is a pretty bad indication of respect for this Parliament.
—I do not believe that this is a legitimate point of order.

—I now identify Senator Newman, Tasmania, Liberal Party, as another who is vexatiously using the Standing Orders to prevent the Government's point of view from being heard in this debate. I conclude, in summary, by saying that this is not a return--
—Order! Senator Cook, your time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —Today Senator Short has introduced a matter of public importance which once again chastises the Government for its failure to pursue policies to address Australia's fundamental economic problems, including its chronic balance of payments and debt problems, as demonstrated by the failure of the January balance of payments figures released today to show any significant improvement.

SPEECH.PARA: One could of course be a bit pedantic and say that the Government has pursued some policies to try to redress the difficult economic situation that we are in. It has certainly tried to do so. In its collective mind it probably thinks that it has produced the right policies. Unfortunately, the evidence is on the table that those policies were definitely the wrong policies. The central policy platform of the Government was to depress demand right across the economy by the use of high interest rates. It pursued that policy in an attempt to reduce Australia's demand for imports. Clearly this was the use of an indiscriminate sledge-hammer to crack one specific nut for which a nutcracker should have been used. We should have used specific measures to reduce our imports and boost our exports. Instead, we now have an engineered recession on our hands.

The results of that recession have often been tabled, but they bear repeating. We now have an unemployment figure which is a quarter of a million people higher than it was a year ago. It is above 8 per cent and rising. Perhaps the worst statistic: it is 23 per cent of young people. These are people who are starting out in their lives; people trying to build careers; people who are the future of Australia. Almost a quarter of them are now without jobs. Clearly the Government has not succeeded in its policy to redress the economic problems. But neither, it must be said, has the Opposition offered any solutions.

I have again listened carefully to what Senator Short had to say. Apart from micro-economic reform, which is certainly a laudable objective and one that must be pursued with vigour, I failed to detect in his speech any alternative program to develop our economy to the point where we can say that people once again can have jobs and where we are once again in a position to be internationally competitive. As it is, the foreign debt continues to rise, and the net income deficit as a result is also rising. In fact, today's January balance of payments figures confirm this alarming trend. The seasonally adjusted figure for the January current account deficit is nearly $1.6 billion, but the net income deficit for January is actually in excess of the total of $1.624 billion. We are now in hock to the world and the interest debt is driving us further into hock.

The Government is saying that we have made great gains in terms of the merchandise trade component, and that is true. Over the past seven months the merchandise trade deficit has been reduced by $3.7 billion but, unfortunately, this has only been achieved by driving the country into recession, as I have said before. What will happen when the economy starts to recover? Imports will again start to blow out and all the pain of the recession will be for no gain on the current account. Clearly, we need to pursue some more effective import limitation policies. This will not be simple, given our intention to adhere to the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade. However, it has been shown that other nations do not have the same compunction about adhering to the guidelines. When we look at the subsidies that are being paid to primary producers in Europe and the United States, we wonder why we should move into a free trade position and deliver up our primary producers as the sacrificial lambs.

We should look for very specific measures to reduce our imports. As an example, a plan, which should be given consideration, has been put forward by Mr Ernst Roedek from the Institute of Management and the Society for Balanced Trade. It seeks to relate directly our imports to exports by issuing credits for any exports that are actually affected and allowing them to be traded in the market as entitlements to introduce imports into Australia. No public money is necessary under that scheme, and exporters would receive significant benefits; in other words, it is a scheme where imports would subsidise exports. The matter has some complexity and would involve difficult transitional provisions. However, I believe that it is worth investigation by the Government.

I also welcome the recent announcement by Senator Button of the first grants under the international trade enhancement program. Although only two firms have received assistance, it is certainly a welcome development. High technology manufacturing must be fostered in Australia if we are to become a modern and competitive industrial nation.

Australia also has a head start in various areas of environmental technology. We must not lose the commercialisation race of our inventions after doing so well in the research area. I agree wholeheartedly with Mr Stocker of the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation, who stresses the urgency of positive government action to get the potentially massive environmental industries off the ground in Australia. Alternative energy, waste management and pollution abatement are at a critical stage in Australia and a kick-start is needed now. All that is needed is the willingness to develop strategies which assist particularly strategically placed industries rather than offering up our economy on the altar of free trade and a totally deregulated market system.

Mr Crean and Mr Dawkins are correct when they cite the policy of the Australian Democrats, as they have in the last few weeks and months. We need more government intervention and more research. The cooperative research centres are something the Democrats support wholeheartedly, yet they still remain an idea. We would like some action and we would like it soon.

Australia's anti-dumping rules are obsolete. It is clear that we can no longer afford a system where damage has to be caused to Australian producers before action can be taken. Currently, the relevant legislation provides for 175 days for the process to take place to assess an anti-dumping claim. It is clear that that must be brought closer to 50 days. It is also clear to us that if a prima facie case is established we should place the onus for the final proof that they are not dumping on the people who are putting their products onto Australian markets.

Many examples, such as the orange concentrate, cement, dried fruit from Turkey, canned ham, chemicals and pasta, to name just a few, have caused tremendous damage to our industries and lost jobs in Australia. It should not be beyond our wit to protect ourselves in this sort of situation. In extreme cases, I would suggest that we should even look at prohibiting the importation of specific items.

However, another major area in this dumping procedure debate is currently taking place to which we should pay some attention; that is, the protection of our living standards, the protection of our social standards. Are we really saying that we are prepared to lose out to products which are produced by sweated labour under conditions which do not take any account of safety or the social and environmental values of our community. I believe that there is a strong case to tie the considerations of equal standards of production and social standards that apply in any one community to the question of how high protective tariffs should be.

Other areas require urgent attention. The tax system needs further tightening and orienting towards productive enterprises. I am pleased to hear, if the media are to be believed, that the Government has virtually determined that accelerated depreciation allowances will be part of the measures to be announced in the industry statement.

Tariff reductions in isolation are not enough. We must guarantee that employees who are made redundant by the trade flows or by advancing technology are retrained at a level where they can still continue to maintain their families. As an example, a German worker may retrain four or five times in a career. We still have the mentality that people are useless if they become unemployed. As I have said before, we have proved that right now with a quarter of a million new unemployed people. This must be reversed. I am looking forward to the industry statement addressing this particular problem in a substantial manner.

The developing country tariff preferences of five per cent, which is currently still enjoyed by Singapore, South Korea, Hong Kong and Taiwan, clearly need to be removed. These nations have stronger manufacturing bases than Australia and should not be granted an advantage which is so clearly out of date. I wonder why we are hesitating.

Government purchasing is another key area where much more intervention is necessary. It has been shown in recent days by reports in the media that, in the defence area and overseas in the area of telecommunications, where orders are placed within a country and where industries are supported to gear up their production in a more productive manner significant gains can be achieved in terms of employment with virtually no losses in terms of the higher cost of products.

We believe that we need national industry plans not only in steel, textiles and cars, where we have them now, but also in the forestry industries and tourism. We clearly need financial reregulation to protect investors and to give them courage and confidence to invest in Australia rather than taking the money overseas. We obviously need further amendments to the corporations legislation to ensure that companies and their employees are acting in the interests of Australian investors and are not simply lining their pockets. We need a serious effort on recycling and waste reduction as part of the drive to make us more competitive in the international area.

The final and possibly most important measure is the need to provide adequate capital for our small and medium sized businesses. These are the real entrepreneurs, not the paper shufflers who have disgraced Australia during recent times. I hope the encouraging newspaper reports concerning action by Senator Button are correct and that there will be a fund providing equity capital for small and medium sized businesses which are currently starved of capital as a result of the deregulation period and the banking boom and bust so evidently supported by the Government and the Opposition.

It is quite clear that the Opposition does not have the answers. It continues with its position that everything can be solved by delivering our primary producers, our industry and our workers to the workings of the market rather than establishing priorities based on the aspirations of our community, which should result in carefully targeted intervention.

Under the Opposition's policies, all goods and services would be taxed. Funerals, food and health services would all become more expensive, and luxury motor vehicles would become cheaper. Export assistance would be eliminated under the current Opposition policy, and there would be no guarantee or other assistance for primary producers. Capital gains will become tax free if the asset is held for more than five years.

It is quite clear, when one looks at these components of the Opposition's policies that have been put forward, that it does not have the solution to our current economic problems. I think it is useful for the Opposition to submit such a matter of public importance, where the Government can be chastised for the direction it has taken which is costing Australian families dearly; unfortunately, it also discloses the Opposition's own bankruptcy as far as ideas and alternative directions are concerned.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather peculiar to follow a speaker with such hype as Senator Spindler displayed in the last few minutes of this debate on a matter of public importance regarding what the Opposition's policy may or may not be. It just shows how the Australian Democrats belong to the left wing of the Australian Labor Party.

SPEECH.PARA: The current account figures released today are very high-much higher than expected initially. The figure is around $2 billion-$1.6 billion seasonally adjusted, and about $1.9 billion seasonally unadjusted. As I said, the figures are much higher than expected and imports are still disturbingly high. These figures will not do very much-in fact, they will do nothing-to trigger the turnaround of the Australian economy and the expected further drop in interest rates.

We have run the course with using interest rates as an effective measure to control the economy. In fact, the Government has gone overboard with keeping interest rates high. Then, of course, we had the engineered recession. At least, the Government said it was engineered to try to recover some lost face when it ran straight into the worst depression since the 1930s.

I know that the Government's interest rate policy was wrong. In fact, I remember being on the same plane as the former Minister for Finance when we were going to a rural crisis meeting in Western Australia. When I asked him, `What have you got next?', he replied, `What can we find next? We used the high interest rate policy and it didn't work, so what else can we find?'. There was a full admission of what had gone wrong.

In our present position there is no way that we can sustain the standard of living that we have been used to in Australia and the benefits that Australia needs so badly. The blow-out in the January current account deficit has seen money market yields rise and the hope of any further cut in interest rates has gone down the drain.

Madam Acting Deputy President, as you would probably expect, I now turn to the effect of the decline in rural exports on the current account deficit. In the period from 1983-84 to 1987-88, rural exports increased by 14.1 per cent annually. If this growth were applied to the value of our rural products in 1987-88 of $15.242 billion, the estimated value of rural imports in 1989-90 would have been $19.850 billion. The actual figure was $15.305 billion. Thus, if rural exports had increased at the same rate over the last two years as in the previous four years, their value would have been $4.5 billion higher and the current account deficit reduced by the same amount. The policies of this Government have done anything but allow that to happen. A reduction of $4.5 billion in the current account deficit for 1989-90 would have represented a reduction of 22 per cent. That is only the rural sector, without considering what any other sector in the community could have done to improve the situation-and I have not mentioned mining.

One economist has been quoted as calling the results announced today `a bit of a nightmare'. I know that there are many in rural Australia who would call the state of our economy far more than a nightmare. Actually, they do not have nightmares because, if people cannot sleep at night, they cannot have a nightmare. For many people, the nightmare is real. I know that because I go out there and see it all the time. I would be happy for some Government members to see it for themselves. In fact, Senator Aulich will probably be in my area next week with a standing committee. I invite him to take some time off so that I can take him around and introduce him to people who will back up exactly what I have said.

The monthly deficit of $1.863 billion is about $300m above the highest market forecast, and compares with a $1.197 billion deficit in December. These figures show that imports are not falling in line with the weakness in the domestic economy, and also point to a crack in Australia's strong export performance in 1990.

Although the tonnage of wheat exported increased over this current account period, the gross value decreased due to a reduction in the average price per tonne. I suppose someone will ask me whether I am blaming the Government for the drop in the return on wheat in the last 12 months. Well, yes, I am. Part of the blame lies with the Government but most of it lies with the General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT). This Government could have used more force with the GATT Round and the United States of America. Instead of sending this not-sohigh level delegation to the United States, it could have sent a top level delegation to work on the United States. Instead of sending a not-so-high delegation, it could have dealt with the European Economic Community as well and made sure that we maintain our share of the market in the Gulf.

There was also the fiasco of Mr Kerin's change to the wheat marketing plan for the period from 1984 to 1989 when he took away the guaranteed minimum price (GMP). Unfortunately, the industry itself and industry leaders willingly gave away the GMP and now they want it back. They have not got a snowball's chance in hell of getting it back from this Minister. There was a decline in wheat income as well.

The value of sheep and lamb slaughtering decreased for the second successive year by 25.8 per cent to $548.1m. The value of wool decreased for the first time since 1982-83 to $5.742 billion, a decrease of 2.8 per cent from 1988-89, but of course there has been a sudden downturn in the last few months. With the difficulties that we are now experiencing with our export of these commodities, one can only guess at how devastating these figures will be at the next round in a month's time.

I move quickly to the people that this crisis is affecting most in the rural parts of Australia-that is, women. Friday, 8 March has been declared International Women's Day. For rural women, the past 12 months have been bleak due to the Government's mismanagement of the economy and next year they will be far worse off. The crisis is biting very hard in rural Australia, and the resulting depression in remote areas has compounded mostly on women. In 1986, the rural women's contribution amounted to $8 billion. In 1989, there were 390,000 people in the Australian rural work force of whom 100,000, or 26 per cent, were women.

For the 2 1/2 million women living in rural Australia the current economic situation is catastrophic. Inflation, unemployment and high interest rates have hit hard. Pain and anguish stalk our farms and country towns. Three or four years ago high interest rates forced women into the work force in the small towns near their farms. They did that to increase their cash flow to help pay loans with interest rates that were out of this world. The recession has come along in the last 12 months and these women have now lost their jobs or have had to leave their jobs to help their husbands run the farm. The farmers could not afford to keep their sons on the farms any longer and their sons had to go to other projects such as mining or, if they were qualified, they went back into their professions so as to keep things moving.
