One-third of small businesses in Australia are owned by women. There has been further pressure on these women. Many of the small businesses are in the country. In his speech Senator Spindler pointed out that the bigger employers of personnel are small businesses rather than the large corporations. But it is the small businesses rather than the big ones that have been going broke in droves over the last 18 months. I know that the big businesses have had some downfalls, but certainly the small businesses have copped a lot. As I have said, one-third of those small businesses are owned by women. The downturn in small businesses was caused by farmers and other businesses ceasing to buy if not 12 months ago, then six months ago.

Rural women have not had an equal opportunity in education because of this Government's mismanagement of the economy and because of its policies that favour places other than remote areas. That applies not only to the women but also to the young people. In 1987-88, 72 per cent of rural families monitored in an Isolated Children's Parents Association survey had a taxable income of less than $30,000 and 65 per cent of these families faced education and access costs between $5,000 and $15,000 in 1989. In 1973 an isolated child's allowance was half the boarding school fees. Nobody can tell me that that is a snob's education. Whether they like it or not, people living in remote areas can do nothing but use boarding schools. Now the Government's assistance for isolated children will be worth only 20 per cent of the boarding component. I hope that Government members who have any say in this area will have this assistance increased after the inquiry into this matter.

Difficulties are also being experienced in retaining Austudy for tertiary age children. Last week a distraught mother rang me in my office. Her son was refused Austudy. On inquiry it was found out that Austudy had been rejected twice for a technical reason. On the third application it was granted so her son will now be able to continue his education.

This Government's management has done nothing for remote areas. Production in the rural areas is how we will get out of trouble in this recession. We have to get agricultural production up again so there is money in those areas. In the meantime, the mining industry is keeping us going. If on 12 March the Government makes the right decision and announces that it will introduce measures such as accelerated depreciation, many more projects will get going and improve the economy. Incentives must be provided to put these projects into place. As I mentioned earlier this morning, a compact steel mill in the south-west would provide employment. We have to get this country moving again. Unfortunately, the way that this Government is managing the economy is not doing anything to get it going again.

Micro-economic reform is needed. We need costs cut on the waterfront so as to compete with our trading partners. That also has to be done in transport, and there has to be labour market reform. I do not have time to repeat it but this morning I gave a good example of a young fellow in Perth who had a job and earned $322 a week. The job was wiped out because of ridiculous labour market regulations. When we are in government we will certainly do something about that.

My time is running out but I support everything that my colleague Senator Short said in this debate. No doubt, I will support what Senator Bishop says. This Government has badly mismanaged the economy. It has pushed us into a corner that I cannot see us getting out of for another four or five years unless it does a great turnaround now.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Aulich Sen T.G.

TALK.START.PARA: —This debate is an important one but unfortunately it has tended to take the same direction as a number of debates on economics, both within this Parliament and outside the Parliament. On the whole it has been characterised once again by an obsession with finding a single cause and a single solution for Australia's economic condition. That in itself has proved to be, in a sense, a changing fashion ever since I came to this Parliament in 1984.

SPEECH.PARA: I recall the first major obsession that both the press and the Opposition, in particular, concentrated on when I first came here. It was the value of the Australian dollar. Fashions then changed. It became a question of Government spending. The next obsession was the deficit and surplus. All the questions that came from the other side were about that. In many cases, they were reported avidly by the economic gurus of the day. Now, of course, it is the balance of trade. All three have had their time as the most fashionable matter of public discussion and, in many ways, the most fashionable problem to be overcome.

If one looks at the Government's record one sees that it has taken a fairly conservative approach to economic management. We have taken on board a large measure of the prescriptions brought forward and enunciated by the classical economists over the last decade. In fact, some of them might even be considered to be a new part of the Labor pantheon, because they have not been part of the traditional Labor approach to the way we managed economies in the past.

I will go through some of those prescriptions laid down by the economic gurus in the past and, in many cases, repeated by the Opposition. I could start with the deregulation of the financial system. This Government took the bull by the horns. It took the advice given by the prevailing orthodoxy at the time. We deregulated the banks. We allowed new players into the game. We floated the Australian dollar so that it would find its own place in the market; in other words, its real value was assessed. Obviously, at the end of the day, it was worked out by the market itself rather than by the more artificial and arbitrary methods used in previous years. The net result of that has been problems with the banks, a massive orgy of overlending and overcommitment, in some cases to very dubious enterprises in this country and, in some ways, the skew-whiffing of investment in this country towards speculative investment instead of long term investment in our blue chip industries.

The floating of the Australian dollar in the long run has made it at this stage about the fourth most traded currency in the world. No-one in this Parliament could say, for example, that the Australian dollar is genuinely at the correct level. I do not think that the market has set the Australian dollar at the level at which it should be as a measurement of the Australian economy. Its overly high value has certainly been a problem for exporters in this country.

TALK.START.PARA: —Because of your high interest rate policy.

—It is not just because of our high interest rate policy; a number of other factors come into it. It might have something to do with Australia's vulnerability as a small country in a major world operation in which financial markets work more closely together every day.

SPEECH.PARA: The second move that we made, apart from deregulating the financial system, was to cut government spending in gross terms and as a percentage of our gross national product. All the economic gurus called for that. It was the type of thing that everyone regarded as the most commonsense thing to do, and we did it. In 1984-87, government expenditure of gross national product was 37 per cent. By 1985-90 that had dropped to 31 per cent. In other words, a 6 per cent drop in the percentage of gross national product was taken up by government expenditure. During that period the only countries in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development (OECD) which surpassed us in terms of an effective record in that area were the United Kingdom and Ireland.

As everyone knows, this Government has an unsurpassed record in its capacity to retire debt as debt becomes due and debts are rolled over. In effect, this Government has not borrowed for over four years because of its very tight budgeting policy. On the second point, we have basically carried out what the economic gurus over the past decade have been telling us to do. Again, the Opposition has supported us in that particular move. We have been able to do what the Opposition was never able to do in its period in government.

The third thing that we have done that fits in with the economic prescriptions of the classical economists is to drop tariff barriers and remove inhibition to freer trade. In fact, one could describe Australia as one of the leaders in the world in terms of its response to the overall General Agreement on Tariffs and Trade (GATT) philosophy. We have dropped quotas in the car industry, we have removed controls over the importation of fertiliser, and so on down the line. Of course, as everyone knows, we have also dropped tariff protection and other forms of protection for the car industry, the textile industry, the footwear industry, the clothing industry and other industries. There has not been a government in the past 20 years that has followed the free trade route as assiduously as we have. We may not have taken it as far as some people would have liked in theory to have gone but we have done it within the realms of what is politically realistic and what is acceptable to social change in Australia.

What has been the response there? We have led the way in GATT in trying to create an international level playing field. Have other countries followed our role? The answer is that in many ways some of the major players in the game, such as Japan and the United States, have given in to their particular vested interest groups and have used all forms of control to ensure that we are not able to compete on equal terms with their home-grown industries. That has been our reward for moving in that particular direction.

Again, we have attempted to control the flood of imports through tighter monetary controls and other techniques. We have kept interest rates high, and, at a time when now the high interest rate brakes need to come off, we have found that the banks themselves have created a secondary monetary policy in which they have continued to prop up interest rates at a much higher level than that which is acceptable to the market, is necessary for the recovery of this country and is acceptable to the Government. In fact, the banks have a second credit squeeze on. Why? In many cases, it is simply to compensate for the bad lending policies that they have been engaged in over the past five years or so. At the end of the day, the consumer suffers for that. Again, the Government has carried out the classical prescriptions advocated by the classical economists who dominate the thinking of the economic community here and, in particular, the major thinkers on the front bench of the Liberal-National Party Opposition.

We have followed the prescription of the classical economists in reducing personal income tax and company tax. The reduction of company tax has in no way diminished the move towards an increase in the number of incorporated bodies in Australia. Amongst the OECD countries, Australia has one of the highest levels of incorporation of companies. Why? No-one is quite sure but one would believe that to some extent it is related to limited liability that is given by the company structure. The lowering of personal income tax rates has not in any way halted that move towards the greater incorporation of entities in this country. Again, the reduction of personal income tax has in many ways not succeeded in the way that many people had hoped. Yet that was one of the major calls advocated by the Opposition. The Opposition has said, `Reduce personal income tax and you will increase incentives to work and this country will get going again'. Once again, the classical prescription has not worked in the way many people, in particular the Opposition, hoped it would.

There is one area where the Government differs very strongly from the Opposition. There have been continuing calls for deregulation of the labour market. Let us face it; when we get down to tintacks and as a Government go to the Opposition and put these prescriptions to it, saying, `Yes, we have carried out most of those. Now what do you want us to do?', the Opposition says, `You may have carried those out but it is essential that you move towards deregulation of the labour market. If only you could do that, coupled with micro-economic reform, and increases in productivity, Australia would get going again'.

Again, in that search for single cause and single solution approaches to economics, the Opposition is wrong. If we look at the success of the accord we see a very good reason why this Government will refuse to deregulate the labour market in the way that the Opposition is calling for. Studies done by Mr Bruce Chapman and Fred Gruen in 1990 calculated the value of the accord in a number of ways. In economic terms, their calculations indicated, according to the models that would give a uniformity throughout the world to conditions relating, for example, to wages and economic growth and so on, that between 1983 and 1987 Australia would be in the position of having a 70 per cent fall in the level of industrial disputes compared with 40 per cent for the rest of the world. Similarly, their studies showed that the wage-caused part of inflation was dropping at about 3 per cent per annum between 1983 and 1989. Again, there was a reduction in real wages; that is, the cost to employers of employing people on the whole dropped between 9 per cent and 10 per cent over the period 1983 to 1989. Of course, this was compensated for in terms of the workers' benefits by improvements in social security and other areas such as health and a spread and a deepening of superannuation benefits which at last were given to a much larger section of the community compared with that which was enjoyed, say, 20 years ago.

The worker got a better deal; the Government, in many ways, got a better deal; and the community got a better deal out of that improvement in superannuation benefits. This is remembering that in 1988-89 Australia experienced boom years in its growth. Yet that was not accompanied by wages explosions. It is interesting that we can have a boom and yet no wages explosion. That is primarily because the accord-that unique social document, an economic management tool drawn up and redrawn through consultation between the trade union movement and the Government-worked in a way that has been of great surprise to other countries in the OECD. Whenever I have been overseas and talked to people in this area who have an interest in industrial relations, economic development and the role of social contracts, they have gone out of their way to state that Australia has engaged in a unique and successful experiment.

I put on record here that this Government in no way is going to resile from the notion and the practice of a social contract along the lines of the accord. The accord is a flexible instrument for social, economic and labour policy. It is something that we are sticking with. All the calls by the Opposition along the lines of classical economics-all those calls for a change to the accord, for an ending of the accord, and for a deregulation of the labour market-will come to nothing, because the accord is still one of the major successes of this Government and of the management of this economy.

What have members of the Opposition offered? To Australia's problems they are offering the simple solution of a consumption tax, increased micro-economic reform, and cutting government spending further. And that is it. How on earth can the people of Australia accept an alternative party which has only that trio of solutions to offer for the improvement of Australia's economic productivity and Australia's economy?

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —Sitting here listening to the debate put forward by the Government, one cannot help but feel sadness. Senator Short and others have drawn attention to the fact that we have not had Senator Button with us today. Senator Button, the Leader of the Government in this chamber, has not seen fit to be present when we are dealing with areas affecting the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating), his own policy area of industry, and of course Senator Evans's area of trade. It is pleasing to see Minister Cook present for at least the part of this debate concerning the need for the deregulation of the labour market. He is relevant to that extent.

SPEECH.PARA: However, the absence of Senator Button, I think, has to be remarked upon, particularly as we are now hearing the universal excuse of the need to prepare the ubiquitous industry statement. The industry statement has been used recently by the Prime Minister to say that he could not accept Dr Hewson's suggestion to accompany him to the United States to lead a mission to attempt to prevent the United States dumping wheat on our traditional wheat markets in the Middle East: he had to stay here because he had to finalise the industry statement. We cannot have Senator Button in the chamber today because he has to be away finalising the industry statement. Yet we read in the newspaper yesterday that indeed the industry statement has already been finalised and that Cabinet put its marker on it yesterday.

So we find ourselves in the situation of having a debate where the main theme has been: do not blame us; we have really done a good job and Australia is in great shape. Senator Cook's theme of near enough being good enough is one we have heard before. He says, `Do not criticise us; we are really doing a great job'. He says that the Opposition should really be blamed because its policies have not been spelt out enough and indeed implemented. Of course, the problem with that argument is that Dr Hewson has on many occasions said that, if the Government took over and adopted policies which we have put forward, it would get bipartisan support and Australia might have a chance to get out of the recession, which, the Treasurer has told us, he specifically engineered. He told us that we were having the recession we had to have, but subsequently he has gone on to admit that he got it wrong and the Prime Minister has gone on to admit that he got it wrong. I wonder how long we are going to have to wait before we see a resignation or two that says that they wish to atone for having got it wrong.

The argument that Senator Short put forward in opening this debate was simply to condemn the Government for its failure to pursue policies to address Aus- tralia's fundamental economic problems, including the chronic balance of payments and debt problems which have been highlighted today with the release of those figures showing that in seasonally adjusted terms we have gone down the tube a further $1.6 billion. Senator Cook would have us believe that it is really okay, that we are not going down the tube quite as quickly this year as we did last year and that really we should take some sort of solace from that fact.

Senator Short outlined neatly and clearly that the Treasurer told us at the time of the introduction of the Budget that we were going to have this wonderful surplus of $8 billion, now disappearing fast down to $1.7 billion and about to disappear altogether. Three months later, having presented that Budget and having told us that everything was wonderful, he told us that he was pulling the levers that would trigger the recession we had to have. Senator Short asked: how can we believe a man who within a space of three months tells us that everything in the country is terrific and that we have to be plummeted into the dire straits of a recession? Tell that to the unemployed. Tell that to the people who are suffering personal bankruptcies. Tell that to ordinary Australians, for whom recession translates into pain and suffering. Tell it to kids who are being pulled out of school. Tell it to the kids whose excursions are not able to be afforded. Tell it to the women who have been earning that second income but have lost their jobs, not even being counted in the unemployment figures. Tell it to those who cannot make their mortgage payments because of the high interest policy that the Government has pursued, which has meant that people are starting to lose their homes. Feel proud of that, Senator Cook? It is not a good record to defend, is it? I truly do feel a touch of sorrow for the Minister.

TALK.START.PARA: —Spare your tears, please.

—Oh, Senator Cook! The deregulation of the labour market, which is relevant to the Minister's portfolio and which is essential if we are to see our way out of the mire, becomes pivotal in this debate today for the simple reason that it brings into sharp focus what occurred subsequent to the deregulation of the financial market. What did we have? We had a freeing up of the financial market and we had a tight grip held on the labour market which affected all those industries in manufactures where we needed to see positive investment and where we saw investment not flowing for the simple reason that the areas that were left were property and paper, where regulation and a tight grip of the labour market were not felt.

SPEECH.PARA: We have promised that we will see a deregulation of the labour market; a reduction of tariffs to a negligible rate by the year 2000, concurrently with micro-economic reform in the areas of telecommunications, privatisation, transportation and the wharves; and, further, the reform of the tax system, including the abolition of the wholesale tax system and the introduction of a goods and services tax. These solutions are all relevant to making Australia competitive and, unless Australia is truly competitive, there is no way we can trade our way out of the dilemma and the difficulties which eight years of this Labor Government have delivered to the Australian people.
Recently the Business Council of Australia published a worthwhile volume: Developing Australia's National Competitiveness. I think it is worth quoting:

Being competitive in any market means firms satisfying customers in relation to price, quality and reliability and unless the nation can compete it soon loses the wherewithal to save and invest enough to stay in the race except by cutting living standards or increasing borrowing indefinitely. Neither is a viable long-term option. The challenge is to improve the performance of the whole Australian economy by tackling the underlying determinants of competitiveness.

As long as we have Senator Cook and others-in particular, Senator Aulich-claiming that the accord is a great solution to Australia's problems, we will go on seeing Australia in an economic bind. The accord is no solution. The accord is part of the problem. Until we see deregulation of the labour market, we will not see our way clear.

Let us take a really good look at the part Senator Button has played in bringing Australia to its knees. I said at the beginning of my speech that the Treasurer and the Prime Minister played a major role, but so has the good Senator Button-who cannot be with us today. He has presided over eight years of failed industry policy. The balance of payments figures today simply bear that fact out. Also today we have seen the Minister for Trade and Overseas Development (Dr Blewett) leading a low level bipartisan mission to the United States, a mission that will not go on to the European Community but will simply spend one day talking to the United States Administration and one day lobbying the Congress.

As we see that mission go, we realise that we have a Prime Minister who has not been prepared to take up Dr Hewson's offer to go to the United States to fight for Australia's right to maintain those markets. The Prime Minister has not done so for two reasons. One is that the precious industry statement might have been read by the Treasurer; a bit of the gloss might have rubbed off on him. Second, I suggest that the Prime Minister really did not want his influence in the United States truly tested. He was not prepared to take the risk of being rebuffed. Because of his own vanity he was not prepared to go to the United States with Dr Hewson to attempt to fight for Australia's access to those markets.

Of course, we also have that wonderful institution, Austrade. Austrade was relaunched by Senator Button who fought to keep it out of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade because he wanted to be in command of it. He fought for it. In 1986 he relaunched it. He said that it would be the answer to all our trading problems. Well, four years later we have the damning McKinsey report which has simply said that Austrade has failed. If we want a bit of good evidence that it is still failing we need only look at Austrade's record in the last several days in dealing with getting Australian contractors into the market for the reconstruction of Kuwait.

To begin with, Austrade released a press statement on 28 February which said that it had been contacted by some 150 companies interested particularly in engineering, construction and equipment supply with regard to the reconstruction of Kuwait. It said that the first stage of the letting of contracts was expected to last some 120 days and that the second stage would last some five years. It was also stated that the potential for Australian companies in the second stage would include communications, processed food, defence support, security systems, health services and agriculture. It also said that it had registered some 30 Australian companies with the United States Army Corps of Engineers, which is handling the first stage of the reconstruction.

However, to test that statement, a would-be exporter phoned Austrade to find out how good its intentions and ability to deliver was. He was very simply told that it was unlikely that Australian companies would get any contracts in the first round; we had missed the boat, but hold on and hope for good luck in the second round. He was further informed that four Australian officials had been withdrawn from Riyadh at the outbreak of hostilities. I do not know what level those officials were; that was not part of the information given. However, there has been an announcement that we will now be putting back the No. 2 man. Hopefully that will improve our prospects of doing business. It will not.

At the time when we need that solid representation; when we needed, in those four years under Senator Button's administration, Austrade to grow and strengthen and be ready for an opportunity such as this, his policies have failed us yet again. Government action has failed this country badly. All we have had is tight monetary policy which has led to unnaturally high exchange rates, despite a bit of intervention now and again, and crippling interest rates, which have stifled demand and strangled investment. The outcome has been bankruptcy, personal pain and suffering and job losses.

Today is a significant day. Today marks the start of the ninth year of Labor administration in this country. It is a good reason for wearing black. The Treasurer has failed, and has admitted he has failed. Industry policy has failed. We are yet to hear the apology from the Minister for Industry, Technology and Commerce. The Government has failed. Australia is in a recession it did not deserve. Australia is in a recession which has yet to feel the true impact of the rural recession and the overseas economic slowdown. In other words, it is going to be a double-whammy.

At the beginning of the Government's ninth year I hardly think we can wish the Australian people happiness and prosperity. We can only say, `Australians hang on'. If the Government will have the good sense to accept our policies we will give it bipartisan support and give this nation and the Australian people a chance to fight back and show that, despite the poverty of the Government's policies, we can win in the end.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Childs Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing a matter of public importance introduced by the Opposition, which states:

SPEECH.PARA: The failure of the Government to pursue polices to redress Australia's fundamental economic problems, including its chronic balance of payments and debt problems, as demonstrated by the failure of the January balance of payments figures released today to show any significant improvement.

I think it is important to go through some of the facts in order to refute some of the things that Senator Short and other Opposition senators have said. In January the balance of payments battled an unfavourable movement in the terms of trade to record a 10 per cent improvement in the current account deficit over the month of December in seasonally adjusted terms. The seasonally adjusted January balance of payments figure is $1,582m, recording an improvement of $175m. Exports rose by 1.3 per cent in seasonally adjusted terms. Imports fell by $83m or 2 per cent in seasonally adjusted terms.

For the seven months to the end of January 1991, compared with the seven months to the end of January 1990, the deficit on current account was down $3,299m or 23 per cent. For the same period, exports rose $2,241m or 8 per cent; imports fell by $1,496m or 5 per cent. Endogenous imports fell $1,964m or 7 per cent. Manufactured exports continued their growth and were up 16 per cent for the same period. In answer to Senator Short, the Treasurer (Mr Keating) believes that the balance of payments figure again indicates that the current account deficit is on track for the Budget forecast of $18 billion. They are the facts.

What we have seen today is the Opposition facing its ninth year in Opposition and with no solutions to the problems that Australia faces. I am very pleased to see that 16 per cent increase in the seven months for manufactured exports. Of course, we are not satisfied with a situation in which 72 per cent of our imports are manufactured goods. Next week the Government will take further steps to build on the plans that it has implemented from the time it came to office in 1983 in the steel, metal and shipbuilding industries and a whole range of other industries. These are quite apart from the broad parameters it has laid down to try to transform industries, whether they are manufacturing or service industries, to make them more efficient and more capable of coping with the changing world that we face.

Major restructuring of industry that this Government has implemented will, in a cooperative way, make sure that with the multi-skilling of our work force and the cooperation of everybody in Australia, we tackle the problems and get a result. Senator Short, who in his previous life worked as an adviser to the Fraser Government, would know the difficulties that the coalition Government had in finding the wherewithal to get cooperation in persuading people to change the way in which they had worked for many years.

This Government, in recent years, has seen a transformation of the work force. Through award restructuring, we have been able to enable people to do things that they would never have done before. This movement to get productivity increases by people working smarter and better is a characteristic of the way Australia will work itself out of the recession.

This has not happened by accident. This Government's policy is to invest in our human capital. When we came to office we realised that too many young people were not continuing their education after year 12. We have taken the retention rate from 33 per cent to 66 per cent. Investment in education and training is a characteristic of this Government.

We are pursuing these problems. I believe that we have policies in place that will enable us to build on eight years of changing the way people work. But it is a slow process. Today the Opposition has not advanced any strategy at all. It has adopted a spoiling approach to this issue and has not addressed many of the problems. It simply cannot stand the fact that the accord system has allowed for not only the reduction of inflation-in rebuttal of what Senator Short has said-but also for laying the basis of further activity.

Reference is made in the matter of public importance to the balance of payments and debt problems. One would think from the way Opposition senators have spoken that this is completely the responsibility of the Government. But Brent Davis, chief economist with the Australian Chamber of Commerce, has pointed out that the current account deficit for January was the result of a soaring interest bill for foreign debt. At the end of December-and these are the most recent figures available-the net external debt was $130.8 billion. Of this, $82 billion, or 62 per cent, was private debt, with $48.8 billion being public debt. I think that needs to be said in view of the fact that a number of speakers have conveyed that this is completely a government problem.

The Opposition referred to micro-economic reform and deregulation of labour movement and if I have time I will come back to those subjects. But it has not told us what its real proposal is for the Australian people. Ordinary people should not be confused by the many figures that have been quoted. They should remember that the basic thrust of the Opposition is to introduce a consumption tax. That is the disaster that the Opposition is promoting-a consumption tax of 15 per cent or 18 per cent. This would mean that medical bills, hair cuts, margarine, luxury yachts and cars, rent, public transport, fares, fruit and vegetables could all be taxed.

Effectively, one would have to pay to eat under a coalition government because so far the Opposition has not indicated that foodstuffs or anything else would be excluded. The Opposition is trying to confuse the issue. At the moment there is a tax levy of 30 per cent on jewellery, furs, cosmetics, gold watches, and things of that type, and 50 per cent on motor vehicles costing more than $48,000. But there is no tax on medical services, shoes, or all the other things that will be subject to the coalition's consumption tax if it were ever to gain the treasury bench. Of course, the secret is that everyone would pay a tax on the ordinary necessities of life but the friends of Dr Hewson and the Opposition would be able to purchase a car worth $97,000 for $77,000. In other words, people at the big end of town would be able to gain $20,000 on this sort of luxury item that seems to condition the thinking of the Opposition.

That is only part of it. Dr Hewson, who is a bit inexperienced, is occasionally inclined, in a very Freudian way, to divulge what the game plan is about. He did so when he was asked about the reduction of company tax. In so many words, he let out the fact that, of course, company tax may be phased down. He said, `Whether we'll actually do it in our first term we will announce in due course'. That is very embarrassing for the Opposition because it indicates that ordinary people who pay the consumption tax will be subsidising reductions in company tax. The Opposition has a secret plan to try to make sure that ordinary people will help the coalition relieve the tax burden on people who are well off.

TALK.START.PARA: —Madam Acting Deputy President, I rise on a point of order. I am not sure whether Senator Childs is aware of it, but the statement he has quoted is inaccurate and has been corrected by Dr Hewson. It is not what Dr Hewson said. That should be recorded.
—Order! There is no point of order.

—I quoted the fact that Dr Hewson has been embarrassed by his admission that this is the way the Opposition is thinking. Of course, he has haggled about the words. But I used the words `a Freudian slip'. Clearly he has haggled about the words. But the reality is that that is the game plan. It hurts the Opposition to be exposed in this way. We know that there is a nexus-a link-between the proposal that company tax be reduced and the intention that ordinary people will have to pay a tax of 15 per cent.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Short had the audacity to make inflation the major point of his speech. Yet, a 15 per cent consumption tax could add 7 percentage points to the level of inflation. This would be a very serious situation as far as the Australian economy is concerned. So, the issue of a consumption tax has direct relevance to this debate.

But it is even worse than that because the Liberal and National parties have very close links with the United Kingdom. Indeed, this idea of a consumption tax is in many ways based on the Thatcher model. Thatcher and that other `Major' problem in the United Kingdom were concerned with the introduction and the extension of a consumption tax in England. The important thing here is that the Conservative Government in the United Kingdom has a balance of payments deficit of significant proportions. Even with all the North Sea oil and a consumption tax, the Government of the United Kingdom continues to have a massive deficit. The situation is that in one country that is very close to us-the United Kingdom-the consumption tax has been a tremendous impost on ordinary people.

I now turn to some of the things Senator Short said, which indicate the view of the Opposition. He said that there was the problem of the rigidity of the labour market. Senator Short wants the deregulation of the labour market, and he was supported in this by Senator Bishop. Senator Short then said that the accord had caused a high inflationary floor under the economy. If one adds to that the views of his colleague Mr Howard, who wants to abolish leave loading and wants people to work lengthy hours, one can see that between them members of the Opposition want to turn the clock back because there is no way one can have the cooperation of people if one poses something so unfair as the proposed deregulation of the labour market.

In brief, one can say that the Opposition is proposing that employers in every enterprise will have access to the lawyers and the economists and all those in the employer associations. The Opposition proposes to cut off ordinary people in an enterprise from their union. It is as simple as that; it is designed to give an uneconomic and unfair advantage to employers. In a recession the idea of doing that is to give capital an advantage over employees in such a situation.

For that reason, it will not be accepted by ordinary people because they will see that it is unfair and will not give them the security and confidence this Government has through the accord to make sure that people share fairly burdens and advantages and, at the same time, have the training and the education to be able to work smarter and so improve the productivity of this country.

DEBATE.TITLE: DRIED VINE FRUITS LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator Cook) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen The Hon P.F.S.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of the Bill is, first, to extend the sultana underwriting scheme by three years and, second, to remove statutory backing for domestic consumer transfers on the sale of dried vine fruit through the removal of the domestic component of statutory equalization.

The Bill forms part of the Government's response to the Industries Assistance Commission's report into the dried vine fruits industry. The other part is contained in the Australian Horticultural Corporation Amendment Bill.
The sultana underwriting scheme was implemented in the early 1980s in response to low world prices of sultanas. This in turn was the result of an over-supply of sultanas on world markets.
The scheme was triggered in its first year of operation and $1.3 million was paid out to producers. This amounted to about $16 per tonne. There have been no pay outs since that time.

In 1986 the basis of the scheme was changed to reduce the level at which the Government would underwrite returns. The level was set at 80 per cent of the average ``Free on Board'' export return for the past three years. As well, a sunset clause was included so that the scheme would terminate on 31 December 1990. This move reflected the Government's view that, where possible, industry should take increasing responsibility for risk management and for responding to the vagaries of the marketplace.

In the context of the current changes to the level of government involvement in other areas of the dried vine fruits industry and the Government's concern to minimise the impact of these changes, the Government is prepared to extend the underwriting scheme for a period of three years.
In doing so, the Government is also taking into account the very regionalised nature of the dried vine fruits industry and concentrated effect on the regions that any impact could have.
I turn now to the second purpose of the Bill, that concerning equalization arrangements.

In each year when domestic returns of dried vine fruit exceed export returns, and this has been the case in 26 of the past 30 years, the domestic consumer effectively subsidises dried vine fruit exports through the operation of the equalization arrangements. In the 1985 year, for example, the Industries Assistance Commission reported this transfer amounted to some $13 million.

This is not the only effect of equalization. As well, it has the effect of masking market signals to producers. A higher than actual return paid to a producer can result in poor production decisions and the misallocation of valuable resources.

The Government has acted in the past to reduce this masking effect by putting a cap on the equalization payment that could be made over and above the average export return. This was implemented through legislative amendment in 1986 and equalization payments are now limited to 15 per cent above average export returns.
Nonetheless, the Government remains of the view that domestic transfers should cease and this can be achieved by removal of the domestic component of the equalization arrangements.

Equalization of export returns are set to continue and will take the form of a reconciliation of exporter returns after the end of each season. There will be no requirement for levy arrangements under equalization of export returns.
The continuation of the sultana underwriting scheme continues the Commonwealth's liability to payment in the event that the scheme is triggered.
The proposed changes to the equalization arrangements will result in the removal of the equalization levy and the removal of all financial involvement by the Commonwealth.
I commend the Bill to Honourable Senators and I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.

In respect of the annual report for 1989-90, I wish to refer to that portion of the report at page 13 under the heading `Design Integrity' where the Chairman of the Parliament House Construction Authority comments that the Authority, through the architect:
. . . has provided the nation with the building called for in the User Requirement Statement approved by Parliament.

I think it is worth reminding people of that fact. Criticisms are made of this building from time to time but, in my view, the architects have built the building that they were asked to build. The user requirement statement was settled long before I became a member of the Parliament; I think it was 1979 or there- abouts that that was the case. The report goes on to refer to the design competition and some of the criteria against which the winning design was judged.

The report refers to the fact that use of the building will inevitably mean that some changes will be required; technology changes alone will determine that there will be modifications to the way in which the building operates. The Authority recognises, as it says in the report, that there will be a continuing need to modify and update facilities to see that the building functions into the future to meet the needs of those who use it. With this in mind, there was an agreement with the Executive Government to a proposal that came from the Authority to establish an advisory panel to monitor and advise on proposed changes to the building. We all recognise that there will be significant changes to the building as the years pass. I also feel quite strongly that the basic design integrity of the building should be maintained-perhaps not at all costs, but certainly to the greatest extent possible.

There was a proposal that a significant group be established, of eight members, chaired by an eminent former member of the Parliament to advise on changes to the building. Without wishing to incur the wrath of the Senate, I refer to a matter that is on the Notice Paper-the notice of motion given by Senator Bolkus to establish the Parliament House Advisory Panel, which is referred to in this report. The Authority says that it considers the establishment of the advisory panel to be a vital step in ensuring that the integrity of the design is protected for future generations.

My reason for raising this matter today is that there is a proposal before the Senate which would establish a panel consisting of eight members and this goes on in a number of paragraphs to indicate what they would do and how they would operate. My disappointment with the proposal before us and the reason that I personally would vigorously oppose it in its present form is that, of the eight members appointed, seven are to be appointed by the Government and one by the Opposition. I do not regard that as a bipartisan approach to something that is as important as maintaining the integrity of this building. I am opposed to the panel being established at all if that is the way in which it is to be done. It is a great pity indeed that the matter should be put in that fashion. I also feel that appointments from the Senate are not in adequate proportion. That perhaps is the lesser of the two criticisms that I would have about the panel itself.

The President can appoint somebody to represent him and one other, the Speaker can appoint someone to represent him and one other, the relevant Minister can appoint a representative and one other, and the Leader of the Opposition can make an appointment to represent him. I concede that under item (E) the chairman, who is to be an eminent member or former member of either House, will be appointed by the President and Speaker after consultation with the Minister and the Leader of the Opposition. The consultation process is not entirely balanced, but even if one concedes that one, it is still six to be appointed by government and one by the Opposition. Now or into the future that is not the way it should be. This matter is before us. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bell Sen R.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —by leave-I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the document.

In the Chairman's summary at the beginning of the annual report of the Dried Fruits Research Council 1989-90, we are told that in 1990-91 the annual research and development program will total $1.1m. This money is raised by levies, which last year were $4.50 per tonne for dried fruit, $10.25 a tonne for dried tree fruit, and $11.00 a tonne for prunes. It is important to note from the report that new projects supported by the Council were in such areas as irrigation and water quality, trellis systems, dehydration technology and reduced reliance on chemicals and practical engineering developments for the dried tree fruit industry.

These are all matters which make the Australian dried fruit industry superior to its international competitors. They are typical of the very matters which the Australian community as a whole expects, and rightly so, our primary industries to be concerned with. These are the very matters which add to our costs of production, but similar costs are not necessarily borne by our international competitors. When consumers in Australia ask, `Why is the produce of country X less expensive than our produce?', the answer is that our producers have accepted the responsibility of meeting the cost of research and improvement in production methods. Our society places other responsibilities on our primary producers. We expect our primary producers to pay Australian award wages and to pay all the add-on costs of employment, whether they be in the form of holiday pay, sick pay, payroll tax or the penalty rates that apply to shift workers. We also expect our primary producers to pay excises and tariffs on imported equipment, fuel and energy taxes, land taxes and income taxes. They support not only the primary producers themselves, but all members of our society for the benefit of our society.

We all see the maintenance of those aspects of the Australian standard of living as fundamental and beyond compromise. Because the industry has accepted those responsibilities, we believe that the whole of society should similarly accept the responsibility of applying a penalty to imports that is equivalent to the total production costs which Australian producers bear. They bear this as part of the social costs. This should not be impos- sible to calculate and should not only provide benefits to Australian producers and consumers if it is applied, but also encourage foreign competitors to attempt to improve their growing practices, as we are told in the report that the dried fruit industry does. If by the application of such a penalty to imports we can encourage this, we will be improving research and employment practices throughout the world.

I think it is important to consider all these things together because they are interconnected; they are not separate. It is not helpful, nor is it wise, to see the research funding aspect as separate-as being only the business of the dried fruit producers. Even when we look at a few of the areas that the Council considers as priorities, we see the opportunity for considerable community benefit. The report refers to some of the areas that are seen as priority areas for the Council in terms of research. We see that priority is given to improved farm weed control in pro- cessing technology to eliminate weed seed contaminations. Another priority is the development of production and processing systems to reduce reliance on the use of chemicals, particularly the fumigant methyl bromide. We see that another priority is the development of new fruit maturity standards. All these priorities have socially beneficial effects.

DEBATE.TITLE: CRIMES (INVESTIGATION OF COMMONWEALTH OFFENCES) AMENDMENT BILL 1990

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are discussing the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Bill 1990. To date, it has been an interesting debate. Of course, there has been reference to the fact that there has been a reversal of decision by the Government as to the particular matter that I wish to address; that is, the pre-charge detention procedures.

SPEECH.PARA: Prior to the change of Attorney-General, it seemed that the previous Attorney-General would regard `reasonable time' as the appropriate wording for this, and the new Attorney-General has limited it to a period of four hours. That has been referred to in the debate. I do not think that any of us quite understand why there was this change. But I found it reassuring that when Senator Cooney addressed the matter he said that he does not have a fixed mind on it. As he is Chairman of the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs, I was pleased to hear that.

As honourable senators know, after the second reading this Bill is to be referred to that Committee to look into that matter, in particular, and the other matters which Senator Spindler raised when he spoke. So the fact that Senator Cooney does have an open mind on this issue is important. There are aspects of it to be discussed most seriously.

The Bill makes provision for the introduction of a fixed pre-charge custodial period in relation to Commonwealth offences. There are a number of other matters in the Bill which I shall not be dealing with and which are not opposed, but this is the one which I think most of us are opposing and feel quite strongly about. It makes a number of procedural safeguards in other areas relating to the rights of arrested persons. It was introduced on 15 November 1990. As I said, I support the basic principles underlying the Bill, as it seeks to provide checks and balances in the area of pre-charge detention. Tonight I will specifically deal with that section.

The Bill makes provision for fixed pre-charge custodial periods for persons arrested in relation to Commonwealth offences, subject to the qualification that the period shall be what is considered reasonable for the individual case; such as periods not to exceed two hours for persons under the age of 18 years or for Aboriginal persons or Torres Strait Islanders and four hours in any other case. The Australian Democrats have suggested that the exclusion that I referred to for persons under the age of 18 years or Aboriginal persons should be extended to include those of diminished responsibility, those not fluent in English or those who are illiterate, so that the two-hour period would apply to all those as well.

I found it somewhat intriguing that Senator Spindler and the Australian Democrats are not prepared to allow police to determine what is reasonable as regards the time of questioning, but they are prepared to leave in the hands of police the determination as to whether or not the person in custody is of diminished responsibility, not fluent in English or illiterate. It is not always easy to determine who is illiterate. People who are illiterate develop extraordinary skills at hiding that fact. A person may not appear to be fluent in English or may appear to be fluent in English and in fact not have a great comprehension, or in fact have a great comprehension but not speak fluently.

Who can determine a person of diminished responsibility among our fellow men or women? From time to time we might look at someone and wonder. We might feel certain, but we cannot be certain of that. Yet the Democrats would wish upon us amendments which seek to incorporate those exclusions and allow the police to make that decision. At the same time they say that a police officer is not competent to determine what is a reasonable time within which to question somebody. I really found it hard to follow the arguments that they were advancing. I do not believe that they can have it both ways.

The Bill goes on to say that the relevant period-that is, the four hours which has been referred to-may be extended to an additional eight hours upon application to a magistrate. Senator Tambling, when he addressed the Bill, listed the difficulties that arose in determining whether four hours was a reasonable time or not and all the circumstances which go to limiting the value of that period. In my opinion, the four hour time limit will cause great problems in the policing and enforcement of justice, especially in the more serious and complex cases. I think that the fixed time limit benefits the more serious criminals and white collar criminals where a long interview is not only the norm but is absolutely unavoidable.

The interim report of the review of Commonwealth law which dealt with detention before charge was of the clear opinion that the law should provide police officers, and others whose duty it is to investigate criminal offences, with a reasonable opportunity to interrogate an arrested person. I believe that few would disagree with that principle. The same review committee admitted-I refer to page 33 of the report-that the difficult question is whether the legislation should provide that an arrested person may be detained for a specific period or for a reasonable time.

The discussion today addresses whether it should be a specific period or a reasonable time. Any discussion of this issue must attempt to strike a reasonable balance between the necessities of law enforcement and the protection of the individual, to provide a balance between combating the sophistication and the money of much of today's criminal activity while at the same time tying the hands of the investigators and, having done so, then criticising the police for failing to obtain the outcomes that one thinks ought to be obtained. I would say that in many instances eight hours is a very short period. I regard four hours as absolutely ludicrous.

The review of Commonwealth law, which I have quoted, goes through the advantages of fixed periods for pre-charge detention, and they are listed. I want to refer to them because I think it is necessary that they are looked at as there is merit in some of them. They are as follows:
1. Such provisions provide the arrested person with a clear and sure protection against unduly prolonged detention.
2. They render certain the power of the police to detain an arrested person for questioning.
3. There is clarity and certainty as to the rights and obligations of all participants in the investigative process.
4. They are likely to reduce the necessity to hold a voir dire for the purpose of determining whether a confession was illegally obtained.
I interpose to say that I think one other aspect of the Bill which provides for recording overcomes that problem.

I want to refer to the Victorian Government's experience which I think is relevant. In 1983 concern that evidence was being rejected on the ground that it was obtained during a period of unlawful detention led the Victorian Government to appoint a committee to make recommendations for appropriate changes. As a result of the recommendations of that committee, the Victorian Parliament in 1984 amended the Victorian Crimes Act to provide for a prescribed period of detention, usually six hours, immediately after the person was taken into custody.

I think Senator Spindler gave figures in his speech of the number of hours people were held in custody. It is a fact, as he said, that the committee found that 99.5 per cent of all interrogations had been completed within six hours. I had difficulty following his logic. He said that that being the case there should be a fixed period. It seems to me it would support the reverse. In the period he was referring to, I think he said that only 10 people had been interrogated for 18 hours or more. That again leads me to the conclusion that there ought not to be a fixed period.

I think the disadvantages of the fixed term period are quite apparent, especially when we look at the area in which the Commonwealth is operating. The six-hour period might well be inadequate in the case of complex investigations or multiple offences. Certainty is achieved, but at the expense of flexibility and practical efficiency. This is particularly relevant in the most serious cases, such as the illegal importation of drugs and complex conspiracies. The necessity to apply to extend the period tended to disrupt the continuity of the investigation. Practically, in some cases a justice or magistrate may not be available, especially in country areas, within the time fixed for charging or making application for an extension of the period of detention. There was a risk that the upper limit could come to be regarded as the norm-this has been mentioned in the debate-and that an arrested person might accordingly be detained for the maximum period, although that period was not necessary for the purposes of the investigation. Given the figure quoted in the Victorian review that 99.5 per cent of all interrogations were completed within the six hours-and six hours was the relevant time then in Victoria-I think there is a high probability of finding that in most of those cases the length of time a person was detained would, in fact, be far longer than it ought to be. That should be avoided.

The Victorian committee concluded that the prescription of a fixed period was too inflexible and recommended that instead the police should be required to take an arrested person before a justice within a reasonable time. The courts will decide that in accordance with the common law. They decide many other things which are far more complex than this. I really fail to see why the Commonwealth is embarking on this path when I think the balance of evidence is that it has been tried and failed. Somehow we have to reinvent the wheel, and if it should happen to go through the Senate, I have no doubt that we will be spending time debating it again in a few years when we too seek to abandon it and get back to what is reasonable. It enables the courts to determine the issue and the case may be thrown out. That is the way it should be. In 1984 the Victorian Parliament abandoned it only 12 months or so after the initial six hours was put in. The Premier, Mr Cain, described the change as a `victory for commonsense'. Why do we not adopt commonsense right now in this debate?

This is not an easy issue. The High Court's decision in the Williams case in 1986 has been referred to. There must be proper safeguards; nobody is suggesting that it should be otherwise. The person in custody must be protected. Any person must be free from arbitrary arrest, open-ended detention and unlawful and unfair treatment. It is my opinion that the effectiveness and efficiency of federal law enforcement and the discharge of justice should not be put at risk for the sake of what I see is ultimately an arbitrary time limit on pre-charge detention.

As I said, this Bill introduces the recording of evidence. I think the warning that is given to somebody should be recorded; it should be apparent as to what occurred at that point in time in an interrogation and any confessions should be on tape. This modern technology is available and should be used.

The imposition of a time constraint as a four-hour limit is totally impractical. It is likely to impede the course of justice and is totally against the public interest. Even if a concept of a fixed time is regarded as reasonable-and I suggest that it is not-and it is in the public interest, four hours is ludicrous. Six hours was found to be insufficient in Victoria in some of the cases that have been referred to. Most of them are less than that. One could ask the question: why are we dealing with it at all if 99.5 per cent of cases take less than that period of time? The United States of America and Scotland have adopted six hours, and the United Kingdom and Canada have longer periods.

The Federal policing arena involves a high percentage of complex and advanced investigations; more so, I think, than many of the areas of State policing. The Federal Government's efforts-which should be encouraged-to eliminate organised crime and drug trafficking frequently involve investigations that are complex and critical. I find it remarkable that in this day and age, when we set up things like the National Crime Authority and we keep saying we want to wipe out organised crime and get rid of drug trafficking, we are pursuing a course here that is deliberately designed to inhibit the police in the operation of the work they are doing. We have the Victorian experience in front of us that flexibility in the length of interview is absolutely essential in solving complex and multiple crimes.

The courts already exercise jurisdiction in many areas of the law. Judges are exercising their discretion on a daily basis. Judges and magistrates are experienced in making judgments of what is reasonable, and there are provisions for appeals against decisions. I believe that is adequate protection. There is no good reason why precedent and discretion with reference to the circumstances surrounding the investigation should not regulate reasonableness in this case. The courts are very vigilant, I believe, in ensuring that the slightest impropriety in the conduct of a police interview with an accused leads to the rejection of that interview as evidence.

The real issue comes back to whether the evidence and confessional material obtained during that period in custody is obtained voluntarily and fairly and without illegal conduct on the part of the police, and time really has nothing to do with it.

This Bill incorporates several procedural safeguards that appear to me to be very adequate in protecting the civil liberties of those being investigated and questioned. Some, learned from the Victorian experience, relate to rights of communication, the right to silence, the voluntariness rules of admissibility of confessional material, cautioning, tape recording and dead time, and I support these wholeheartedly. For example, sound and video recording of police interviews is a sensible and long awaited protection for the police, the interviewee and the victim. It provides a mechanism for ensuring the total propriety of the interrogation process.

It is my contention that the safeguards built into this Bill are more than adequate to protect the individual and to enable a reasonable balance to be struck between the requirements of law enforcement agencies and the need to protect civil liberties, without the need for a fixed time, pre-charge detention period, and certainly a fixed pre-charge detention period as short as four hours.

I hope the Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs (Senator Tate), like Senator Cooney, has an open mind on this and that the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs can go into this question of the pre-charge detention period in some depth and come back to the Senate with a solution. I would be reluctant to have to support six or eight hours as a fixed period. Four, as I said, is absurd. I think the sensible and reasonable thing is to leave it as a reasonable time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Tate Sen The Hon M.C.

TALKER.NAME: Senator TATE
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Justice and Consumer Affairs)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank those honourable senators who have contributed to this important second reading debate on the Crimes (Investigation of Commonwealth Offences) Amendment Bill 1990. The chamber and the Parliament are faced with a dilemma which the Attorney-General (Mr Duffy) has obviously faced. We need to make a choice as to how to balance two competing matters of great concern to the Attorney-General, as first law officer of the Crown, and to this chamber and the Parliament generally. We need to find a balance between, on the one hand, the civil liberties which we have inherited through the centuries in common law such as protects the individual against undue intimidatory tactics employed by those investigating offences in our community on behalf of the public and, on the other hand, the responsibility to ensure that laws are enforced, and that obviously requires vesting certain persons in our society with a real, effective capacity to undertake such investigations.

SPEECH.PARA: It is very hard to get that balance right. I must say that over the centuries the common law itself has maintained the same principles, adages or slogans, but has not always kept up with the fact that the structures of law enforcement have changed. There was a time in the early history of common law when the magistrate had a more inquisitorial function and actually asked questions concerning a person who was brought before the magistrate. In other words, there was an opportunity for the magistrate to actually carry out some questioning of the suspected offender.

That is no longer the case. The rule that the High Court of Australia reaffirmed in the Williams case was that no questioning could be safely undertaken by police officers of a person whom they had arrested until the person was brought before a magistrate within a reasonable time-at the first practicable opportunity, in fact.

Previously, it had been taken for granted that an arrested suspect, or a person who was aiding the police with their inquiries, could be questioned about an offence in the course of deciding upon what charges should be laid before taking him or her before a magistrate. The High Court in the Williams case threw that particular practice into relief against what was said to be common law principles which ought to apply. This is what has given rise to the dilemma. Parliaments around the Commonwealth have been faced with trying to get the balance right between the liberties of the subject and the need to have a practical means of investigating the possible commission of a crime, and the laying of relevant charges in relation to that criminal activity.

The jurisdictions have asked committees of great eminence to review the difficulty. For example, the Gibbs Review of Commonwealth Criminal Law, under the former Chief Justice of the High Court of Australia, formed the clear opinion that the law should provide investigating officers with a reasonable opportunity to interrogate an arrested person and conduct other necessary investigations before taking the arrested person before a magistrate. It was recognised that the questioning of suspected persons is not, in itself, an evil thing or something which is inherently wrong, so long as there is no compulsion to answer questions; that there be no unfair or oppressive means of questioning; and that there are good reasons-that it is a necessary part of the law enforcement-why questioning be undertaken before a charge is laid.

Provided there are certain remedies or precautionary safeguards to ensure that the risks associated with that period of pre-charge detention do not come to reality, then I believe that the Parliament can provide a regime where civil liberties and law enforcement methods can be properly balanced, and that is what this legislation attempts to do.

It is important to emphasise that nothing in this proposed legislation tries to give any extra powers to police to detain involuntarily somebody who is not under arrest. I do not want any confusion in this regard: there is no attempt in this legislation to say that the police can hold somebody against that person's will where the police officer has not formed a reasonable apprehension that an offence has been committed by that person such as would justify an arrest. This Bill does not seek to enable the police somehow to detain somebody against his will and question that person even though he has not been arrested. That is certainly not the case. There is no extension of the powers of arrest. The right to refuse to participate in any such questioning is not affected at all.

What the Government and the Attorney have considered as appropriate is that there be a strictly defined reasonable investigation period within a specified maximum period of permissible pre-charge detention and that even within the maximum period of four hours, which is the initial and, perhaps, one hopes the normal, usual and permissible precharge detention time, the time has to be spent in the proper and relevant questioning of the person concerned. It may be that only one or two hours questioning is reasonable. It is a maximum within which the police, in asking their questions, have to act reasonably.

But four hours is an initial maximum and can be inflated by the recognition of what is called dead time. This was not the case in the initial Victorian legislation. The framework which the Victorians initially put into place had a fixed time regime which did not have the flexibility that has been built into this proposal. For example, dead time refers to those periods of time which it is considered appropriate to exclude from the calculation of the investigation period, as they are all periods when investigation should not, in fairness, take place. They include direct travel time to the police station; time arranging communication with family, friend or lawyer; and time spent waiting for the attendance of a lawyer or prisoner's friend. One can see that in fact, for various reasons, the maximum four hours of investigation time might not be reached for some six hours after the person is detained by the police.

In addition, it is quite clear that by application to a magistrate in appropriate circumstances, which are spelt out, the period of pre-charge investigation questioning can be extended to eight hours. Further questioning up to a maximum of eight hours is permitted. So I believe that there is a degree of flexibility built into this proposal, which is useful from the point of view of the police and also, in having that in-built requirement of reasonableness, protects the interests of the person who has at that stage not been charged.

I believe that the Attorney-General has struck a reasonable balance in providing for a specified maximum time, which, of course, differs from the Opposition's preference for an open-ended reasonable time. Greater certainty is provided for the accused-if that is the exact expression; perhaps the person voluntarily assisting the police would be a better term-the legal representatives of that person and, of course, the police. The police themselves do not have to guess what a court might determine was or was not a reasonable time for pre-charge detention.

The dead time provisions overcome most problems of the lack of flexibility complained of regarding the Victorian fixed time limit provision, where there was no allowance for dead time. I believe that the admissibility of confessions and so on will be made more certain. With objective compliance with these conditions, a clear regime will be in place. I believe that there are plenty of means-for example, in regard to extensions of time in remote areas, telephone or other electronic means are to be permitted-to make these provisions work well.

Some other matters have been brought up during the second reading debate, particularly concerning the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander issue. It is well known that the Bill includes the provision that for young persons, Aboriginal persons and Torres Strait Islanders, the permissible maximum period of pre-charge detention will be two hours with an eight-hour extension, of course, able to be granted by a magistrate. I guess, at first glance it could be thought to be paternalistic or discriminatory. To a certain extent it certainly is discriminatory. But we are all aware that the setting up of the Royal Commission into Aboriginal Deaths in Custody has particularly highlighted the risks associated with the initial period in custody; not the prison custody of a person convicted of an offence or even on some sort of formal remand, but the detention period, the initial period, in the police cells or where a person is being held before a charge is made or even before arrest.

The public sittings and investigations of the Australian Law Reform Commission, particularly in Alice Springs and Darwin, revealed that in frequent cases bail was not even contemplated until the morning following an arrest of Aboriginal persons in the Northern Territory; and that the Aboriginal and Torres Strait Islander people, who have a disproportionate contact with the criminal justice system, need to be protected because of their vulnerability to the abuse of power to overbear them and to hold them in pre-charge detention for long periods. The provision for young persons is self-explanatory and would not cause great concern.

Perhaps one of the more interesting parts of the Bill- certainly a very positive part and one which I am very happy that the Government found funds to underpin during the budgetary processes-is the provision which requires video taping or audio taping of the questioning undertaken during this pre-charge detention period. This is absolutely fundamental and will turn out to be a great advance, both for civil liberties and for law enforcement here in Australia, in relation to the investigation of Commonwealth offences.

As a result of the structure of the Bill which is before the Senate, if a person who is in custody for a Commonwealth offence makes a confession or admission to an investigating official, the confession or admission is inadmissible as evidence against the person in proceedings for any Commonwealth offence unless the confession or admission was made in circumstances where it was reasonably practicable to tape record the confession or admission, and the questioning of the person and anything said by the person during the questioning was tape recorded.

There are other provisions but basically that is the central policy objective of this part of the Bill-that a confession or admission will be inadmissible unless it was tape recorded during the time of pre-charge questioning. That is a very important protection for the person engaging in the questioning session. It will also lead to a situation where confessions and admissions will be more easily brought into evidence in the proceedings of a criminal trial. It will save a lot of time where baseless allegations are made against police officers that `they verballed me'.

The evidence will be there from the beginning of the process of questioning where proper warnings will have to be recorded on the tape through to the end of the interview. The particular recording equipment will be of such a type that any interference with or break in the continuity of the recording session will immediately be apparent. This will be an extremely important protection which goes hand in hand with the permission which this Parliament would be giving to allow for questioning during this period of pre-charge detention.

The High Court held that a confession obtained during this period, however voluntary, could be held to be inadmissible. I believe that, if the Parliament is to override that ruling of the High Court, amongst all the other protections in the statute, the tape-recording of confessions and admissions amounts to the most important and, I hope, effective protection of all.

The Bill does try to strike the right balance. I believe that we could all argue about whether the first Victorian proposal should be the one that is adopted, whether it should be the proposal that now commends itself to the Victorian Parliament or whether the period of initial maximum pre-charge detention should be four hours or six hours as the Gibbs Committee has recommended that it might be. These are all matters which are legitimate for discussion and debate. The Government has decided on the model of a maximum period with all the flexibility built into it through the provision of dead time and with the period of questioning having to be reasonable within the maximum limit. I believe that within that model there may still be room for argument about four hours, five hours, six hours, and so on.

To answer Senator Reid, the Standing Committee on Legal and Constitutional Affairs will receive this Bill for consideration, and I believe that that will be a very fruitful review by that Committee. I do not believe that there will by any means be a blunt approach by either side. I hope that it will be a very useful Committee discussion. I look forward to the committee stage of the Bill. At the moment I thank all honourable senators from the Opposition and the Australian Democrats who have indicated their support for the second reading of the Bill, and I commend the motion to the chamber.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time.
