SPEECH.SPEAKER: Archer Sen B.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —In speaking to the Insurance Amendment Bill 1990, I shall make a few comments about insurance generally because insurance has now become a very essential part of life. Insurance is the sharing of risks in whole or in part. There is not much that can now be done in business of any sort where insurance is not necessary and required. Of course, insurance is broken into two fairly even parts: one is safeguarding the present and the other is safeguarding the future.

SPEECH.PARA: But insurance involves money and wherever money is involved, crime automatically follows or goes hand in hand. I do not mean that it is only the public who are to blame because in many cases the companies themselves fail to present their case and their cause in a reasonable and just manner. Some sell very poor cover and sell it very badly but the vast majority of companies and offices are first class and most responsible.

It has always been my experience that there are far too many misunderstandings in insurance. Too many people do not know; do not remember; are not told of some of the intricacies of the policies at the time they are taking out insurance; have problems with the terminology used; do not know what they get with fire insurance; do not know the difference between householders insurance and comprehensive insurance; hear people quoting what they have been paid by way of a loss, and so on.

In business we have matters such as excess clauses and certain policies are subject to average. There is also the question of storm and tempest cover, which has been very widely commented on this year and the difficulty that arises is whether it includes or excludes flood and matters such as this. It really does require not only the companies but also the people insured to be more careful about the class of insurance taken out and exactly what is covered. People should read their insurance policies. They should know what they are covered for and they should know what the exclusions are.

Car insurance is now almost universal and has become a very big business on its own. That is largely because car stealing has become such a huge business, such a major crime, in most cities. We are now told that, amongst the car stealing fraternity, people only have to say the make, the model and the colour of the car wanted and those involved in car stealing will get it. We are also in an age of court decisions regarding professional negligence, accident and injury, and third party. These judgments now being handed down are making insurance very expensive and very difficult to get. This is changing the whole question of liability very much indeed. It is now becoming necessary for people to spend more and more of the money that they would otherwise use in other household or business ways on keeping themselves in line with the law.

Insurance provides backing for loans and mortgages, whether in business, in housing or whatever. An insurance policy, such as life insurance cover, provides security when people want to get a mortgage on a building or other type of loan. A fire insurance policy is also necessary. It is possible to borrow 90 per cent, or even 100 per cent, provided people have the mortgage insured. But the losses that are now accruing in insurance generally are tremendous.

I was looking at the annual report of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission in this regard. On page 116 of this year's annual report I noted that the premiums paid for fire and general insurance to 1989 amounted to $12,293m for the year. An enormous amount of money is now being paid for insurance. Many of these claims involve the crime of arson, which is generally regarded as being the easiest crime to commit and to get away with. It makes our insurance very expensive. I remember a few years ago being told that insurance premiums for fire insurance could be halved were it not for arson.

That is an enormous amount to keep in mind. Currently the estimates are something between $200m and $800m a year. The crime of arson has inadequate resources devoted to it. It requires a lot more attention and a lot more policing, but it is just not possible to provide those facilities.

Of course, it then comes back to what is now referred to as the `bottom line' in business. Page 120 of the Insurance and Superannuation Commission report shows the deficits for all classes of insurance for the last five years: $569m for 1985; $800m for 1986; $717m for 1987; $583m for 1988; and $687m for 1989. To eliminate even those is again going to require a great increase in premiums.

At present the losses are being covered by insurance company investments, not by premiums. Of course, the biggest items in those losses are not the traditional fire covers, but motor vehicle insurance and employers' liability. In the year of this report, 1989, there was a loss on motor vehicle insurance of $270m and a loss on employers' liability of $111m. So it goes on. We have to be able to cover those things. They have to be paid for. The attitude that it does not matter if one cheats a little because it is only an insurance company, I am afraid, has become far too common in our community.

It is also, of course, far too easy for a business that has become unprofitable or premises that have become obsolete to have one of those unfortunate fires. Recently studies have been done by the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation and others of the commencement of fires, with a view to trying to cope with more of these criminal acts. The research has improved, but we still need a lot more.

When we get around to insuring the future, we are talking about life insurance and superannuation. Again these are very big figures; it is a vast business. Page 91 of the report shows that the new business written, that is, the amount insured for the particular year, was $108 billion. That is going to mature some time in the future and require to be paid out, but it is growing at a very fast rate. That showed an increase of 23.5 per cent on the year before, which was again 24.1 per cent up on the year before that. People have become very conscious of insurance and superannuation and are putting a lot of money into them now, and quite reasonably so.

At present the assets are in the order of $90 billion, but the money that is there is a matter of some concern to many people. All sorts of people, all sorts of organisations, governments and so on look at this money and work out how they can get their hands on it or how they can influence its expenditure. It is a bit worrying that there are so many people thinking about it because sooner or later somebody is going to try to get their hands on it to see how they can wheedle it away for some other purpose.

This is the money that is going to largely determine Australia's future. How these huge amounts of money are going to be invested and the responsibility that that places on management to see that they are reasonably placed is important. Placed wrongly, of course, we will start to get a lot of investment and development distortion. Placed correctly, it can look after the future of Australia for the next century or so.

I have seen many companies and businesses that have been in a make or break situation, depending on what the insurance companies have done with their assets. I am not saying whether it was made or broken, but we have only to take the case of Ansett Transport Industries. It got sold because the AMP Society decided to cash its shares. I do not think that these big owners of shares, particularly the life insurance companies, take enough responsibility for the shareholdings they own. I believe that they move in and out of the market with little responsibility; they do not get seats on boards, even when they get up to holding approximately 20 per cent of the shares. When they should be involved, they do not do it. I believe that companies which are going to have such an effect on the market should be more responsible.

Insurance companies and superannuation funds quite often appear to me to have the impression that the whole purpose of insurance is the perpetuation of the company and of the staff and directors that run with it. It is not. The interests of the policy holder have got to be the prime consideration. I guess that if we all stopped for a moment it would not take as long to think of those sorts of companies that we know only too well, where perpetuation of the staff seems to be what it is all about. That is a most important issue, and I think it needs to be watched very carefully.

There is one other example: I notice that the ICA Bulletin for February 1990 gave a run-down of the decade of the 1980s. To give the Senate an idea of the sort of work that insurance does, it covered year by year the major disasters that caused insurance so much difficulty. In every year of the 1980s cyclones, floods and bush fires took their toll, with a total insurance bill exceeding $2.2 billion for the decade. In the past decade, average daily pay-outs in respect of natural disasters increased from an estimated $11m every working day in 1980 to $27m per day in 1989.

Two months into the decade Cyclone Dean whipped through the Pilbara, causing $38.7m damage. Fire destroyed 25 homes and 75 farms in the Adelaide hills-$25.2m. At the end of the year Brighton, Queensland, left insurers to pick up a bill for $28.5m. Floods and storms in Dalby, Queensland, three months later cost $38.7m. Ash Wednesday in February 1983 cost insurance a total of $253m. Heavy rain in the eastern suburbs of Sydney, New South Wales, in November 1984 caused damage worth $103.3m. During 1985 more bush fires in Victoria and South Australia and violent storms in Brisbane and Melbourne took their toll-$257m. In 1985 hail storms in Brisbane were the worst that Queensland had experienced for years-$216m. Cyclone Winifred crossed the north Queensland coast near Innisfail in February 1986-$50m. Extraordinary rain and hail caused $125.8m worth of damage in Sydney's western suburbs in October 1986. Victoria's freak storms in November saw many roofs blown off-$9.6m. Heavy rains whipped across Queensland and New South Wales and caused more than $11m worth of damage in Alice Springs, Northern Territory, during April 1988. Weeks of rain left a total damages bill of more than $47.8m.

The following month the tail end of Cyclone Herbie caused $22m damage. Later that year, the north-western coast of Western Australia experienced severe storms causing $8.6m damage. In November, wild winds battered Melbourne, causing $11.8m damage. In April 1989 a cyclone struck the Queensland coast at Alva Beach near Ayr, causing $27m worth of damage. Australia was relatively disaster-free for seven months until November 1989 when hailstorms and heavy rains caused more than $30m damage in Ballarat, Moe, the Melbourne suburbs, Sydney and Brisbane. The decade ended on a disastrous note: on 28 December 1989 Newcastle experienced a devastating earthquake with damage worth over $600m.

This is what insurance is all about. This is why people require insurance. Even though we are dealing with only a small piece of legislation tonight, it is important. The Bill seeks to amend the Insurance Act 1973. I believe it is quite a good, concise Act. I think the Act is in good order and condition, but I understand that a full replacement is contemplated. However, the legislation before us tonight relates only to section 37 of the Act. Section 37 provides for a monetary limit up to which a small insurer may collect premiums without the necessity for a full reporting which the Act otherwise requires. The limit on this amount of premium income is currently set at $500,000, having been raised from $200,000 in 1984. It is now proposed to raise this amount to $750,000 and in due course to permit the limit to be adjusted by regulation. I have a preference that these sorts of issues should be dealt with in legislation and be subject to parliamentary consideration whenever changes are proposed. However, the Opposition will not oppose the proposal on this occasion. We support the Bill.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate is debating the Insurance Amendment Bill 1990. The Insurance Act 1973 regulates the non-life insurance industry. The Act was amended in 1983 to strengthen the supervision of the industry by increasing the minimum paid-up capital and solvency requirements, updating penalties and improving the reporting and accounts provisions.

SPEECH.PARA: Section 37 of the Act provides an exemption from various reporting requirements to insurers whose activities are confined to conducting insurance business with limited classes of persons, generally only members or employees of a company or a particular trade, industry or profession, and whose annual premiums do not exceed $500,000. The threshold figure applying before the 1983 amendments was $200,000. The Australian Democrats did not oppose the increase in the threshold on that occasion. The Bill seeks to amend section 37 in two ways: firstly, to increase the premium limit to $750,000 to restore the real value of the exemption, thereby enabling one of the insurers to continue to be covered by the provision, and, secondly, to allow the limit to be adjusted upwards by regulation.

As Senator Archer said, and I agree with him, it is preferable to make such changes by legislation rather than by regulation. However, it is a fact, of course, that such regulations come before the Senate and we are able to disallow regulations if we disagree with them. The Australian Democrats on this occasion also will support both those amendments.

There are a number of other matters in the insurance industry that I would like to take this opportunity to comment on. In the first instance there are the recent problems which Regal and Occidental has experienced and which are now before the courts. As a result of these problems the Government has proposed a levy on life offices to bail out any shortfall which may arise after the legal proceedings have been concluded. This proposal raises many issues and the Australian Democrats continue to have this particular issue under consideration.

The Government also proposes to strengthen the minimum capital requirements of the Life Insurance Act. We welcome this move to strengthen the prudential supervision of life offices. It is well known that the Government has been reviewing the Life Insurance Act for years. It is interesting that it has taken this crisis to prod the Government into action on these issues. I trust that we will have legislation before us soon. Clearly, strong regulation of the financial sector is desperately needed. The problems that have come to light in regard to Regal and Occidental are only part of a long string of such problems.

We currently have the debacle of the South Australian State Bank's problems over its finance subsidiary which points to the need for Federal regulation of the non-bank financial sector. In addition, we have, of course, the examples of the Pyramid Building Society in Victoria, the State Bank of Victoria and the Estate Mortgage unlisted trust. The list goes on. It is in response to this clearly ineffective prudential supervision of our financial system that I have introduced my private member's Bill into the Senate to achieve a national scheme of strong and effective prudential supervision for non-bank financial institutions. Recent events, of course, have shown that these failings exist also in the banking sector. The Reserve Bank's methods of supervising that sector, with particular reference to the South Australian State Bank, have been admitted by Mr Fraser recently.

Another problem that must be dealt with, apart from prudential supervision, is the question of the capital backing of the fund management activities of banks, as they increasingly enter the fields traditionally dominated by the life offices. Many other insurance issues remain unresolved. The Democrats have been advocating a better deal for consumers in that area for some years. We believe that independent ombudsmen need to be appointed, along the lines of the banking ombudsman, in the areas of general insurance, life insurance and superannuation.

I turn now to the issue of outrageous fees for insurance and superannuation products, which has still not been addressed adequately by the Government. A report in Tuesday's Australian Financial Review shows that the Insurance and Superannuation Commission is still not adequately confronting the issue. I also agree with the remarks made in the debate on this Bill in the other place by the honourable member for Capricornia (Mr Wright) about the insidious practice of twisting undertaken by some unscrupulous agents. Twisting involves agents going to a previous client or to a new client whom they know is involved with a rival insurance company. The client is then convinced to enter into a new insurance contract which generates new fees for the agent and which in most cases ensures that no benefits, or rather reduced benefits, accrue to the client for the first two years during which the payments are made on the new contract. Self-regulation by the industry has not stopped this practice. Clearly, some stronger measures are needed in that area.

The last issue I would like to touch on in this debate concerns the availability of capital for Australia's small business sector. We must ensure that the magnificent efforts of our researchers and inventors yield commercial benefits not only to them but also to the community. Today's Australian newspaper documents yet another result of Australian research being developed offshore. A new diagnostic and screening kit developed by the Protein and Enzyme Technology Research Centre at Monash University has been licensed to a Japanese firm after failure to develop the project in Australia, apparently due to a takeover in 1986.

Clearly, our existing financial system arrangements have failed in this regard. Happily, Senator Button has acknowledged this on many occasions. Hopefully, next week's industry statement will address this issue by a proposal to establish an equity fund which could attract some of the growing resources accumulating in superannuation funds. I await with interest the Government's policy proposals in these matters.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The debate on the second reading of the Insurance Amendment Bill has been appropriate for what is essentially a straightforward and noncontentious Bill, but a Bill that deals with an Act that covers very important issues generally and issues of very significant current concern to a lot of Australians. It is not appropriate at this stage in deliberations of the Senate when we are trying to pass a lot of legislation to pursue all the issues raised by honourable senators; they were important. I would love the opportunity to debate some of the very important questions about investment and about people taking responsibility for the consequences of their actions, whether by cheating on insurance or as the consequences of their actions as agents or the consequences of their actions as people with enormous funds under their control for investment. All of those are important social issues of current and continuing concern.

SPEECH.PARA: But with regard to the Bill itself, I welcome the support of both honourable senators who spoke and the parties they represented. They raised one issue of particular concern; the changing of the threshold by regulation. This was a matter which immediately leapt to my attention because it is one regularly raised by the Senate. But in addition to the points which both honourable senators raised, about the fact that it is reviewable, the other point to note is that it is only possible for the Commissioner to exercise this discretion to the advantage of the citizen; it can be exercised only to increase the threshold. So, for those two reasons, I think the response of the Government, the Opposition and the Democrats is appropriate, and I welcome the support for the Bill.
Question resolved in the affirmative.
Bill read a second time, and passed through its remaining stages without amendment or debate.

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.
Motion (by Senator McMullan) agreed to:
That this Bill may proceed without formalities and be now read a first time.
Bill read a first time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: McMullan Sen R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That this Bill be now read a second time.
I seek leave to have the second reading speech incorporated in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-
The purpose of this Bill is to implement and give effect in Australian law to the provisions of the Hague Convention on the Law Applicable to Trusts and on their Recognition.
The Bill will:
- provide machinery for identifying which country's law is to govern a particular trust; and
- provide guidelines for the recognition of that trust in accordance with that law.
BACKGROUND

The Convention was adopted at the Fifteenth Session of the Hague Conference on Private International Law in 1984 as part of its work in promoting the unification of private international law. As a member of the Conference, Australia participated actively in its work on the Convention. The Convention will enter into force after 3 countries have ratified it (Article 30).

Although a number of both common law countries (the United States, United Kingdom and Canada) and civil law countries (Italy, Luxembourg and the Netherlands) have signed the Convention, only the UK and Italy have yet ratified it.

As its name suggests, the Bill deals with the law applicable to trusts and the recognition of trusts. Trusts are essentially an equitable institution which has developed in legal systems based on the English common law-the concept of a trust is generally not used in civil law systems based on the roman law model. A trust may be described as an equitable obligation which binds a person (called a trustee) to deal with some specific property (the trust property) for the benefit of persons (called the beneficiaries) or for the advancement of some specific purpose. In the common law world trusts have been developed to serve a variety of functions, ranging from charitable purposes and estate planning to vehicles of commerce.

The Convention is intended to overcome potential conflict of laws problems which may arise where aspects of a trust-such as its assets, beneficiaries or trustees-have connections with more than one jurisdiction. If the trust concept is not recognised in one of those jurisdictions, as is the case in civil law jurisdictions, the very existence and validity of the trust may be in doubt. Even among common law jurisdictions which recognise trusts, there may sometimes be different rules for ascertaining the law to govern the trust and its incidents. The Convention provides a common regime of rules governing both the recognition of trusts and the determination of which law is applicable to the trust.

The Convention is largely for the benefit of common law countries such as Australia, in that it requires civil law countries to recognise a purely common law institution while conferring benefits on common law countries or their citizens who are likely to be beneficiaries of a trust. There will be no incentive for civil law countries to be party to the Convention if common law countries are seen to lack interest in it. For this reason, early implementation of the Convention in Australia is desirable, to enable accession in the near future.
PROVISIONS OF THE CONVENTION

The Schedule to the Bill reproduces the Convention, which is divided into Chapters and Articles. Chapter I outlines the scope of the Convention and defines whether something is a trust covered by the Convention.

Chapter II identifies the national law applicable to any particular trust. Prima facie the governing law is the law chosen expressly or impliedly by the settlor, that is, the person creating the trust. Where no choice is made, the governing law is the law of the country with which the trust is most closely connected. These rules will serve to clarify existing choice of law rules, which are far from clear.

Chapter III deals with the extent to which a trust is to be recognised in accordance with the applicable law by states that become parties to the Convention. Such recognition involves, as a minimum, that the trust property exists as a separate holding and that the trustee may bring and defend proceedings in his or her capacity as trustee. As a separate holding, the trust property will have a legal existence separate from other property in general and from the trustee's own property in particular. Thus, the trustee's personal creditors will not have any recourse to the trust property, though that property may be held in the name of the trustee.

Chapter IV contains a number of general articles, several of which limit the effect of the Convention in particular circumstances, where there are good reasons either for a trust not being recognised at all or for the governing law determined in accordance with the Convention being ignored in favour of some other law.
Chapter V contains final articles dealing with signature, ratification, accession, reservations and entry into force of the Convention.
ADVANTAGES OF IMPLEMENTATION FOR AUSTRALIA

The Bill will enable Australia to ratify the Convention and, once the Convention enters into force, to bring its provisions into force for Australia. The major advantage of the Convention arises when property subject to a trust is located within the jurisdiction of a civil law contracting state to the Convention. The practical effect of Australia acceding to the Convention would be that the true ownership of Australian trust property in the territory of a civil law party would be recognised and respected.

At present, the law governing a trust with aspects extending over more than one jurisdiction is determined in Australia by common law rules of conflict of laws. The Convention is largely consistent with the Australian common law rules of conflict of laws. Adoption of the Convention would not require amendment of existing Australian statute law and would not cause substantial changes to existing Australian law.

In particular, the Convention would not impose new obligations on Australian courts to give effect to fraudulent or otherwise ``undesirable'' trusts. The Convention provides merely for the determination of which law applies to a trust. Moreover, the Convention allows precedence to be given to a contracting state's public policy (Article 18), mandatory laws relating to insolvency, succession, transfer of property, exchange controls, protection of cultural property, etc (Articles 15 and 16) and exercises of a contracting state's fiscal powers (Article 19).
SCOPE OF APPLICATION OF COMMONWEALTH LEGISLATION

The Commonwealth legislation will apply the Convention only to ``international'' trusts, where the law of a foreign country is potentially applicable, and not extend it to solely domestic or ``interstate'' trusts to which the law of another Australian State or Territory is potentially applicable. The Convention specifically allows a federal state to refrain from applying the Convention to conflict of laws between its territorial units (Article 24). The Commonwealth legislation would not prevent States and Territories from themselves legislating, as some have indicated an interest in doing, to apply the rules of the Convention to ``interstate'' trusts. The Commonwealth legislation is quite simple, merely adopting in Australia the terms of the Convention subject to the reservation regarding non-applicability as between Australian States and Territories.
COMMONWEALTH-STATE IMPLICATIONS

Within Australia trusts are generally a matter of State/Territory law and the Convention could be implemented in Australia either by uniform State/Territory legislation or by Commonwealth legislation. As the Convention has no effect on statute law, has the minimal possible effect on common law conflict of laws rules and is essentially concerned with international trusts, the Government has decided that it would be most simply and conveniently implemented by Commonwealth legislation.

The Convention was considered by the Standing Committee of Attorneys-General in 1987 and the States and Territories have accepted this course of action. It is understood that the States and Territories, or some of them, might later enact legislation to apply the rules of the Convention to ``interstate'' trusts.
CONCLUSION

The choice of law rules in the Convention are very similar to the existing common law choice of law rules. The qualifications on recognition contained in the Convention may appear to detract from the value of the Convention to common law countries, but they were essential in order for the civil law countries to agree to the draft Convention and their existence will be of prime importance in persuading such countries to ratify the Convention. The Convention's value is that it establishes a framework and scheme for recognition of trusts and perhaps also an expectation of their recognition. Its adoption will result in a substantial improvement over the present situation.
FINANCIAL IMPACT STATEMENT
The Trusts (Hague Convention) Bill will have no impact on Commonwealth revenue or expenditure.
I present the Explanatory Memorandum to this Bill.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.
Debate (on motion by Senator Brownhill) adjourned.

DEBATE.TITLE: INDUSTRY, TECHNOLOGY AND COMMERCE LEGISLATION AMENDMENT BILL 1991

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 13 February, on motion by Senator Bolkus:
That this Bill be now read a second time.
(Quorum formed)

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —We are debating the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. On behalf of Senator Bishop I would like to foreshadow an amendment to the motion. The object of this Bill is to amend the principal Act, the Industry Research and Development Act 1986, with the following objectives: firstly, to extend the grants for the industry research and development scheme as administered by the Industry Research and Development Board in line with last August's Budget, and to make minor adjustment changes to those operations; secondly, to bring the national procurement and development program under the Act; and, thirdly, to amend the Science and Industry Research Act 1949 in order to allow the Commonwealth Scientific and Industrial Research Organisation to accept gifts of up to $1m without having to obtain ministerial approval.

SPEECH.PARA: There are additional provisions to amend drafting errors within the National Management Act 1960, the Export Market Development Grants Act 1974, the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Act 1989 and the Patents Act 1990. Having made the introduction, with your permission, Madam Deputy President, I think it would be appropriate if Senator Bishop took over from here.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bishop Sen B.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill is an important Bill. I will be moving an amendment at the conclusion of my speech, which simply says that we will be condemning the Government yet again for its incapacity to allow the Australian economy to survive and, indeed, generally notes that the extension of the schemes as provided for in the Bill, specifically those under the grant for industry research and development (GIRD) scheme, is further evidence of the Government's failure to make our economy work.

SPEECH.PARA: The words are couched in technological language but the sentiment remains firm. On my behalf, Senator Parer outlined the intent of the Bill, which very simply is to extend the grants for industry, research and development scheme. The Bill will have a financial impact of ensuring that those grants will total approximately $32m over the next four years. The national procurement development program is to be brought within the Industry Research and Development Act 1986 rather than continuing to operate under delegation.

The extension of the various schemes in the Industry Research and Development Board are expressive of deeper difficulties in commercialising technology and establishing high technology industries in Australia. The fact that they are put in the position in the first place of having to force or contrive industry and research linkages attests to a fundamental weakness in the commercialisation process at work in the economy.

The Government has led us to believe that Australia's economic and industrial future will be characterised by the development of a new generation of high technology in manufacturing; but, quite frankly, this has not come to pass. Increasingly over the course of the past two decades, more successful economies have exploited innovative product development, advanced and flexible manufacturing processes and high returns to small and medium volume niche markets, but Australia has failed to adapt or evolve its manufacturing sector in this way. Australia has failed to integrate high technology production strategies within the industrial sector and has therefore crippled opportunities to create the sort of industrial base which feeds off and contributes to the research base.

The nature of the GIRD scheme has the potential to establish the conditions for industry development, especially in the high technology industries, but it is not easy. There is a need to draw broader policy initiatives which address macro and micro policy settings. If this does not happen and if the overall across-the-economy conditions are not supportive of secure investment climates and improved productivity, the chances of building up a real base for a particular industry or industry grouping will prove difficult indeed.

There are examples which are useful to illustrate the problems facing the enhancement of technology. Australia has great potential in various areas of the information related industry. As it is an area in which Australia has a trade deficit of $4 billion-$10 billion by 1996-it is also of critical economic significance. The Government has had in place an industry strategy designed to consolidate its areas of strength and provide the conditions for establishing smaller start-up companies within the domestic market, but that very strategy is foundering on the Government's failings on broader economic strategy.

High interest rates and the recession have taken their toll on the fragile local industry, particularly on the software and component sectors, which depend on continuing demand from users. The disruption in demand caused by the recession is crippling these fledgling industries. Growth in the Australian information industry sector has been slashed by half as a result of the recession, representing a loss of $11.45 billion.

How does the Government reconcile this deliberately engineered recession with the impact this will have on emerging local information related industries? Already in the past year the industry recorded its first drop in profit in 12 years. Its growth has fallen below the consumer price index at 5.7 per cent; investment has fallen 13 per cent and is still falling; and imports massively outweigh exports-$444m versus $2.4 billion.

I think it is significant to note the important role played by the government sector in adding to the import bill of information technology generally. It is extraordinary that Australia is the eighth largest market in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development in terms of the sale of information technology. As a country of only 17 million people, we have a huge import bill. Indeed, in the last reconciled figures that I have seen, information technology represented our largest single import.

At least 50 per cent of information technology purchases is made by government. As we still maintain a cash accounting system, information technology has a value in the year in which it was purchased, but the very next year it virtually does not have to be accounted for nor accorded a value. We have the situation where it is open to a department to say simply, `I think we might have a little toy because the other fellows have got one'. We have no real information about whether the equipment purchased is doing something useful or whether the department could have done without it. It is a serious problem when we realise that this is an import cost to this country; at the same time the ingenuity that we have in Australia is being disadvantaged.

As I said, business spending on computer systems and networks in the private sector is a very low 1.3 per cent and falling, whereas overseas companies spend more than that. But it is significant to note that the public sector is the largest buyer of information technology in Australia.

Again, it is interesting to look at what happens to Australian companies when they are, quite frankly, disadvantaged by problems of the Government pursuing its macro-economic policies. Delen Corporation, located in South Australia, which produced printed circuit boards, tried to offset some of the $100m a year we spend on imported PCBs and was set to negotiate a $14.5m export contract with Digital Equipment Corporation (Australia) Pty Ltd. The plan could have produced about 12,000 square metres of printed circuit boards per month if it were working at capacity. This would have been worth something in the vicinity of $30m to $40m in annual sales. But the collapse of local orders, caused by the recession-the recession we had to have; the one that the Treasurer (Mr Keating) personally engineered and pulled the levers for-forced that plant to close its doors last year. The firm is being propped up by grants from the South Australian State Government in order to find an equity partner but, with little demand for product, the search may prove difficult.

The collapse of economic activity caused by the deliberately engineered recession has also struck at the skills base in the industry at a time when we need those skills to be maintained in this country. Although the long term skills needs of industry remain formidable, the irony is that the computer programmers and others skilled in the computer sciences are being retrenched. As an example, witness the closure of the Commonwealth-funded Victorian computer industry training course which was terminated because it was, and I quote from the December bulletin of the Australian Computer Society (Inc), `an unfortunate casualty of the recession'. For the many who have been forced into bankruptcy, into financial penury and into seeing sometimes decades of work collapse around their ears, `an unfortunate casualty of the recession' is an awful phrase to use to explain the plight of Australians. How does the Government reconcile the need to maintain and develop the skills base for the information sector with its economic policies that are driving the computer programmers onto the unemployment queues? Those queues are growing at a rate which has knocked the final leg from under this Government's record. When we were looking various performance indicators of the Government's record, so many times we would hear, `Ah, yes, but we made employment grow; we do not have the same unemployment rates that we had under the previous administration of the coalition'. Of course, that plea has now been knocked sideways too as unemployment figures continue to grow at an unconscionable rate.

The recession has hit at many tiers. There were many who were quite shocked at the closure of the Black and Decker plant when it pulled up stakes from its high-tech Croydon plant in Melbourne in late January, preferring to import its power tool product rather than manufacture locally. It was doing everything right. It had enlightened, experienced management which had put in place a coherent technology and business strategy. It incorporated advanced management training. It was a state of the art plant which used robotic production lines. It was doing its bit. It had a reputation for keeping down its overheads and for extracting every efficiency possible. It produced a product which retained its commercial prominence because of a constant push to improve quality and design standards.

It was about achievement of excellence, and yet it failed to sustain its local high- tech manufacturing capability because it simply could not compete on costs with internationally manufactured products. It could not be competitive, and therefore it had to close. It could not win the big international contracts because it was uncompetitive on price.

Why was it uncompetitive? I refer to the Business Council of Australia report, which I mentioned earlier, and which said that if we do not compete internationally our standard of living will collapse. According to the former managing director of Black and Decker, Mr Kevin Cashman, falls in protection were taking place without the offsetting or compensating micro-economic reforms. I refer to the micro- economic reforms which were promised to be the feature of the previous Hawke Administration prior to the election, but we still do not see the real economic reforms taking place.

The same issue has crippled the viability of high technology chemical industries. Mr Cashman, however, pointed out that there had been no improvement in the handling of the labour market. He said that the costs of the domestically operated transport network, especially the waterfront, had robbed the company of its price competitiveness.

Again and again from the Opposition benches we have said that there must be deregulation of the labour market, that there must be the ability to have enterprise agreements. We have said that there must be significant reform on the waterfront, and not the sort of thing that is simply a golden handshake for selective, shall I say, and more elderly wharf labourers who in many cases could be said to be replaced by sons-almost a dynasty or an image that is being perpetuated.

TALK.START.PARA: —What would you do instead? What would you have us do? You have not actually told us yet.

—I reply to the Minister by saying that we have presented to him a whole range of policies. We have said that, if he chooses to take them up, we would grant him bipartisan support. The challenge has been there.

SPEECH.PARA: It has cost Australia Black and Decker because that company could no longer compete. In fact, a Government survey blames current economic policies for the lack of manufacturing export growth. The report of the Bureau of Industry Economics (BIE) entitled Impediments to Manufactured Exports released last month shows that Australian businesses are clamouring to enter overseas markets but are undercut by poor levels of labour productivity and other cost factors. The report, based on a survey of 1,200 manufacturing firms, essentially discredits Government efforts to focus its industry policy solely on providing aid to manufacturers by way of subsidies and other export assistance schemes. In other words, the Government has only embraced bandaid measures. Unless we attack the underlying problems, we will not be competitive and will be unable to maintain our standard of living.

The respondents to the BIE survey singled out labour costs, the high cost of capital, the inefficiency again of the waterfront, and inefficiencies in the transport sector as the key reasons for the failure to break into new markets. The message of the study was clear. Australian firms do not need handouts, and indeed they do not want them. They simply want to be freed from the basic inefficiencies of the economy.

The BIE survey indicated difficulties in competing on prices as a major obstacle in winning a bigger share of export markets. That is a point with which Kevin Cashman of Black and Decker would no doubt feel in sympathy. The BIE also said that other countries such as West Germany and Sweden have been able to pay higher wages than Australia and yet be successful exporters. I think it is quite significant to acknowledge that the competitive edge that Germany is enjoying or has enjoyed through the 1980s in its toolmaking capacity has been significant, as other economies have needed those toolmaking manufactures in order to build up their own economies. Germany has been efficient in meeting that demand.

In those countries where there has been so much advance, the difference is in the area of labour productivity. The study reveals that the rush to embrace a new generation of protection and assistance schemes only represents economic tinkering. It does not matter by what name protectionism is called. It does not matter whether it is called strategic trade theory, a new development to enhance profitability, or anything else; if it is protection, in the end the interests of an industry are not served.

Our experience of the 1950s and 1960s, when we built tariff walls of protection around us, teaches us the lesson that we must learn in the 1990s if we are to maintain our standard of living. Until such time as the Government is able to set its industry policies within the context of an efficient economy, the fantasy of rebuilding the nation's high technology manufacturing base will never be realised. It has to be soundly based.

Schemes such as these that are before the Senate are in their effect limited in terms of impact in doing anything significant to reconstruct the commercialisation process in the economy. Efficient economies with strong advanced industrial bases are essential to technological structural change. Therefore, I move:
At end of motion, add ``, but the Senate:

(a) is of the opinion that the very existence of the discretionary grants scheme and the generic technologies scheme, administered by the Industry Research and Development Board, attests to the Government's failure to carry out necessary economic reforms which has resulted in:
(i) the incapacity of Australia's economy to derive the full benefits of technological innovation,
(ii) the high cost of capital and general economic conditions which have compromised industry investment, especially in technology-related business strategies, and
(iii) the inability of small start-up companies to gain access to suitable private capital backing or industry support at the early stages of product development; and
(b) notes that the extension of these schemes until 1994, which the Bill proposes, is further evidence of the Government's failure in this regard''.

In moving that amendment, I make clear that we will not be voting against the Bill. We wish simply to put on the record that we find that the way in which the Government has managed-or mismanaged-the Australian economy for the past eight years has resulted in Australia not succeeding in the area of high technology.

I said earlier that today is an occasion for the wearing of black because it is the anniversary of the beginning of the ninth year of the Australian Labor Party in government in Australia. This is indeed an occasion on which to wear black. One acknowledges that we still have two more tedious and grinding years of bad management, poor administration and suffering by the Australian people before we can see light at the end of the tunnel, with a change in government which will inevitably come.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to speak for the Australian Democrats on the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. This Bill seeks to amend several other pieces of legislation and, as has already been pointed out, to extend the grants for industry, research and development scheme, known as GIRD, for a further four years with approximately $32m per annum, and also to extend the national procurement development program to June 1992. They may well be extended beyond those times, as the Minister for Administrative Services (Senator Bolkus) pointed out in his second reading speech, but the latter will be reviewed at that time.

SPEECH.PARA: It also seeks to make various other amendments. I am pleased to see that the use of the standard international units will be given effect by this legislation. That is something which is long overdue and which makes the meshing of scientific understanding of matters and trade matters much simpler if one standard international set of units is used. It also allows the use of derived units. The Minister mentions litres per minute or some such example, which will be a useful legal clarification.

Turning to the main section of the Bill, the Democrats would have no criticism of this Bill as far as it goes, but we use this occasion to point out that while some of the things which the previous speaker, Senator Bishop, pointed out in relation to micro-economic reform and the need to improve the efficiency of industry may well have some substance-I think that the Minister is already turning his attention to some of those things-our primary criticism is that this Government has really lacked vision as to where it wants to position Australia in the decades ahead.

I return to a theme which I developed in speaking to the Senate Standing Committee on Industry, Science and Technology, which is looking at the greenhouse issue, and reiterate that what we as a country must recognise is that human beings are not free to do what they like with the environment and we do work within very serious constraints. Those constraints are impacting on us in a way which, unless we take notice of those restraints and unless we make our industry conform within those restraints-indeed, unless we make our whole society conform within those constraints-there will be no society at all. The upside of recognising those constraints and making industry fit with that is that we will have industry which fulfils the needs not only of Australia but of world markets in the years ahead.

I point again to the International Panel on Climate Change (IPCC) which pointed out that there is an urgent need to reduce greenhouse gas emissions by as much as 60 to 80 per cent. That would not bring greenhouse gases down to a level where they were before industrialisation began; that is merely to cause them to stabilise at a much higher level with very considerable greenhouse consequences, which at this stage in the development of our global industrial lifestyle we simply cannot avoid. As I pointed out before, if we are also to observe the need for international equity in relation to access to resources, Australia must do much better than that. Indeed, we must reduce our greenhouse gas emissions by as much as 92 per cent.

While it is certainly true that the signs of greenhouse warming and the consequences in terms of climate change, sea level rise and so on are not yet unequivocally evident, the best scientific evidence available, which came from the IPCC committee, is that those signals will become absolutely unequivocal by early in the next century. If we think that we are going to build industry simply by invoking the buzzwords `high tech', `micro-economic reform', `working harder' or `clever country' and we are going to solve Australia's problems and the world's problems, then I am afraid that we are well on the way to going down the gurgler along with everybody else.

Australia is in a position to take note of this best scientific advice-and that is what this Bill is substantially about-and to start putting its research funds deliberately into those industries which are oriented towards energy efficiency in the first instance and towards renewable energy as we find the need to replace the sources of energy supply which we currently use. What do we find when we look at what this Government has done in that light? We find, for instance, that the research funds which have gone through the National Energy Research, Development and Demonstration Council (NERDDC) grant scheme into renewable energy have declined by a factor of eight in real terms since 1978. I will read from a brief paper by Professor Kaneff of the Australian National University in the journal Solar Progress. He states:

The real values of NERDDC grants for Renewable Energy R& have now dropped to about one-eighth of the 1978 grants. Taking into account the drop in the Australian dollar over this period, and the fact that R& equipment often needs to be purchased from overseas, the real value of grants has dropped more than an order of magnitude.

In other words, it is more than a factor of ten. The article goes on to deal with the individual areas in some detail and then turns to his own particular area of excellence and one in which this year the United States will be building in California a solar thermal power station of over 600 megawatts. Speaking of Australia, he says:

This lack of recognition is most evident in relation to solar thermal power employing medium and high temperature for which less than 2 per cent of the total grant monies has been allocated. Yet this area offers one of the very few ways in which renewable energy can be used on a mass scale and so make a major contribution to total energy resources. Curiously, this fact is realised overseas far more than it is in Australia.

I wanted to point to one particular defect which I find in this Bill and in many other Bills which the Government is bringing forth. It is the lack of a clear vision of where we need to position this country and its industry in the next 10 to 15 years so as to meet the objectives. I stress again that the very best scientific evidence that we have available to us indicates that it will be absolutely essential that we address these objectives.

In turning to an extension of that idea, I find the same degree of short-sightedness in the United States. The year 1987 was described by one leading solar researcher as a black year. The activities of the Solar Energy Research Institute of Western Australia were greatly reduced; they have since been closed down. The Solar Energy Research Centre of the University of Queensland was totally disbanded. So not only is the Federal Government not spending money in this area, but also it is sending a clear signal to the United States that it is not appropriate that it spend money either. Yet this is the very area in which in a few short years into the future it will be absolutely necessary that we have the technology to provide the energy which is the very basis of all our industrial processes.

To turn to another area where I believe we are on the threshold of making a great mistake, the world has now recognised that we must move away from the use of chlorofluorocarbons (CFCs) in refrigeration and in a number of other areas for which those gases are used. The high technology approach is to attempt to slot into refrigerators an alternative which has been developed by ICI Australia Ltd and DuPont going by the name of 134a. It is a hydrofluorocarbon (HFC) and it does not have the serious ozone depleting characteristics of CFC-12, the commonly used refrigerant. However, it has approximately 10 per cent of the greenhouse effect of CFC-12. It does not require a great deal of imagination to understand that if refrigeration, even using the new 134a refrigerant, comes into widespread use in a country such as China with 60 times our population and the same sorts of technology are used-namely, one in which as the unit requires maintenance the gas is simply bled off to atmosphere-irrespective of what we do about carbon dioxide, the addition of HFC-134a to the atmosphere will far exceed that reduction in CO2 in its effect on greenhouse. Our children and our children's children will be in a worse situation than they are today.

We have in our midst a low technology-I stress that-refrigeration using ammonia. It happens to be five times more energy efficient to use ammonia than it is to use CFC. It is used in all our gas fridges and all our kerosene refrigerators. Looking 10 to 15 years into the future, I believe that we should be making an intelligent decision to go back to the old technology which has been around for well over 100 years now and to develop that as a major technology for use both within Australia and for export purposes. I believe that as the world wakes up to what it is doing going down the alternative `high technology' road using the new chemical, it will discover it is going down a blind alley and cannot use that technology.

There are a lot of other technologies, some of them old technologies, which are more appropriate to where we need to go. The point I am trying to stress is that we are lacking the wisdom to see where we need to position this country and, indeed, act as a leader to the rest of the world in developing those technologies which are appropriate to meet the environmental constraints which some of us see looming so large before us.

This Government pays lip-service to those matters; indeed, it has appointed a number of people within its various departments to advise it on greenhouse. My experience of those people is that they have been put there deliberately to obfuscate the issue and to attempt to put off as long as possible the need to address this urgent problem. My criticism of this Bill and many other Bills like it is simply that lack of wisdom, that lack of ability to see that there is a cohesive, coordinating imperative developing in the environment which must direct the way in which we develop our technology over the next 10 to 15 years to meet those challenges so that we do not leave behind us a legacy of a world which is degraded, in which the options for our children and grandchildren are so much depleted; indeed, in which the options may be so depleted that they find it difficult to survive at all.

Let us get away from the buzz words of high technology and micro-economic reform and let us talk about the real constraints within which Australian industry must be developed. While I believe we should be doing this for reasons of sanity, for reasons of responsibility to later generations, if we go down that road it will also produce the sorts of industries which will position us in a very good way to meet the challenges of other countries and, therefore, to address the very serious problems which we face in terms of our balance of trade and our own industry vis-a-vis industries in other countries.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Olsen Sen J.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —My contribution to the debate will be somewhat brief. However, I would like to pick up the theme established by Senator Bishop. While not opposing the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill 1991, I believe that it is worth taking stock at this point of where we are at in Australia economically, in the climate in which the business community has to exist.

SPEECH.PARA: It is worth putting on the record that we are constantly presented with legislation which is necessary, not for the advancement of Australia's industry in international markets but actually to hide damage already being done to that sector by the policies of the Hawke Government. Today we have seen yet another example of how those policy settings are wrong for the business community and job opportunities for Australians.

One of the main objectives of the legislation we are discussing tonight is to extend the grants for industry research and development (GIRD) scheme to 30 June 1994. The GIRD scheme has operated since 1986. As we know, it provides assistance to companies and research agencies to develop technologies with commercial application in Australian industry.

In the financial year 1989-90 its two components in total approved some 90 applications at a cost of $37.6m. No-one on this side of the chamber doubts the necessity in the current economic climate for supporting the extension of this scheme. However, the examination of why such schemes are actually necessary is quite a different matter. They are unfortunately necessary because this Government, while making bellicose statements about achieving the clever country and paying lip-service to how crucial industry innovation is for Australia's future, has, at the same time, set in place policies which can only cripple it and it becomes a vicious circle. The policies are wrong.

The Hawke-Keating economic inefficiencies are not being addressed by appropriate government action because no-one but John Button will admit there are inadequacies. So bandaid government schemes, such as GIRD, are created to camouflage the damage. But camouflage or not, the facts remain glaringly obvious. And they are not facts of which the Government can be proud.

While GIRD certainly encourages some firms, which could not otherwise afford to invest in research and development, business sector spending in that area as a percentage of gross domestic product (GDP) still leaves Australia at an extremely low level. Our business sector spends just 0.52 per cent of GDP on research and development. When compared with, for example, Germany's business sector at 2.08 per cent, it is not a healthy sign. I doubt anyone can take comfort in the fact that if one searches through the statistics long enough one can find a country whose business sector spends less than ours, such as Spain at 0.42 per cent of GDP. Meanwhile Australian government sector spending on research and development as a percentage of GDP remains higher than other Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development countries at 0.39 per cent.

We obviously have a long way to go in getting a better balance between government and business spending on research and development. It is quite clear that the balance cannot be achieved under the present economic policies of this Government. These policies have militated against the raising of venture capital to underwrite industry related technology innovation. As well, the crippling interest rates and labour costs, the taxation burden, the waterfront inefficiencies and the loss of consumer confidence do nothing to either allow or encourage business to invest in research and development.

Senator Bishop referred to one South Australian company in the high-tech research and development innovation area and the difficulties it is facing. Whilst not naming it, I would like to mention another South Australian based company. A very successful family company, it has been in operation for 80 years and has plants overseas based in the United Kingdom, Germany and China as well in South Australia. It employs several thousand employees within Australia alone.

For the first time in its 80-year history that company most probably will not be making a profit this year. That company has reduced staffing levels across the board from management down to the shop floor. It is now looking at the last area of curtailing expenditure-its research and development area-and cutting that out. It is a company that relies heavily on research and development to upgrade its market opportunities, to upgrade its product lines and to keep pace with and in front of the rest of the world in terms of the product that it manufactures and exports for Australia.

That company is no different from many other companies, small or big, throughout Australia which, because of a range of economic policies and pressures that have been applied to them, have simply cut out those functions that are not absolutely essential to survival today. It is sad that research and development is one of the areas that gets crossed off and dismantled. It has long term repercussions not only for the companies concerned but also for job opportunities and for Australia in the long term.

The recession that this Government tells us we had to have will further markedly reduce business investment in this area. Ideally, industry related technology innovation programs should be the responsibility of the private sector. It is, therefore, uncomfortable to know that the economic circumstances of 1991 mean that as a Liberal I have to support legislation which is, in effect, an industry prop.

TALK.START.PARA: —As you have done for 25 years.

—I am opposed philosophically to such props. This is the same policy direction that the Government is picking up in terms of its tariff reductions. It is all very well for the Minister at the table to say, `You have supported this policy direction for 25 years'. The fact is that a whole range of economic circumstances are now compounding the problem, making it absolutely essential for these types of policy directions to be in place, to give some assistance and to stop the drain away from a vital and important area in research and development. A country governed properly has industry which does not need props to keep it moving in a direction which is in its own long term interest, unhindered by poor economic management from Canberra.
—This is the perfect world approach.

—No, it is not the perfect world approach. We certainly do not have the perfect world approach in Australia at the moment; there is not much doubt about that. The fact is that a climate needs to be created for business opportunities. Those policy settings-the economic settings-as I have mentioned, have made it impossible for business to maintain research and development in those areas.

SPEECH.PARA: We need to get the mix of research and development between the government sector and the private sector a little better balanced so that we start equating with countries like Germany, which has a greater percentage of its GDP committed by the private sector to research and development. That is what I am talking about. If the Minister were listening to the whole component of the speech he would understand that that is the direction-the signpost-that we ought to be putting in place in policy direction in this country.

During the last session I spoke out strongly against changes to the Export Market Development Grants Amendment Bill which watered down government help to the nation's small business exporters. That is in contradiction to the interjection that the Minister made in this debate. On the one hand, in that particular area the Government is watering down assistance to small business enterprises, to open up and maintain export markets overseas. That puts the lie to the comment that the Minister made earlier during my remarks.

TALK.START.PARA: —It also defeats your own argument.

—No, it does not. The reason it does not is that those small businesses, because of the circumstances applying now, simply cannot tap into and maintain those export markets. We have a balance of payments problem in this country-or had the Minister not noticed? We need to get the economic settings right so that we can start systematically removing some of the props costing taxpayers in this country, by giving positive and active encouragement to business to commit its own funds to research and development, as it ought to be, as it does in many other countries throughout the world.

SPEECH.PARA: In the instance that I have just referred to, the Government removed some of the aid and, as a result, many small firms have walked away from the export market because in the current climate they simply cannot meet the withdrawal of that aid and support. That is why we are supporting these measures before the chamber tonight. We are supporting these measures because they are clearly an indication of this Government's failing in economic policy settings, and the difficulties that are being experienced by business throughout this country as a result.

While we agree that the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill 1991 should not be opposed, our reasons for that decision are not in line with the Government's views. I hope that the need for the GIRD scheme will be as short as the life of this Government. The only way that we will set about creating a climate in the long term for those business opportunities, for research and development, and the appropriate committal of private sector funds to research and development, is to ensure that overall economic policy settings in this country are right.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —I thank honourable senators for their contributions to the second reading debate on the Industry, Technology and Commerce Legislation Amendment Bill 1991. The Opposition, of course, never lets the facts stand in the way of a good story and it has not done so on this occasion.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to point out briefly that the picture has been painted this evening of Australia being in a regressive state as a result of this Government's policies in respect of research and development from the private sector. I would like to put the facts on the record. The level of Australian business investment in research and development has in fact risen from 0.24 per cent of gross domestic product in 1981-82 to 0.52 per cent of GDP in 1988-89. That is in real terms almost the highest growth rate of private investment in research and development in the Organisation for Economic Cooperation and Development.

This is encouraging in terms of business research and development. That is a major determinant of the innovative capacity of private business. But it is paralleled by an even more impressive figure, and that is the extent of Australian companies seeking patents overseas. In 1978 there was an annual rate of 2,400 applications, which had risen in 1988 to 14,400. That is almost a six-fold increase in the number of Australian companies that are not only innovative but also actively seeking to patent their wares elsewhere overseas.

In conclusion, I want to speak very strongly against acceptance of the Opposition's amendment. It is in fact a political statement, and Senator Bishop and Senator Olsen had the opportunity to do that in debate anyway. The opening paragraph, paragraph (a), should be defeated because it is a fact that governments of all political persuasions have supported research and development directly with grants such as those provided under this scheme for a quarter of a century. So they should, and so we should continue to do. It is not an indication of the Government's failure to provide a perfect world where private enterprise will do this without any assistance at all. In this country, with our large continent and our small population by international standards, it is essential for government to play a role in this area. I hope that on those grounds the amendment will be defeated.

In terms of the sparkling performance of the Opposition in providing real solutions rather than political rhetoric, none could be better demonstrated than in the matter that has been raised by Senator Bishop, and that is reform of the waterfront. We now have-and I have been waiting for it for a year-the first detailed statement by a shadow Minister from the Opposition as to what the Opposition's policy is. At an industry function a week ago, a speaker said to the shadow Minister for industry and commerce, `You have been criticising the Government for 12 months'--
Debate interrupted.

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The ACTING DEPUTY PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! It being 7.30 p.m., under sessional order I put the question:

INTERJECT.PARA: That the Senate do now adjourn.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —I will not hold the Senate for very long on my behalf tonight--
—Good.

—Senator Collins, I am right in what I am saying. On 12 February 1991 at page 339 of Hansard I was talking about the Australian Wheat Board's annual report of 1989-90. Unfortunately, a few of my statements were put wrong by Hansard. Not that I blame it; it was a case of using terms. I will go through and read into the Hansard the correct version. I have been in contact with Hansard today and it may be too late to change it. As I said, I was talking about the Australian Wheat Board annual report for 1989-90. In the first paragraph I mentioned that we had had a change in the Wheat Marketing Act. I said that the basis of that Act was the deregulation of the domestic market and the removal of the GMP; in other words, the guaranteed minimum price. If I can use my phonetics, it should be Golf Mike Papa. Unfortunately, the Hansard read--
—How does GDP become Golf Mike Papa?
—Does Senator Collins not know his two-way radio phonetics?

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Collins interjecting-

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, it should have been GMP but it came out as GNP-Golf November Papa. Hansard then put, `the removal of the gross national product (GNP)'.
—That is the Golf November Papa.
—Yes, that is what I said; that is the second one-Golf November Papa. It should have read Golf Mike Papa.
—Roger; over and out.
—Roger, over and out. No, I am not over and out in this case. That was the first paragraph. In the fourth paragraph I said:

SPEECH.PARA: What I would really like to ask Mr Kerin is: When is he going to carry out the promise he made in 1988, when he was trying to convince us to accept losing the rotating . . .

I then mentioned GMP. That is what I said. But Hansard has put GNP-Golf November Papa. I read that in to correct any impression that I might not know what I am talking about. In the final paragraph, Hansard reports me as saying:
Of course, I am also very critical of the Grains Council of Australia which willingly gave up that GNP . . .

This was wrong again. I have risen briefly to correct the impression that some people have gained. Members of the Grains Council of Australia lashed me in front of a primary industries committee today. They said that I did not know the difference between a guaranteed minimum price and the gross national product. I can assure the Grains Council that I know what I am talking about. I can also assure it that I still believe what I said about it giving up that guaranteed minimum price without a fight, which we have paid for now.

TALK.START.PARA: —So you are saying that Hansard got it Whisky Romeo Oscar November Golf?
—That is correct, Senator Collins. Mr Acting Deputy President, I thank you for your indulgence in allowing me to correct those points in Hansard.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Macdonald Sen I.D.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tonight I take the opportunity to mention a matter which is of very great importance to Australia. It relates to waterfront reform. I am pleased that Minister Collins is in the chamber while I say this. Commissioner Sweeney in the Industrial Relations Commission today issued a statement on six matters still outstanding relating to Conaust (Aust) Pty Ltd and Container Terminals of Australia Ltd (CTAL) in their attempts to reform the waterfront. The six matters still outstanding were really some of the most crucial ones of dispute between the parties. They were matters which needed to be resolved if there is to be any real chance of waterfront reform in Australia. They related to overtime, double headers, recruitment, the practice known as two-up and two-down, amenities men and preference in employment.

SPEECH.PARA: Following the statement Conaust and CTAL announced publicly at the time that whilst they had reservations they did accept the statement of the Commission. Whilst it is not everything they wanted, they were, in an attempt to get the reform process going, prepared to state publicly, because of the public interest involved in this, that they would accept those things subject to some conditions. The conditions were that all other matters understood to have been previously agreed were to remain as agreed and, in particular, the number of permanent employees of CTAL should be the number indicated to the Commission during the most recent talks and around which this particular package was designed. The other condition was that a strict timetable for processing the outcome to actual implementation of reforms be announced and stuck by.

It now awaits the union organisation to determine its attitude towards this particular issue. Conaust and CTAL deserve the very great thanks of this nation. They have our congratulations and should have the nation's congratulations for the part that they have played in this. They have not been bullied into accepting a second rate agreement. They have not caved in where others have. In doing so, they have done Australia a great service,. The agreement that has resolved following today's issues is good and as good as one might hope to get in this instance. It has much better qualities than many other agreements that have been spoken about and accepted by competitors of Conaust and CTAL, to the extent that these people who held out for the right agreement will now be much more competitive. It also makes a mockery of the statements of the Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support (Senator Collins) that the right agreements had been achieved in other issues. I am more familiar with the Cairns port, but in the agreement with National Terminals Australia Ltd--

TALK.START.PARA: —It was not a judgment.

—That is the Minister's opinion. Not all wisdom resides with him. In fact, the Minister's handling of this issue has been scandalous. It is no wonder that he had to get the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke), the Treasurer (Mr Keating) and other senior Ministers to come along and help him with it. I am pleased to say that as a result of the people standing out and as a result of the Opposition's pressure-and Mr John Sharp has done a marvellous job on this-the pressure has been kept up and the industry moving. If it had not been for people such as John Sharp and the Opposition generally, Senator Parer and other people, agreements would have been made months ago which did not carry out the necessary reform.
—Three hundred million down the gurgler.

—As Senator Parer says, $300m down the gurgler. That is what the Minister would have people believe but Conaust had the guts, the intestinal fortitude, to stick it out and it has got somewhere. It deserves congratulations from the nation for that.

SPEECH.PARA: One might be a little suspicious of this happening. It was because the Prime Minister wanted to announce something in his economic statement. He had nothing of any interest and of any real reform to announce.

I suppose that we should be thankful for small mercies and it is probably good that the economic statement is to be made. At least we will get some reform. I might also add that this matter is not resolved at the moment. The people on one side have indicated that, with some reservations, they would accept. They announced that publicly and quickly so that the process could go ahead. We await the union's response.

I suspect that the Government and the Minister are pleased that the matter is almost resolved. But I am sure that tonight they will be the subject of many calls from their mates in the Waterside Workers Federation of Australia who are trying to stop this sort of thing. Some of the reforms that may well have been implemented through the courage of Conaust and CTAL would overcome some of the rotten practices that have grown up in the waterfront over many years.

TALK.START.PARA: —Which have been condoned by the Minister.

—As Senator Kemp rightly says, that has been under the control of the Minister for almost a year. Time is running out and Senator Collins's `use by' date has almost expired.
