As Senator Walters said a few days ago, `There are only a certain number of sleeps before Senator Collins is back on the back bench where he was until the Prime Minister, for some reason, promoted him to the front bench some time ago'. It is good that we have had this statement. It is up to the unions to decide what they will do and hopefully, for the benefit of Australia, the unions will come along with the right decisions.

SPEECH.PARA: It is probably appropriate that I just briefly mention the six matters that were dealt with and that have been determined, spoken on, resolved or supported today by Commissioner Sweeney. Probably the most important matter is the question of recruitment. It may seem strange to other employers in Australia, and it may seem strange to me as a small businessman, that where I could employ the people I wanted to employ, that has never been possible in a union industry. The union used to employ the labour for the employer. The employer had no say in who was employed. The union chose the employees. I am very pleased to say that that practice has now ceased in this particular instance. Hopefully, this will be a precedent for all others in the stevedoring and waterfront industries. That was one of the major problems. It is a significant breakthrough that that particular issue appears to be overcome in this instance and hopefully this will allow others to follow this course.

On the issue of preference of union labour, the Commissioner has stated that that should be left as an award issue to be dealt with later. Another matter dealt with was the question of overtime. In the past, employees could not work for the very small period that may have been needed to finish unloading or loading a ship. They had to be paid for the whole shift. As a result of this agreement today-or what I hope will be an agreement-that practice has now been reformed and the overtime can now be extended by 2 1/2 hours without the whole shift having to be paid.

The question of double headers, which I have mentioned, was also dealt with. A double header is where an employee working day shifts, works as overtime the immediately following shift. There was a proposal to take a lesser rate of pay where that happened more than a number of times in a week and to take time off in lieu. That has not been fully resolved but the employers are prepared to accept it. Another issue is referred to as two-up two-down. The Minister will no doubt give us the benefit--

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us what that is, Senator.
—The Minister would save time if he gave us a very professional, exact and detailed description of what it is. But if the Minister wants me to keep talking, I will tell him what it is.
—Tell us.
—Okay, I will tell the Minister what it is. It the is where--
—Ah, ah!
—Well, I do not have the great expertise of the Minister in these--
—You were the one who was doing the criticising. Tell us.
—I am only criticising the Minister's hopelessness in dealing with it.
—You have 20 minutes.
—All right--
—What is two-up two-down? Tell us.

—Well, it really relates to the driving of heavy equipment. The Minister wants to know what it is about; I would have thought that he might have known. CTAL requires some, but not all, drivers on any shift to drive for two consecutive work periods of 2.2 hours. These work periods are separated either by a smoko or a lunch break. Then the third period of 2.2 hours is free from driving. The union will only allow men to drive on the first and third periods whereas the employers wanted them to be able to drive on the first and second periods.
—What is two-up two-down, Senator?
—I am telling the Minister, if he will listen.
—He cannot understand it.
—What is it, Senator?
—Have I not just explained it? Is that not correct?
—We are talking about rosters.

—I am sorry, that is what Conaust says is two-up two-down and that is also what Commissioner Sweeney says is two-up two-down. If the Minister wants me to explain a little further, so that he might understand, I will read what Commissioner Sweeney says. His statement says:

SPEECH.PARA: Driving of Heavy Equipment-Two-up/Two-down
The company requires some but not all drivers-
which is exactly what I have been telling the Minister-

on any shift to drive two consecutive work periods of 2.25 hours. These work periods are separated by either a ``smoko'' or a lunch break and then the third period of 2.25 hours is free from driving. The union's position is to maintain the ``two-up/two-down'' which effectively allows men to drive on the first and third work periods.

TALK.START.PARA: —What is the two-up two-down?

—That is the Commissioner's explanation of what it is. If the Minister cannot understand it, it proves the point that I have been making that he is incompetent and should never have been put in that position. In fact, the only decent decision he has every made was to get a team of senior Ministers to help him out of the fix in the hope that it may well overcome his promise to resign in a few days time. For Senator Collins's benefit, the statement continues:

SPEECH.PARA: The Commission believes that the principles of efficient operation of mechanical equipment, multi-skilling of the work force and safety, all need to be fully tested.

The employers should, in consultation with the unions, prepare working arrangements testing the three operators for two machines with respect to mobile mechanical equipment while container crane operators should continue to work on a two-up/two-down system.

TALK.START.PARA: —And what is that, Senator?
—I have just spent five minutes and I can read it all again if Senator Collins cannot understand it. Maybe I will save my colleague's time and let him read it in Hansard.

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I raise a point of order. The Minister has consistently interjected on Senator Macdonald. Senator Macdonald has done him the courtesy of answering his incessant questions. Could we please ask for Senator Macdonald to be heard in a bit of silence.
—Order! I take the point of order, Senator Knowles. Senator Collins, you will have your chance shortly.

—It is Wednesday night and I do not want to keep my Senate colleagues too much longer from their very belated dinner break. I simply want to mention the other point that was decided which related to amenities men--
—What are they, Senator?
—The words are in my mouth to tell you. If you can just be patient for a couple of seconds I will tell you. Again, I might have thought--
—He is the Minister and should know.
—I thank Senator Knowles. I thought he might have some idea, as Minister.
—Order! There are too many interjections and, Senator Macdonald, would you address your remarks through the Chair, please?

—Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President; I should. With my colleagues here, who understand these things, of course, I do not have to explain things in minute detail. With the Minister, who is supposed to be in charge of this reform, maybe I will have to go into a little more detail.
—Who knows nothing and has done nothing.
—I must acknowledge that and repeat what my colleague said, `Who knows nothing and has done nothing'.
—What are `amenities men', Senator? You have raised it.

—I will tell the Minister again. Amenities men are people from the Waterside Workers Federation (WWF)-and the Minister might notice that I am not reading this, just to get that into the record-who were employed to clean the administration and the amenities sections of the waterfront. It had nothing to do with Waterside Workers Federation members and should have been done by other unionists, but it was done by the WWF. The Commissioner today has agreed that it should remain a WWF issue, but has commented, of course, that the work practices, which were the real concern of the employers, are another thing and that maybe they should be looked at: the number of people doing these jobs, the way they were doing them, and the management practices. It has been suggested that the WWF be allowed to remain there and, whilst not particularly happy with that, the employers in this instance have said that they will go along with it.

SPEECH.PARA: There is a brief explanation of the issues that were involved-six very major and important issues. Hopefully, if the union will do the right thing, it will acknowledge them tomorrow and that particular matter will be off the table for some time and will provide a precedent for future reform on the waterfront and in other parts of Australia. I know that there have been other places where these things were sought but were not agreed upon. I mention again Cairns, with which I am more familiar and in respect of which the Minister had the hide to stand up and say that it was beautifully done. Like one of his colleagues, I guess, he probably used such terms as `beautiful agreements' or `beautiful numbers', with just as little knowledge or understanding of what it is about.

Fortunately, this breakthrough has been made. Hopefully, the stevedores in Cairns, Townsville and Mackay will be able to look at the question again. Most importantly, wherever we go the stevedores will tell us that being able to select their own employees was paramount. It is a breakthrough. I only hope that the unions will respond accordingly and maybe-just maybe-the waterfront will be a little reformed. I again congratulate Mr Sharp, the Opposition, and those companies who held out, who would not succumb to the soft agreements, and who would not be bullied and pressured by those who have brought these corrupt practices. They deserve the nation's thanks and I certainly express that on behalf of the people that I am aware of in the industry, the people of Australia, who will benefit so much from it.

TALK.START.PARA: —You ought to give back the money they paid you for the time you made that speech.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Collins Sen The Hon R.L.

TALKER.NAME: Senator COLLINS
TALKER.ROLE: Minister for Shipping and Aviation Support)

TALK.START.PARA: —Absolutely. I had no intention, of course, of speaking on the adjournment on Wednesday night; I do not make a habit of doing it. But I am delighted that we have heard the 25 minutes of consummate drivel that we have just listened to.
—A very valuable speech.

—Indeed it was; and it will be quoted by me extensively because there is nothing that makes my heart gladder-and I did not expect to get this bonus this week-than watching an Opposition politician on the run. I was expecting this tomorrow, not this evening. What I have said consistently in the not yet 12 months that have elapsed since this process started is that the one thing members of the Opposition wanted to see this process do was fail. They have consistently demonstrated that.

SPEECH.PARA: It must have hurt Senator Macdonald when he had to leap to his feet tonight on the adjournment to try to claim credit for John Sharp for what has been a significant breakthrough in the process. I will tell the Senate why that is important. Senator Macdonald, of course, comprehensively demonstrated to everyone here tonight that he did not have the slightest idea what he was talking about. In respect of the nonsense Senator Macdonald delivered, the recruitment issue was sixth out of the six issues in terms of importance.

TALK.START.PARA: —In your mind, but that shows your ignorance of the whole issue.

—No, in terms of the Commission's mind. Senator Macdonald should look at the judgment, the Commission's decision, that he has just applauded. The most important issue was in fact the manning of heavy equipment, the one that Senator Macdonald comprehensively demonstrated he knew absolutely nothing about. I come to the decision taken this afternoon in the Commission and the statement made by Commissioner Sweeney. It should be noted by every member of the Senate-and I am delighted to say it-that Senator Macdonald, if not the most ignorant, which he most certainly is, then one of the most prolific critics of the Government's program, said this evening in applauding the decision that it is a significant breakthrough, that it is a good agreement, if it is adopted by the unions, and that I can look forward, therefore, in Senator Macdonald's own words, to having it applauded. But just note his words.
—Do you reckon it is going to stick?

—Do not kill it off before it gets a chance to be born. The Senate can see what I am talking about: the self-fulfilling prophets of doom on the other side. They complained about interjections, I note, Mr Acting Deputy President. I do not mind. But they do not want to see this program succeed; they want to see it fail. To hell with the country, they want to see it fail. What have Opposition members said about their program of waterfront reform in the last 12 months?
—More sense that you.
—Order! Senator Kemp, if you are going to interject, interject from your own chair.

—I welcome that interjection, because they made the most comprehensive statement about it a week ago from one of their shadow Ministers on the front bench. Mr McLachlan, the shadow Minister for industry and commerce, attended an industry function last week. He was confronted with a member of the industry-no friend of the Government-who jumped up and said, `You are the speaker here today on behalf of the Opposition. You have been criticising the Government for 12 months on its waterfront reform program. We are yet to hear one single piece of information from the Opposition about how you would do it instead'. That is true. Apart from the absolutely meaningless political rhetoric such as `taking the gloves off' and `getting tough with the unions' which we heard tonight, we have heard in 12 months not one single piece of policy information delivered by those opposite about how they would reform the Australian waterfront. I have been waiting for a debate in the Senate on the issue for 12 months-in vain. It has never been run by the Opposition. I am still waiting for the first waterfront debate.

SPEECH.PARA: Those opposite run repetitive matters of public importance. We had today the fourth matter of public importance in a row on the same issue-but not a debate on the waterfront. Why? Because they have nothing to say. The shadow Minister, Mr McLachlan, in response to an industry request for some information, said, `We are not going to tell you what our policy is on reforming the waterfront because we do not want Bill Kelty to know'. That was carried, I am not surprised, prominently on page two of the Australian newspaper. I must say that I am amazed that any member of the Opposition would have the hide to stand up in Parliament and even talk about waterfront reform when the shadow Minister responsible for industry and commerce says that at an industry function to an industry inquiry. It went down with the industry like a lead balloon. I heard about it long before I read about it in the Australian newspaper.

Mr McLachlan went on to say, `Well, we have got nothing to tell you about waterfront reform. We haven't got a policy on waterfront reform. We won't tell you because we don't want Bill Kelty to find out'. Now, there is a sophisticated approach to getting reform in industry. He went further and said, `Wink, wink, nudge, nudge, but there are a couple of senior people in this room who know what we will do before the next election'. Honourable senators opposite call that a policy!

Senator Macdonald said, `Conaust has not been bullied into accepting a second class agreement'. Indeed, it has not. The bullies were all on the other side. It was the bullies who wanted the second-class approach adopted by abandoning the agreement process, the one they wanted to fail because they do not believe in consensus. They do not believe in getting agreement from unions. They want to be hairy chested without specifying how. That is how they are going to do it. They do not believe in a consensus approach at all. They were quite happy to say six months ago, `Let's abandon ship. Let's go for a national brawl on the waterfront'. That is what they wanted. That is what they said. They said, `Let us take on the unions. Let us have an industrial brawl we don't need or we can't afford just for the sake of getting tough with the unions. We don't want a negotiated approach'.

It was because we did not give in to the bullies on the other side in pursuing the agreement approach which has in fact resulted in the decision today. Might I say that it would have been very easy, as a member of parliament of some 15 years standing now, to have become an instant, overnight hero- of course, it would have hurt the country-by saying, `Let's get tough with the unions. Let's take the gloves off and get stuck into the unions'.

What did Senator Macdonald do in respect of the balanced approach taken by the Opposition? I can assure Senator Macdonald that he has delivered a very quotable speech here tonight. He singled out the employing company, Conaust Pty Ltd, for praise and then attacked the union. He said that it was Conaust that had done it, as distinct from National Terminals (Australia) Ltd, which had a second-class agreement. Senator Macdonald would not know the difference between those two operations. He would be as ignorant about that as he is about what two-up two-down is. That is in fact the major issue that has been resolved this afternoon in the Commission.

TALK.START.PARA: —Tell us about two-up two-down.

—I will tell the honourable senator. It is very complicated. Senator Macdonald was not able to respond to it this afternoon. It means that there are two drivers driving machines while there are two drivers who are not driving machines. Two are up on the machine and two are down, not driving. Senator Macdonald did not know that. It does him no credit. Senator Macdonald was forced to read from a roster schedule produced in the Commission. Senator Macdonald made a fool of himself, and he knows it. He does himself no credit. It would have been the solution the Opposition was promoting, that is, confrontation and a fight on the waterfront nationally, that would have produced, as I have said many times in the last 12 months, the second best result that Senator Macdonald is talking about.
—Have the unions agreed?

—Senator Macdonald wants to wish this to death tonight, and he is trying again. As much as we get agreements, they have to be implemented. It is in the implementation of those agreements that this country will get its real productivity increases.

SPEECH.PARA: Senator Macdonald talked at length about National Terminals. I will tell Senator Macdonald why the National Terminals agreement was negotiated before the Conaust agreement. It is very simple. I ask Senator Macdonald whether he is listening. He will not know, but it is about time he did. The National Terminals company has two major terminal operations in Sydney and Melbourne. That is it. On the other hand, Conaust operates not only terminal facilities in Sydney and Melbourne but also a string of conventional stevedoring operations right around the country, including my home port of Darwin. It is in fact, although Senator Macdonald would not know it, the largest employer of waterfront labour in Australia.

Quite simply the reason the National Terminals agreement, which is an excellent agreement that is going to result in excess of 60 per cent productivity increases in that company, was negotiated before the Conaust agreement was that the operations of the two companies are totally and utterly different. National Terminals does not operate conventional stevedoring operations such as Conaust does around the country. That is why the issues were so difficult to resolve.

Twelve of the outstanding issues between the union and the company were resolved in the first few weeks of the negotiation. A further 20 were resolved in the past six months by agreement between the union and the company. Senator Macdonald singles out the employer and says that it is due to it and John Sharp, who has contributed not one jot-I ask him to look at the public record-to this process in the past 12 months and he then condemns the union. Of course, this is the night before the union is due to appear before the Commission again to indicate its position on the matter.

TALK.START.PARA: —Have they agreed?

—The process of the Commission requires the union to appear tomorrow morning at 9 o'clock. As I say, there is nothing nicer to see than an Opposition politician on the run. The Opposition did not want this process to succeed. If we have ever seen a politician on the defensive, it has been Senator Macdonald tonight. As I have said before, National Terminals is going to achieve those significant productivity improvements and also is currently engaged in a $60m upgrading program of its facilities in the port of Sydney which will make it, in fact, one of the most modern facilities in the world because of the success of the reform program and agreement it has got. It would never have spent a dollar otherwise.

SPEECH.PARA: I know that I should not be cruel to Senator Macdonald, but he talked also about overtime. He said that what has been achieved in the Commission this afternoon is an agreement that will provide for overtime to be worked, as from today, instead of just letting the ship go, whereas previously overtime was not worked. It is a piece of nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —Read the Hansard.

—The Senate record will stand. Everybody will read the Hansard. The fact is that the issue simply involved half an hour. The reason it was before the Commission is that the union has just agreed to renegotiate the rosters at the Container Terminals of Australia Ltd (CTAL) terminal in Sydney, an extremely important matter not just for the employers-I point this out to Senator Macdonald, although he does not care-but also for the employees as well whose entire lives, their family life, sporting life and everything else, revolves around the rosters they work. It all revolved around an agreement by their unions to change the rosters at CTAL to reduce them to a 7 1/2-hour roster. The argument was then that the existing extension, which has always existed in the industry-it did not just come up today-should remain at the original 2 hours or should be extended to 2 1/2 hours so that the original time period of standard shift plus overtime remained at the 10 hours it was previously. That was the issue, not the piece of nonsense Senator Macdonald delivered in the Senate tonight. In fact, in terms of Commissioner Sweeney's recommendation this afternoon it was decided that that should be the case.

SPEECH.PARA: The parties now have to consider how this agreement will be implemented. What Conaust has done in the Commission is not simply accept the recommendations of the Commission unequivocally and unilaterally, as Senator Macdonald has said. In fact, Captain Setchell of Conaust has indicated to the Commission a set of conditions. These are not the Commission's conditions, but conditions that Conaust has now placed on that acceptance and which the unions now have to consider. That would be lost on Senator Macdonald. Senator Macdonald wants to know why, when Conaust stood up in the Commission this afternoon and indicated acceptance, the unions could not immediately indicate acceptance too. The reason for this can be found in the transcript of the Commission hearing. When Conaust stated that the recommendations were acceptable to it, it said that they were acceptable `on the condition that' and retailed them. Senator Macdonald has told us only about some of them this evening. Conaust then detailed a list of conditions. These were not Commission conditions, but company conditions which Conaust wished to have implemented.

The union was hearing these conditions for the first time. Naturally, it now has to consider whether the conditions, as well as the recommendations of the Commissioner, are acceptable to it. It will appear in the Commission at 9 a.m. tomorrow. What the Opposition is running scared about now-and it is painfully obvious-is that this process may actually succeed. It is a frightening prospect for an Opposition politician. I know how it feels. I have been there myself for 10 years. I recognise an Opposition politician on the run because I have been one myself on past occasions. In conclusion, the Government also endorses the recommendation of Commissioner Sweeney.

TALK.START.PARA: —And the Conaust proposals?
—In response to that piece of nonsense, I do not yet have the full detail of Conaust's conditions because there were many of them, and I know of two at least--
—Order, Senator Kemp! There are too many interjections on my left.

—I know of two at least that were indicated by Conaust that Senator Macdonald has not canvassed this evening. When I return to my office I will have faxed to me from the Commission what the conditions are. I have not had an opportunity to read them yet because I have been in here-or have Opposition senators not noticed? The Government endorses Commissioner Sweeney's recommendations. We think they are sensible; we think they are equitable. As Captain Richard Setchell of Conaust said today, they are recommendations that will lead to very real reform and productivity increases on the Australian waterfront.

SPEECH.PARA: I have seen the Commission's recommendations, which have arrived-Captain Setchell's have not yet; they are being faxed to me by Captain Setchell now. What I do have is the Commission's transcript, and in respect of that transcript I unequivocally endorse the recommendations of Commissioner Sweeney. I would urge all of the parties-the unions and the employers-to act immediately on those recommendations and move to the conclusion of the negotiation of an enterprise agreement. That agreement, for Senator Macdonald's information, will not result simply in the CTAL agreement in Sydney being consummated-that is the reason this has been a long, drawn out process-but in a whole string of other enterprise agreements, I am sorry to tell the honourable senator, which are being negotiated in Conaust's operations right around the coast of Australia.

I want to conclude on one matter which again has escaped Senator Macdonald. Once again, he has bucketed the unions tonight. He has singled out Conaust and said how wonderful it is and it is all its achievement-something which not even Captain Richard Setchell, who runs the company, would ever say-and what a terrific achievement it is. I will tell honourable senators something about the union reality. It may well be that the working conditions that have been implemented on the Australian waterfront, and not touched by any government for the last 50 years until now, have been unproductive.

I have a copy of an interview where Captain Setchell on national television six months ago conceded publicly that the management and companies were just as much at fault as the unions in allowing these conditions to be developed. If Senator Macdonald would like a copy, I will send it to him. But in every respect, leaving aside whether the issues concerned in the work practices are good or bad, the process required of the unions has been on every occasion to negotiate giving up a condition which they have had for nearly half a century. Whether we are talking about amenities men, two-up two-down, double headers, overtime or any of the other 32 clauses that have already been negotiated by agreement prior to the Commission being involved, it has involved the union making concessions.

I have no difficulty in saying that in respect of the consummation of the national terminals agreement last year there is no argument from me that these conditions had to be given up, but they did have to be given up by the union. The company was in the position of getting productivity gains. It was easy for the company in a real life industrial situation to make ground because it was gaining, but in every case it required the unions to give up--

TALK.START.PARA: —So was Australia.

—That is correct. It is because of the commitment the unions have given to delivering real reform by agreement that that agreement was negotiated last year. I am absolutely confident that it will be because of that same commitment, publicly expressed many times by the union leadership, to get reform on the waterfront for the sake of this country and indeed for the industry and its members that the Conaust agreement will also-much to the chagrin and disgust of Senator Macdonald and his colleagues-be consummated by this process of agreement. When it is, the Government's targets set for both productivity and for redundancies will not only be met but substantially exceeded.
—Mr Acting Deputy President-
—You can't speak twice on the adjournment.
—Senator Macdonald, are you rising on a point of order?

—Yes, Mr Acting Deputy President, I am rising on a point of order. I am glad that you are in the chair and not the Minister, who is obviously trying to run it. Pursuant to standing order 191, I claim to have been misquoted. I certainly would not enter into a debate with the Minister over his arguments, which do him no justice and belittle his position as a Minister. But I want to raise two matters where the Minister deliberately misquoted. First, he said that I mentioned that there were a number of conditions from Conaust. There were three, and I said it. The Minister tried to indicate that I had said something else. Secondly, the Minister deliberately misquoted me when he told the Senate that I said that no overtime had ever been worked on the waterfront. That is an outright an untruth. It does not do a Minister of the Crown any credit at all to go around making accusations which he knows are completely untrue simply to try to belittle a senator of this Parliament--

—Mr Acting Deputy President, I wish to raise a point of order. We have given a fair bit of latitude to the honourable senator. He knows full well that we are not allowed to debate personal explanations. We simply have to indicate where we have been misquoted. In concluding the point of order, there is only one thing better than watching an Opposition senator make a mug of himself, and that is watching an Opposition senator know he has made a mug of himself.
—I do not believe there is a point of order, Minister. Senator Macdonald, I believe you had finished explaining your point of order?
—I had. It was urged that I should ask the Minister to withdraw, but I would not even bother. He belittles his position and we might leave it at that.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Alston Sen R.K.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services, upon notice, on 17 October 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) What did the department pay out in rental costs for all its CES service outlets during 1989-90 and how much rent was paid for each service outlet.
(2) What is the estimate of the total rent bill for all CES service outlets for 1990-91.
(3) As of 30 June 1990, what percentage of CES offices were co-located with Social Security regional offices.
(4) By the end of 1990-91, what percentage of CES offices does the department expect will be co-located with Social Security regional offices.
(5) What labour market programs are administered in any and what ways through CES offices.
(6) What is a description of these programs.
(7) How many people does the department expect to participate in each of these programs for 1990-91: (a) nationally; and (b) by State and Territory.
(8) What was the average period of employment in the CES office for permanent departmental officers who completed spells of employment in a CES office during 1989-90.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Higher Education and Employment Services has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Rental costs for all CES service outlets during 1989-90 totalled $35.8M. These payments were made on behalf of the Department by the Department of Administrative Services. Details of individual payments are being obtained from this agency and will be forwarded to the Senator when received.
(2) The estimated total rent bill for CES service outlets for 1990-91 is $40.3M.
(3) The percentage of CES offices that are either co-located or within 3 minutes walking distance of Social Security regional offices as at 30 June 1990 was 49%.
(4) It is anticipated that by the end of 1990-91 this percentage will be 50%. It should be noted that this corresponds to 66% of DSS offices.

The Job Search Training, JOBTRAIN, and JOBSTART elements of the Employment Access sub-program are delivered through the CES. Monitoring and administrative functions are performed both in the Department of Employment, Education and Training's (DEET's) Area and State Offices, and in Central Office.
CES Offices are involved in the operations of the SkillShare and New Enterprise Incentive Scheme (NEIS) elements of the Community-based Strategies sub-program through:
- referring potential participants to SkillShare projects;
- acting as the principal point of contact with SkillShare project sponsors and responding to inquiries;
- promoting NEIS and providing information about the Scheme to clients;
- referring prospective participants to DEET State Offices/State governments and/or managing agents; and
- processing payments of Formal Training Allowance with respect to participants in NEIS training courses.
The CES may also provide information to establish NEIS participant eligibility and may also be represented on NEIS approval committees.
Aboriginal employment and training assistance is provided through the Training for Aboriginals Program (TAP) utilising two different delivery mechanisms:
- training and job subsidy assistance for individuals is delivered through various CES outlets; and

- community employment and education development assistance is administered by Aboriginal field officers through the various Aboriginal Employment and Education Development Units (AEEDU's) attached to DEET Area Offices.
The Mobility Assistance Scheme is delivered through the CES with monitoring and administrative functions performed by DEET's Area, State and Central Offices.
CES staff are responsible for the delivery of this sub-program to eligible clients and for its administration.

The JOBTRAIN program provides opportunities for the long-term unemployed or other especially disadvantaged job seekers to receive vocational training based on opportunities in the local labour market.

JOBSTART is a general wage subsidy program which provides access to employment for job seekers who have experienced long periods of unemployment or face other disadvantages in obtaining work. Under the program employers receive subsidy payments for up to 20 weeks as an incentive for engaging and improving the employment prospects of these disadvantaged job seekers.
The Job Search Training Program aims to address the employment needs of disadvantaged job seekers by providing them with intensive instruction in job search techniques.
There are two components to the program:
- Job Clubs, which provide for intensive supervised training and job hunting over 3 weeks; and
- Job Search Training Courses, which provide 20 hours of formal job search training.

SkillShare is a community-based labour market program targeted at the most disadvantaged in the labour market. It operates as an Australia-wide network of local projects managed by non-profit community organisations or local government authorities (known as sponsors) with the skills and experience to assist long-term and other most disadvantaged unemployed people gain work and proceed to further education or training.

Sponsors receive funding to provide a range of practical, innovative activities and services responsive to the needs of the target group and taking into account opportunities in the local labour market. The relevant Area Director of the Department of Employment Education and Training, is responsible for the funding of SkillShare projects.

In line with the Government's efficiency and equity objectives for the labour market, SkillShare aims to assist long-term unemployed and other most disadvantaged unemployed people to increase their skill levels through:
- the provision of structured skills training and other employment-related activities;
- the provision of enterprise activities; and
- referral to other more formal employment or training programs or services.

NEIS provides assistance for unemployed people to set up self employment ventures. The Scheme operates as a partnership between the Commonwealth and either State/Territory Governments or private sector and non-government organisations. The assistance provides a comprehensive support package for participants during the crucial establishment phase, increasing their opportunity to establish themselves successfully in permanent self-employment.

The Commonwealth provides 12 months income support, broadly equivalent to Job Search Allowance, and training in business plan development and small business management skills. This is complemented by start-up capital and business advice provided by State/Territory Governments or other organisations participating in NEIS jointly with the Commonwealth.

The target group for NEIS is unemployed people registered with the CES, in receipt of or dependent on Job Search Allowance or certain other Social Security benefits or pensions, aged from l7 years through to the ages for Aged Pension eligibility. Proposed businesses must be new, independent, reputable and assessed as commercially viable and meeting an unsatisfied demand.

Detail of the various elements of TAP are provided in the explanatory notes and the DEET Programs booklet for 1989/90. Essentially, the sub-program provides wage subsidies and training assistance to assist Aboriginal people to obtain employment and to enhance the prospects for career development of Aboriginal people already employed. Assistance is also provided for Aboriginal participation in community enterprises.

The primary aim of Mobility Assistance is to contribute to the efficient, effective and equitable functioning of the labour market by giving job seekers access to training and jobs which are not locally available, while also helping employers to obtain workers with appropriate skills.
Mobility Assistance includes the following elements:
Sub-Program 5.3-Industry and Regional Labour Adjustment Assistance

The sub-program provides a range of labour market measures administered under the auspices of the Office of Labour Market Adjustment (OLMA). They cover training or other re-employment assistance, directed to workers in particular industries undergoing structural change in recognition of the need for enhanced competitiveness, and to workers losing employment as a result of structural adjustment or specific Commonwealth Government decisions. The assistance is available in specific packages of `mixes' according to the assessed needs of the workers in the particular industry or region.
Numbers of anticipated commencements of the component programs are current as at 7 January 1991.

The SkillShare program operates on a calendar year basis, with projects receiving funding to provide a program which runs from 1 January to 31 December. Information is therefore provided on expected participation for 1990.

No targets are set for the Mobility Assistance Scheme.

It is difficult to forecast assistance under the program as it is demand driven, that is the potential demand for program assistance is dependent upon fluctuations in retrenchment activity in designated industries-companies, the effects of structural and other changes on regional labour markets, and the capacity of the broader economy to absorb workers displaced in these processes.
(8) The officers who separated from the CES in 1989-90 numbered 359. The average period of employment in CES offices by these officers is not available in readily accessible form.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Newman Sen J.M.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 26 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Did consultants present a report on commercial vehicles for the defence forces at the end of 1988; if so, what is the name of this report, what did it contain and is it possible to obtain a copy.
(2) Have any of the recommendations of the report been implemented; if so, which ones.

(3) Has there been any resistance to introducing management information systems and commercial vehicle management practices to manage the Services' vehicle fleets; if so, what resistance and from where.
(4) Are the Services aware of the personnel costs involved in operating commercial vehicle fleets, if so, are any reports made to senior management.
(5) Is it correct that the Services do not know what their real operating costs are for fuel, oil, servicing, spare parts, labour, tyres, repairs and accidents.
(6) Has there been an increase in the contracting out of the management of commercial vehicles; if so, what is the current situation in regard to this.
(7) Has the Department of Defence estimated what it might cost to commercialise the Services' vehicle fleets; if so, what are the costs and if not, why not.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) Pak-Poy and Kneebone Pty Ltd with Henderson Consultants reviewed the Defence commercial vehicle fleets in 1988 with assistance from a Defence Review Team and presented the following reports:
Consultancy Study-Army Commercial Vehicle Fleet Phase lB
Consultancy Study-Review of Defence Commercial Vehicle Fleet Phase 2 (Navy, Air Force, remainder of Defence)
Copies of these reports are available.
(2) The following recommendations agreed by the Services are being implemented:

The Services should maintain the ownership of their CL vehicle fleets but in so doing should adopt new acquisition and disposal criteria which are no less advantageous than those pursued by DAS and commercial operators.

Even though there would be a long term cost advantage from the Department owning its own fleet, at this stage it should continue to hire its CL vehicles from DAS where it does so at present (ownership would require Government approval for an exemption from current rules).

A substantially self-funding arrangement should be adopted in which funds generated from the disposal of Service CL vehicles are preserved and applied directly to the procurement of replacement Service CL vehicles.
In the present sales tax free environment, a basic replacement criteria of 2 years/40000 km should be adopted to maximise the sales tax advantages of selffunding.

An automated fleet management information system (Fleet MIS) should be introduced by each Vehicle Controller within Defence to provide information to allow managers to make timely decisions and to enable their fleets, as a whole, to be operated in a cost-effective manner.
The arrangements and organisational structures for the management of the various fleets should be simplified and the resources devoted to vehicle fleet management should be reduced.
A standardised system of vehicle nomenclature and groupings should be adopted throughout Defence.
VIP and ceremonial Service vehicles should continue to be purchased in Service colours. Other vehicles should be purchased in colours which maximise the returns from sale.
Defence air-conditioning policies should be reviewed.
Vehicles should be purchased with accessories, options and specifications which would optimise returns from sale.
Whole of life costs should be considered during acquisition.
Defence should establish and maintain appropriate channels of communication with DAS and pursue the scope for obtaining discounts in other than just the long haul area.
The scope for increased use of civilian contractors for repair and maintenance should be examined.
A series of initiatives should be taken to develop and introduce disposal arrangements which would optimise returns from the sale of Defence owned vehicles.

(3) In the early stages, some resistance was experienced but, as staff have become better informed and more aware of the benefits of improved fleet management practices, this resistance is no longer evident and indeed has been replaced by support.

(4) The Services are aware, at the macro level, of the personnel costs involved in operating commercial vehicle fleets. There is not the same awareness at the micro levels where the actual vehicles are managed. There are currently no regular reports of these particular personnel costs made to senior management. However the Commercial Vehicle Management Program initiatives now being introduced will improve visibility of these costs at all levels of management.

(5) As with personnel costs, vehicle operating and maintenance costs are available at a macro level. Current management information systems do not readily provide detailed information on operating costs for commercial vehicles. The introduction of a new Fleet Management Information System in early 1991 will provide the means for the Services to capture, analyse and report this information down to the level of individual vehicles if required.
(6) The management of the Services commercial vehicle fleets is not contracted out. The consultants recommended that the management of commercial vehicles remain within Defence.

(7) The estimated cost to bring the Services' commercial vehicle fleets up to an efficient standard was an additional $36m over two years. Substantial savings would then accrue. These funds are not available and a longer term funding option is being undertaken with additional funds being provided to the Services for implementation of the initiatives.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Reid Sen M.E.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Treasurer, upon notice, on 29 November 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Is the Australian Government aware of any breaches by the Italian Government of the Convention in force between Australia and Italy for the prevention of double taxation. Specifically, is the Australian Government aware of any instances where the Italian Government is taxing Italian pensions paid to residents of Australia.

(2) If the Government is aware of such breaches, what action does it propose to take to ensure the Convention is complied with so that recipients of Italian pensions residing in Australia are not taxed twice.
(3) If the Government is presently unaware of any breaches, will it undertake to investigate the matter further to ensure no such breach is occurring.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Button Sen The Hon J.N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Treasurer has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) It is relevant to refer to procedures agreed with the Italian Government concerning the exemption from Italian tax provided by the double taxation convention for pensions paid from Italy to residents of Australia.

These procedures require a pension recipient to lodge a form with the pension payer in order to stop Italian tax being withheld and to obtain a refund of any such tax withheld. Those forms, which are available from Italian consulates in Australia, require an endorsement from the Australian Taxation Office that the pensioner is a resident of Australia and is therefore entitled to the Italian tax exemption accorded by the convention. These procedures were the subject of a press release issued on 15 April 1988 by the Commissioner of Taxation after consultation with the Italian Embassy.

They were also referred to in a comprehensive Ruling issued on 10 August 1989 by the Commissioner to clarify a number of issues regarding the tax treatment of Italian pensions. Both the press release and the Ruling were widely reported in the Italian press in Australia.
The Government understands that these procedures are operating satisfactorily to avoid recipients of Italian pensions residing in Australia being taxed twice.

The CDEP scheme provides a basic grant equivalent to the surrendered benefits and additional grants for administration and capital equipment. CDEP forms an important part of the Aboriginal Employment Development Policy.
Communities in New South Wales which have participated in CDEP in 1988-89, 1989-90, and 1990-91 are:
(3) All but 1 of the participating organisations has provided 1988/89 documentation enabling acquittal of grants received that year:
ENNGONIA (MURRAWARRI) The Audit Report has been prepared. The Auditor is awaiting payment in order for the report to be released and the acquittal to take place.

All but 8 of the participating communities have provided 1989/90 documentation enabling acquittal of grants received that year. Audited financial statements are still outstanding from: Gulargambone, Coonamble, Warren, Wilcannia, Enngonia, Lightning Ridge, Walgett and Wallaga Lake.

(4) COLLARENEBRI Investigations have indicated that there have been nine ``cash'' cheques presented to the value of $5,338.95. This practice was enough in the way of a procedural discrepancy for the Regional Manager to take steps to cease funding the organisation directly and to arrange payment through another organisation.

WILCANNIA A loan of $1,500 to an employee from wages is being repaid by fortnightly deductions. The matter has been investigated by ATSIC and the organisation has undertaken that this situation will not occur again.

WALGETT ATSIC is aware of allegations concerning unapproved cash transactions outside the Community's approved budget. These allegations are presently under investigation by ATSIC Bourke Regional Office.

(5) A qualified audit report was received by the Toomelah Aboriginal Co-operative Ltd for the financial year ending 30 June 1989. Shortcomings in the administration of funds were identified relevant to internal controls and procedures.

Aboriginal Employment Development Policy (AEDP) agencies, namely Department of Employment Education and Training, Department of Social Security and ATSIC are working closely with the community and progress has been made in overcoming these inadequacies as indicated by the audit report to 30 June 1990.

(6) An evaluation of Grant Acquittals for all Programs is currently being conducted by the Office of Evaluation and Audit on a national basis. The Office will be involved in an evaluation of CDEP this calendar year.

(8) COMMUNITY DEVELOPMENT PLANS The Commission acknowledges the importance of community development plans. New South Wales has commissioned MSJ KEYS YOUNG PLANNERS PTY LTD and other consultants to assist CDEP communities in this task. Eight communities have development plans or have reviews/economic studies underway.

Under the new administrative arrangements for CDEP, communities will have to provide a CDEP works program when making applications for CDEP grant funds. The works program will comprise a list of projects that the community sees as important to its social, cultural, recreational and economic development.
Communities are being encouraged to develop specific CDEP plans and/or community development plans. The CDEP works program would be an integral part of either of these plans.
All CDEP grants are assessed by the Commission on the annual ``Grant Assessment Form'' which is completed by Regional Officers as part of the annual draft estimates documentation.

In addition to the annual grant assessment all CDEP projects are to be fully reviewed on a three year cycle commencing in 1991/92. It is envisaged that these reviews will be undertaken by officers from the Commission and the Departments of Employment, Education and Training and Social Security.
NSW has reviewed three projects that commenced in 1988/89, namely: Toomelah; Glen Innes and Murrin Bridge. The findings of these reviews are being implemented.

Under new administrative arrangements priorities for the allocation of CDEP Oncost and Support funds will be determined by Regional Managers in consultation with Regional Councils and CDEP communities and organisations.

It is acknowledged that some communities do not always submit fortnightly variation schedules. However, while this can cause short term inaccuracies, community entitlements are adjusted when subsequent schedules are received.

The Commission will be introducing administrative changes to the CDEP scheme to take effect from 1 April 1991. These changes have been designed to simplify the calculation of communities' entitlements and should reduce the possibility of inaccuracies. This streamlining will assist the monitoring process.

The lack of qualified Aboriginal people has been a problem for DAA/ATSIC and communities alike. Training initiatives have been taken by DAA/ATSIC and the Department of Employment, Education and Training to address this issue.

As a part of new administrative arrangements for CDEP, a Training Needs Schedule and a training program to meet these needs for each CDEP is required. Through programs administered by the Department of Employment, Education and Training (Training for Aboriginals Program) funding is available for communities to engage a consultant, where appropriate, to prepare training needs analyses and/or training schedules for project participants.

Since the ANAO audits of Queensland, Western Australia and the Northern Territory were conducted there has been a significant improvement in the take up rate of the Family Allowance Supplement by CDEP participants. The Department of Social Security is promoting this allowance through its Aboriginal Liaison Officers and Community Agents.
While ATSIC encourages the payment of wages at award rates, the setting of tasks, and hours of each participant, is left to the discretion of community councils and organisations.

Award coverage for CDEP communities is a complex issue as the nature of the work generally is only part-time. The Commission is currently in the process of contracting a consultant to undertake research into industrial relations issues associated with CDEPs including the question of award coverage.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 17 December 1990:

QUESTION.PARA: What has been the number of persons registered for employment, and the unemployment rate, for each quarter since September 1989 for the Federal Electorates of Ballarat, Burke and Wills.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: Data on the number of persons registered as unemployed and seeking employment (Unemployed Awaiting Placement) at local CES office or other small area level are not released as these figures are neither an accurate measure of unemployment, nor a reliable indicator of changes in unemployment, for the following reasons:

* coverage of job seekers can vary over time as a result of changes in labour market conditions, variations in administrative procedures and the effects of Government policy, especially the impact of changes in labour market programs;
* some jobseekers remain registered with the CES although they have either independently found employment or left the labour force but have not notified the CES;
* not all people seeking employment register with the CES for assistance; and

* at the local level the inaccuracies and distortions in the data which often occur are especially significant, and there are concerns that these figures may have been given undue emphasis in the past in determining plans and resource allocations in local communities.
In any event, the Department does not hold these data grouped into electorates.

The following table of unemployment rates is based on Australian Bureau of Statistics (ABS) Labour Force estimates and provides the information requested by the honourable Senator in relation to the unemployment rate in the areas broadly covered by the three electorates.
Unemployment Rates for ABS Labour Force Regions

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Spindler Sen S.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training, upon notice, on 23 January 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: Why will Victoria, which has already experienced severe education cuts as a consequence of the ALP State Government's Budget, receive no share of the $9m of additional Federal funds allocated to the Disadvantaged Schools Program in the 1990-91 Federal Budget.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen The Hon N.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Minister for Employment, Education and Training has provided the following answer to the honourable senator's question:

ANSWER.PARA: - The Government has introduced a new national index of disadvantage for the allocation of 1991 Disadvantaged Schools Program funds, including the additional $9m made available in the 1990-91 Federal Budget. The index seeks to identify the most seriously socio-economic disadvantaged communities in Australia, and is based on 1986 Census data and an analysis of schools' catchment areas.
- The new index adopts the following six variables with the weightings indicated:

- The basic index would have resulted in reductions in funding to the government school sectors in Victoria and the Northern Territory, and to the non-government school sectors in New South Wales, Queensland, South Australia and Western Australia. However, the Government decided that no State-sector would receive less in 1991 under the new index than it had in 1990. As a result, allocations for the potential losers are being maintained at 1990 funding levels in real terms at a total cost of $1.6m. Their enrolment ceilings are also being maintained at 1990 levels.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Durack Sen The Hon P.D.

TALK.START.PARA: asked the Minister for Defence, upon notice, on 23 January 1991:

QUESTION.PARA: (1) Has an adequate roll-over protection system been fitted to the Perentie series 110 Landrover; if so, when and is the Minister satisfied with the action that has been taken in this regard.
(2) Will the Minister pursue an investigation into the safety of the vehicle.
(3) Will the Minister make public the findings relating to the question of this vehicle's safety.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —The answer to the honourable senator's question is as follows:

ANSWER.PARA: (1) The Land Rover 110 vehicle was introduced into service with roll-over protection designed to protect occupants specifically against possible roll-over when the vehicle was negotiating difficult slopes at slow speed. Its predecessors, the Land Rover Series 2, 2A and 3, had no roll-over protection.

(2) Extensive investigations into the safety of the vehicle have been conducted over a number of months. An analysis of the results of the investigations conducted to date indicates that, properly driven, the Land Rover 110 vehicle performs better than its predecessors.
(3) There are ongoing investigations into the dynamics of the vehicle and, as appropriate, the results of these investigations could be made available when completed.
In addition to the ongoing investigations into the dynamics of the vehicle, the following actions are being taken:
- the correct driving techniques are being emphasised during driving training; and
- additional roll-over protection will be installed commencing in February 1991.
